But once I adjusted, I could appreciate a story with continuously shifting story lines, all held together by the central character. First I thought this was a book about a severely dysfunctional family, then add in an extremely accurate and poetic portrait about the ecology of the North Carolina coastal marsh (a reference to Aldo Leopold hooked me in), then we find out the main story line is a murder mystery. How can you beat a well written story, with depth in each story line, continuously shifting themes, and  finally an ending that is predictable but surprising never -the- less. And, I love the title.
title: Intreging chacter whose story line keeps shifting

author: MaddieD
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2020
review_content: Warning:  may be spoilers.  Many people have certain beefs with this book.  The geography is way off, the type of wetland is decidedly fanciful (where are there beaches, cypress, and other types of marsh along with tidal estuaries all together?) and some aspects of the plot stretch credulity.  However, the psychological portrait of motherloss, abusive family dynamics and abandonment are accurate and beautiful, as is the depiction of the love of nature.  People claim that a small child cannot raise herself--her father was there for part of time, and she looked after her self on a minimal, survival level.  Out of necessity, she found a way to survive.  Small town dynamics are different than a lot of people are used to.  People know a lot about others, and yet many things are not spoken of.  Some readers blame Tate for his abandonment of her without taking into a account that he was very young at the time.  It is true that both Tate and Chase are reduced to mere types, but how many books feature female characters that have been put in similar simplistic categories.  The only part of the book I found completely jarring was the second secret life, which just seems improbable.  I would also like to point out that while the trial took place after the Civil Rights Act of 1964, that did not instantly change long held habits, especially in relatively backward areas.
title: Flawed but emotionally wonderful

author: Shelly Hammond
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2020
review_content: With over 50,000 ratings I think you probably know what this is about so I'm just going straight into the opinion part of the review.This is a good story. There were times that I found it dragging a little and I drifted off. At these times I was thinking it was a 3 to 3.5 star rating. I always liked it but would get bogged down a little. Of course I read this in a day which could have something to do with that. By the time I got to the end though, it was a solid 4.The writing is really good. It's written in a way that you really feel like the characters are a live as you are reading it. As if the author wrote them to life (or death, whichever fits). The scenery is perfectly written so that is also very well imagined as it's being read. The whole story comes alive. It's a movie in your mind as you read. That's not easy to do but it's done here.The end is terrific. Even if you see certain things coming the way it's done is great. You may not have expected things to be exactly what they wind up being. I can't say too much but I can say it was good. The whole book was good. I enjoyed it and would recommend giving it a shot if you are curious about it at all. It's worth trying out at least.
title: Very good story

author: Marysusan F.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2019
review_content: The author wrote a heart wrenching, disturbing and sad tale that drew you in until the end which sends you crashing. I was with this one until the end and it was so horrifyingly disappointing.that I just can’t rate this any higher.?
title: Disturbing

author: Book Addict
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2019
review_content: Where the Crawdads Sing by Delia Owens sat on my book shelf for months waiting patiently until I had the time and inclination to read. Highly recommended from friends, the book remained unopened.Then I attended a writer's workshop with several successful authors. A question asked of a local North Carolina bestselling author resulted in a wave of comments raising disdain for the acclaimed novel.Guess what I did when I came home? Right. I opened the book and dug into it. Before I heard one more comment--negative or positive--I needed to determine for myself what I thought about the book.Once started, I had to finish. Good sign. The language of the naturalist captured me in its net. I lost myself in the descriptions of island life off the coast of North Carolina where even the tiniest of creatures and the most obscure of flora received its due. The character of Kaya broke my heart in its innocence and cheered my heart for her resilience. Tension builds throughout as she learns more about the world away from her narrow experience with human life forms after abandonment by those who should have taken care of her.But...and this is a big one...this book published by G.P. Putnam's Sons contains some errors that should make the editors at the big house cringe and rush to correct. The first one that disappointed me occurred while the police chief and deputy sit after a long day of detective work to figure out who murdered a local man. They are on the deck of their station facing the marsh and then the Atlantic Ocean beyond. The author writes that the two are drinking a beer while watching the sunset. I read the line to my husband and asked him to tell me the location of the novel. "California," he replied. You'd think. But no. A simple, silly mistake that should have been caught and corrected.Then there are multiple references to folks in this small community heading on over to Asheville, North Carolina, as if it's just a short jaunt. Once it's when the father needs to check on his disability payments. In another instance, a mother wants a special gift, but the Ace Hardware near the island didn't carry it so she drives over to Asheville . Sorry, but Asheville may be recognizable to the rest of the country, but anyone who knows the area knows two things. Asheville isn't a big city nor the closest one to the coast. Try Raleigh or Charlotte for checking in the with the VA. Same with the Ace Hardware. I don't think a busy struggling mother would drive more than three hundred miles for a toy when other larger cities are much closer. The critics at the writing conference where I first heard of this complaint speculated that the publishers wanted to use a popular town as reference. But anyone who knows the state at all knows that Asheville is the furthermost city from the coast located in the western part of North Carolina.Fiction elaborates, exaggerates, enhances, and embellishes reality. But if an author uses real places, facts and details should be accurate. I usually put down books that contain such blatant errors. Fortunately, Ms. Owens created such an otherwise compelling read, I forgave and forged ahead to the end. I don't blame her. I blame her editors and proofreaders. I recommend reading the book and ignoring the stupid errors. It's worth it and captures the life teeming on the sea shores in all its bizarre, beautiful, and horrific glory.Click here for Where the Crawdads Sing by Delia Owens
title: It's worth it to overlook the errors made by the editors

author: Lisa BoBisa
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2019
review_content: Some of the dialogue in the beginning is forced and unnatural, and some of the characters were stereotypical, but I was willing to ignore that for awhile. However, the author is apparently unable to read a map. In North Carolina, Asheville is the state's most famous town, but it is SEVEN HOURS of interstate driving from the coast. Back in the 50's and 60's, and/or with kids in the car, it would be even longer. Plus, in the 59's and 69's, it was a fairly small town. People at the coast would never have "run over to Asheville" for anything, as the characters in this book did at least 3 times before I gave up. Going to Asheville would not have been a 2-day, weekend trip from the coast, either, as happened once. Nevermind the fact that to get to Asheville from the coast, those characters would have had to drive THROUGH at least 2 bigger cities. Ridiculous. So many other little things were of about the setting and how people talk, but this was the one that was unforgivable for me.
title: Starts good, then fizzles

author: abcthatsme
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2020
review_content: The fact that it is labelled as part murder mystery made me pass it up at first (I'm one of those "not a murder mystery person" types), but I'm so glad I finally read it. In the end I realized the murder mystery is 100% necessary for the book to be as impactful as it is, and thankfully it doesn't actually read as a murder mystery. The story is about the coming of age of a young woman, and the murder fits within and is such an important part of that coming of age story - both in the troubles it highlights throughout her life up until that point, and in the ways it affects her in the aftermath. The murder is not the main point, it is part of the larger coming of age story. Don't shy away if you have a similar hesitation -- it's totally worth it.I don't have many books that I say I want to read again, immediately after finishing them. This is one of those books. I am shaken by how well-written this is, how intricate and emotional it is (and a roller coaster of emotion, at that), and how deeply it touched me. I cried throughout, my heart broke multiple times, and in the end, the book struck the perfect balance between happiness and sadness, love and loss. Once I started this book, I truly could not stop, reading until I fell asleep every night, and finishing the last 200 pages in one day. I finished the entire 370 pages in 1 week (a huge record for me).
title: Don't shy away just because you're "not a murder mystery person"!!

author: Lilli
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2021
review_content: I wanted to like this book, but it was so unoriginal. If you have seen the movie, Nelle, or read Island of Blue Dolphins, then you will see too many similarities to the point you assume she took plot events from those stories to create her own. I am from NC and not impressed with her description of the coast and the people. There are too many loopholes in the book, as well. Kya has no food and then she’s eating a sausage biscuit. How does she survive being seven and on her own? How does she just suddenly know how to read without much struggle when a teenager is teaching her over a course of a few months? Some of this is just mind boggling because it doesn’t make sense. You wonder how she takes care of herself and survives. There is no mention of a hurricane, which we know she had to go through one because she is on the coast, and there are and have been hurricanes. I was just unimpressed. The story is good but has been written by taking ideas from others, which I do not find entertaining.
title: Too much like Island of Blue Dolphins- completely unoriginal

author: R. Black
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2019
review_content: I really enjoyed this book. I picked it for its great reviews and favorable commentary from many book clubs. Living in the south myself, I was intrigued by the story’s location and wanted an enjoyable, “take-me-away”, poolside read. The plot and characters are well developed throughout the book and the further I read, I found myself feeling empathy for the story’s main character. The circumstances as they unfold, made me recognize just how important a person’s upbringing and early years are, and even more importantly, how formative they can be as we move from a child into an adult. The author also does a great job of helping you visualize the surroundings of where the story takes place, and in an interesting way, weaves her knowledge of nature and the natural environment into the story. While the beginning of the book brings to light some sad and difficult issues, the story itself evolves over time to focus on the rich personal relationships that are formed, shining a light on the resilience of the human spirit. The book kept my interest throughout and provided enough plot twists to keep me guessing and turning another page. Gladly recommend it be added to your reading list.
title: Hope this book becomes a movie!

author: Jess G.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2021
review_content: Beautiful and symobolic book about a girl abandoned by her family and town who finds solace in mother nature, in the marsh along the North Carolina coast. In nature she finds independence and thrives, she finds peace after surviving so much loss. The book spans years, following Kya from childhood to woman. Through love and murder.  I should also note that the authors writing style is very unique and quite frankly, BEAUTIFUL. Where the Crawdads Sing reads like poetry and the descriptions of nature are so beautiful it might bring tears to your eyes.  The author transports you to the marsh, along with it's smells and sounds. Definitely read this book!
title: Reads like poetry.

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2021
review_content: I came to this book after reading Deborah Spera's excellent first novel Call Your Daughter Home. After finishing, I read the reviews on Amazon, which compared Deb Spera's book to this one. As most reviews go, everyone has an opinion, and I didn't let the 5-star reviews or the 1-star reviews sway me in either direction. I found the premise of Where The Crawdads Sing compelling and decided to read it. I'm glad that I did. Although the two books are quite different, they both have a way of pulling you into the characters' environment and creating empathy for the women in their stories. I laughed, and I cried, I was shocked and angry. I enjoyed both equally, for they evoked emotion in me, and that's why I read fiction. For the 1 star reviews, I'd say, "Get over yourselves."  The author can create whatever she wants. For those that criticize the writing for lack of detail about a character, write your own novel. I'm glad I live in a place where I accept literary works as they are and not as I want them to be. I highly recommend both books, warts and all.
title: Wonderful 1st Novel

author: Annie Oakley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2020
review_content: I was disappointed, for sure but I concede that a young woman (or a woman of any age struggling with profound loneliness) at ta pivotal moment of her life may find that this story really resonates with her.  Not me.  It was nice to learn about the natural life in the marsh but I was expecting much better writing and story line.  The dialogue was "meh."  The story was quite superficial.  I never got a good grasp of what motivated the main female character (whose name I've already forgotten even though I just finished the book last week).  Her awkward attempts to fit into mainstream teenage scene and various adolescent crushes and her responses to breakups were just what I'd expect in a Y.A. novel.  And then there's the police procedural story line that was more of a distraction than anything else (featuring some of the worst writing). The rush to include a summary of her life up to and including her death in the last pages of the book were totally unnecessary.  Is it me or do some of the NYT bestsellers like this one disappoint greatly?  I've learned to be more and more discerning of NYT bestsellers over the years.  Just because a book is on the list longer than any other novel of its kind does not make it a great book.
title: It's not great writing - it reads like a Y.A. novel

author: Ada
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2020
review_content: I really wanted to enjoy this book but sadly it fails as both a "coming of age" story and a "whodunit". Without giving away any of the plot (such as it were) there is a huge problem with the murder scenario and the actual details of how the victim got to the scene of the crime to begin with are lacking. The timeline of when detailed information about the murder is made public also has a glaring error. Most disappointing is the story of how Kya raised herself from the age of 6 alone in a marsh. Even with maximum suspension of disbelief there is just too much to overcome to make this an enjoyable read. I'll also add as someone who has lived the majority of her life in the south and Lowcountry  I feel the author describes a swamp more than a marsh. After all the positive reviews reading this book was a complete disappointment.
title: Requires maximum suspension of disbelief

author: Rosiegirl
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2019
review_content: If Olive Kitteridge had reviewed this book she would have deemed it "dopey"An unbelievable story at times redeemable then sinking into melodramatic mush.  Agree with others, does Reese Witherspoon actually read these books or does she just "loan" her name out?First book I actually caught myself rolling my eyes as I read it.
title: Crawdad's didn't sing

author: SouthernGal820
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2020
review_content: I wish I knew how many books I have read in my lifetime.  I have always been a reader, taught early in life by my Mother to both read and appreciate books. There have been few books that upon reading the last page, elicit a simple word from me...Wow.  One I recall was All the Light We Cannot See.  Reaching the end of Where the Crawdads Sing...wiping tears from my cheeks I said out loud, Wow.  This is such a beautifully written book that you are there seeing the beautiful grasses, birds and beach yet you feel at times the loneliness of Kya, the joy when she is with the seagulls, her love for Tate. What a book, what a story.  I highly recommend this lovely book, this both sad and sweet yet, very complex story.
title: Beautifully Written

author: The Brown Bookloft
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2019
review_content: Summary: When Kya is six years old, she watches her mother walk away. Most of her siblings drift away, too, unable to live any longer with their drunken, abusive father. Kya’s older brother sticks around just long enough to teach her some basic survival skills, then he, too, vanishes. Kya learns to live around her father, vanishing into the woods and marsh to avoid his beatings. After a while, he also takes off. Kya is now ten years old and all alone in the North Carolina marsh.With the kindness and friendship of the few people she comes in contact with, Kya manages to eke out a living selling shellfish. She wanders, collecting feathers, shells and plants. She meets a boy a few years older than herself who teaches her to read and write. Tate is kind and patient, and a gentle, youthful romance blossoms between them. Kya no longer feels so alone.But in the town, the adults scorn her and call her dirty “Marsh Girl”. The group of popular kids think it’s fun sport to frighten Kya. When one of them takes things too far, there are horrific consequences.Comments: I finally gave up on waiting for Where the Crawdads Sing at the library and purchased a copy. It was worth every penny. The lyrical language and descriptions drew me into Kya’s environment. I heard the shore birds, felt the spray and salt on my skin, the humidity dampening my hair. The author obviously knows how to write about natural settings. But the characters are what really pulled me deeply into the novel. They just felt so real. I read this book in a single day. I just couldn’t put it down.Highly recommended for readers of Literary FictionNote: This book is not a mystery or historical fiction. Those are misleading genre labels. It has a bit of a mystery in it with some courtroom drama, but that is not its essence. The time period is 1940’s-present day. The time period is there not to emphasize historical facts. but to give credence to the story.
title: Literary Fiction at its Best

author: Lucky in KC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2019
review_content: Holy Wow...I LOVED (and still love) this novel...so much so that I'm not sure I can write a review that will do it justice.The writing was almost lyrical...it just flowed. Does that make sense?  Even though I was reading it, at times it seemed as if I were right there. No, not as a character but as an observer. And I KNOW how far-fetched this sounds but there were times I swear my breathing slowed down. Especially when the characters were in the marsh. Ms. Owens described people, places and things with astonishing reverence.I didn't want this story to end. I've talked to others who have read it and we all agree that when we finished reading it, we waited almost a week before starting on another novel. Everything about it stays with you for awhile.I'm not sure I'd want to see it were it made into a movie.  I think the nuances and finessing would be lost on film.As for those who gave this book angry one star reviews, I'm not sure what they missed.The only thing I can think of is that they forgot it was fiction.I don't want to give anything away so I'm going to keep this short.  But...if you take this book to the beach or the pool, slather on the sunscreen b/c you won't want to put the book down to get into the water or shade.
title: Do NOT read the end of the book before you start or finish it...seriously.

author: swiminakilt
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2019
review_content: I enjoyed this book because it did the one thing that reels me in.  It builds.  You grow to want to know more and more about every character.  Kya was the one character I could not picture which really interested me.  A recent review I read spoke about how this story is not realistic.  I disagree completely.  I had a friend not go to school for a year and about the same amount of effort went into finding him.  As for the character not really getting sick, when you aren't around other people it's pretty difficult to get sick!  Now to what I truly loved.  It is the knowledge of nature that makes this book amazing.  You have great characters, a great story being told back and forth from chapter to chapter.  But on one page it mentions the plover.  A plover is a bird that migrates further than any other bird.  Choosing that bird made it special for me as the story is about someone who never really leaves home.  There is so much more to this story than meets the eye and all of the nature is perfectly woven in.
title: A wonderful read

author: Clark Kent
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 15, 2020
review_content: SPOILER ALERT: I would have given it 5 stars had it not been for the ending. What I don't understand is why make her to be a murderer when you already brought us up to like her. Making her a murderer changes everything about how I think about her. Yes Chase was a low human being, the lowest of them, but it doesn't justify murder. If you are smart enough to figure out a way to do murder and get away with it then you are smart enough to find a way to convict him of an obscene crime. Would it not be more satisfying if she did this rather than murder him? Send him to jail for life. Make the trial about Chase instead of Kya. If the jury was willing to find Kya not guilty I am sure they can find Chase guilty.I'm truly appalled by the ending and honestly I was afraid the author would do this. I would have loved this book and kept it however I have already returned it to Amazon after reading that incredibly distasteful ending.
title: Distasteful ending, not a fan of Kya after reading the ending

author: dctcs
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2019
review_content: I just finished reading this book that I had put off reading for months and months.  It just did not appeal to me.  I had read the synopsis, and it still did not say "read me."  I kept thinking it was going to be like "Before We Were Yours" which I totally detested, but finished it somehow.  I guess I was looking for something to read, and I saw there were 23,000+ reviews, so I got the sample.  I buzzed through the sample.  I already had a hard copy of the book, but I have gotten so used to reading on my Paperwhite, I just went ahead and one-clicked it.  It really got so good and I found myself driving home for lunch to read a couple of chapters.  Then I put the Kindle app on my phone and I found myself reading at work.  I never do this!  Also, I got up earlier to read and of course would read until I fell asleep at night.  It was just so good.  I am trying to decide what makes this book stand out from others.  Not certain if it was the story line, the writing, the characters, setting or what.  I briefly glanced over some of the 1 star reviews.  OK.  Everyone has his own opinion, and I have mine.  I guess comparing "Where the Crawdads Sing" with "Before We were Yours" the "Crawdads" writing was so descriptive and I could just see the setting and the characters that I got to know.  I loved Jumpin and Mable.  Whereas the "Before" writing could have been that of an 8th grader.  I am now going to sit back and think about the whole story and try to figure out why I enjoyed this book so much.
title: Where the Crawdads Sing is not what I expected.  It was great.

author: Kaitlyn Morar
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2020
review_content: When I like a book, or a movie or anything for that matter, I like to search the web for people who disliked it.  I want to see if I’m missing something, see if my feelings can hold up against critics.  I have to say, that the reasons people don’t like the book aren’t wrong—- they are just missing the point.  For one, a lot of comments are about the implausibility of aspects of Kya, one in particular is her fending for herself and cooking at the ripe old age of 6.  This is, rather inaccurate from most young kids, but it’s really not the point.  This book’s plot, which made it an enjoyable read, to me, is second to themes.  Themes of nature v. Nurture, intelligence v. Instinct, what makes a family, to name a few, are dealt with in uncommon and interesting ways.  Beyond this, books serve all kinds of purposes.  They don’t all need to be historically accurate, or Nobel laureate level.  Books can be charming, delicious, snack reads—- leaving you feeling satisfied and warm.  That’s what this is, and what I’d recommend for someone who is just a bit peckish.
title: Not a perfect book, but a delightful one

author: Thebookbella
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2020
review_content: TW: abandonment, alcoholism, child abuse, attempted rape, racism, abusive racism, discussions of murder, Kya is only 7 years old in 1952, living with her family in the marsh land of North Carolina. Her mother abandoned her and her 4 other siblings. Kya's Pa is an abusive alcoholic and so Kya's siblings all leave shortly after. Kya is left for several years with her Pa who is only at their marshland shack intermittently as he goes out on drinking benders for days. In time he leaves for one of his benders and does not return. Kya is forced to figure out how to live and provide for herself.This book starts off by punching you in the heart and this is a trend throughout most of the book. It is solemn and melancholy, but the discriptions of the marsh land emphasized her shelter and safety were not with people, but the land she lived off of. She was independent and wildly herself. She is strong and resilient and kind and gentle.There are two timelines we see in this book. This book starts off in 1969 with the investigation of a murder and leading up to a possible resolution of who the murderer was. Then we have the other time line that takes place in 1952 as we watch Kya grow and leading up to everything that happened before the murder prior to 1969. We see Kya's harsh life and the men she fell in love with. We see her passion for the marsh.There were so many beautiful discriptions of the marshland that really made you feel immersed in this land. They discribed the stars and the wildlife, the grass and the bugs. I really enjoy it. And if you expect to enjoy this book, be prepared for quite a bit of that.I love Kya and her analytic mind. We often saw the marsh through her inquisitive eyes. She had a background deeply rooted in science and so scientific themes, evolution and biology would periodically surface to recapture the marsh from her point of view.This book wasn't an "at edge of my seat" kind of book. More along the lines it crept up on me. It took me 230 pages to really click with it. I enjoyed the whole thing, but for me I didn't quite know where the story was taking us and I didn't feel that aggressive need to read it until everything clicked for me.The ending of this book was worth it to me though. I am left in a perpetual state of awe and really felt the ending was well structured and really went with the themes of the rest of the book. I really loved the feeling of surprise this gave me.
title: An emotional and hard hitting story in the marshland

author: MamieD
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2018
review_content: I read this on my Kindle, and I kept checking the % to see how much I had left.  When I reached 67% I wanted to slow my reading down because I didn't want this book to end.  However, the story was so lovely and gripping that I couldn't stop.  I finished the last page with a sigh and then thought about the book the rest of the day.  From the first paragraph, I fell in love with this story.  Kya is a wonder and you will be at turns delighted with her, terrified for her, and filled with sorrow for her.  The weaving together of human nature and animal nature and the lessons learned from living in the marsh were a wonder. I cannot recommend this book enough.  It is a book I will read again since now that I know the outcome, I can go back and just read for the beauty of her descriptions.  (I tried doing that but I really really really wanted to know what would happen!)
title: This book will stay with you

author: Kathy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2020
review_content: I wish all books were this well written with a couple exceptions. In trying to be realistic about small towns, it stereotyped to excess. I grew up in the South, but was born in the North. Yes I was made fun of by kids and teachers who ridiculed my Yankee accent. Yes it took time to be accepted and finally able to feel I belonged. But I'm not convinced an entire small town would be so calloused, mean and utterly stupid.  It wasn't easy to believe all the things this girl went through as any reflection of reality. It certainly conveyed how people in small towns anywhere! can be closed off to different things and people that they avoid them making them even more isolated and lonely. But this book seemed to make a quaisi political point that southerners would turn their backs on a child in dire and dangerous straits. I didn't buy the premise, but I can't say I hated the book.  The nature aspects were engaging. The skipping from story to investigation was and always is annoying and disruptive. I hate when authors do that instead of integrating the different stories for the reader who's paid money for the book. Do they think readers like that?Regardless, the child in me wanted to believe the story and the notion of surviving in a hell hole, but alas it came through as a fairy tale, just not believable.
title: A heart rendering fairy tale.

author: Gini Rainey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2020
review_content: Imagine, if you will, a shack in the middle of the backwater marshes of the Atlantic Ocean in North Carolina.  The setting is as raw as the story that Owens tells about the abandonment and coming-of-age of young Kya. Left behind by her entire family at the age of six, Kya learns more about life and survival in a short time than most people learn in a lifetime.Ms. Owens’, no stranger to the publishing community, having several books in print, paints a world full of wonder and discovery as Kya explores the beauty of nature around her as she struggles to stay alive.  Living on the edge of a community that neither helps her nor understands her, she grows into a beautiful, highly intelligent young woman with the help of a young boy who was a friend of her brothers.Expertly building characters you will come to either love or despise, Ms. Owens laces Where the Crawdads Sing with a hint of physical abuse, romance, and murder. Owens has created a book that has everything necessary to keep the reader turning the pages to the surprise ending.
title: Wonderful Read

author: CoffeeCrazy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2020
review_content: The novel has a good plot; I love mystery and I love the NC coast, so that should be enough for a 5. However, as a North Carolinian, this book drove me nuts. There are so many words  phrases, and descriptions that do not fit life or the geography of Eastern NC. We don’t have a “sea”; maybe the author was trying to describe one of the many large sounds we have or the Intracoastal Waterway which lies between the barrier islands and the mainland. We have the largest strand of barrier islands, so Kya didn’t have a swamp, the “sea”, estuaries and the ocean at the same location; we have dolphins, not porpoises; palmettos are farther south. So many small, yet obvious references were so off that it just made the setting silly and glaringly fake. Also, the author plugged Asheville twice as a place to buy goods...what?? Why would the residents of a coastal town bypass New Bern (unless the fake town was New Bern), Greenville, Raleigh, Durham, Greensboro, etc? Another silly, thorny scratch in the novel’s setting. New Bern was NC’s original Capital City- the Capital building burned to the ground in 1792 and Raleigh was then selected as the new Capital City. Why not just use real names of real places?I did enjoy the author’s fabulous use of alliteration, and her ability to unfold the mystery so that I wanted to reread portions of the book again to see what clues I might have missed.  I enjoyed the ideas of Kya being one with nature, and I loved the relationship she had with Jumpin’ and Mabel. Overall, it was a good book.
title: Not from here, are you?

author: Pati Mooring
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2019
review_content: I had a lot of trouble getting into this book.  I read it for my book club and I'm glad that I did in the end. It was a slow start for me, but I stuck with it.Spoilers:Kya was just a young girl when everyone in her family left her. I don't quite understand it, but I have never been in an abusive family. First her mom, then her sisters, then her brothers and finally her dad. Kya raised herself. Thankfully, she had a little help when she was really young. The grocery lady, Jumpin, Tate and  Mabel. These people helped her get by when she had no money, needed supplies, gas for her boat; a Godsend for her. Her best friends were the gulls and she learned to outwit everyone that came looking for her. As Tate taught her to read and write, she began to label her specimines, feathers, shells, etc.  She dated Tate for a beat and then he went off to college and didn't return for several years. While he was gone, Kya tried building a relationship with Chase only to find out he had a whole life outside the marsh all the when continuing to tell her he wanted her to be his wife and he was going to build a home for them. Until one day, she found his wedding announcement and called off the relationship. A while later,  Chase tried to rape and assault her and she beat him up and ran to hide. He tried locating her but she always hid from him. Well in Oct, she was asked to meet her publisher in a nearby city and while she was gone, Chase ended up dead. The police tried to pin the murder on Kya but her alibi was solid. After spending 2 months in jail, she decided to again have a relationship with Tate the only person she ever loved. They got married and Kya continued making reference texts about the marsh and secretly writing poetry and submitting it to the town paper. Later after Kya died, Tate found a secret hidy hole under the stove and was amazed at what he found. Kya was a smart woman who knew how to take care of herself.
title: Even the quiet ones can surprise you

author: Mary Clark
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2019
review_content: This book poses some great questions, but also has some major flaws. In lyrical language, the child Kya's relationship with the natural world conveys a sense of wonder and appreciation of life. This is the best part of the book, showing how we are renewed and supported by our natural environment. However, this story is set against a gloomy plot. Some of the main characters are vibrant, but others are hollow and vague.Two books are being written. One is the story of a child growing up despite a minimum of parenting but with the comfort and lessons of the natural world, who suffers abuse but finds help from other outcasts and compassionate people. Dawn and gifts. The other story is a crass justification for people behaving badly. Love and death are reduced to a non-human level of understanding. People who have good character are sent into the background. Even the beautiful is dreadful. Twilight and fireflies.The book tries to have it both ways: that the child Kya matured and excelled intellectually because of a few relationships with other people and with nature, but also never really developed emotionally, morally and ethically for the same reasons. This doesn't make sense. Kya is shown examples of morality and ethics in her relationships with those few who did help her. There are lessons in compassion and non-violent resilience in the marsh life as well as the cruel ones. She has the ability to read and write. She does reflect, which is essential to making moral and ethical decisions. She relies on certain people, knows they care for her and will accept her gifts.Do the repeated hardships keep her from maturing as a human being, or does choose which examples and lessons to follow? Either way, she has a thin excuse for the actions she takes with the man who loves her and the man who threatens her. What we're left with is someone who only understands human behavior well enough to mimic it, and only understands the natural world well enough to mimic it. But that is not the dreaming, loving, artistic and forgiving person who appears in some parts of the book. So which is it?After showing growth from experience and reflection, the story reverts to an old paradigm, perhaps the fatal flaw or a last century psychology, rather than moving forward into greater understanding, that is, humanity.  That would be going far beyond, where the crawdads sing.
title: If only she had gone where the crawdads sing

author: Erica
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2018
review_content: This reads like a less plausible version of the Boxcar Children.  At least, the first 30% of the book does--I didn't finish it.  It is populated by a cast of one-dimensional characters.  The plot is preposterous and melodramatic.  Added a star because it is a first novel and the writing is better than most popular fiction.
title: Boxcar Children for Adults

author: Quarterback's Mom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2019
review_content: I think this author has a lot of gifts.  What bothers me - and it's far too often - is the distinct sense that publishers tell these authors that the novel has to be at least 350 pages or no one will take it seriously.  I felt that my time was highjacked.  I cared about the people, but the narrative went far, far afield.
title: Needed a good editor

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2019
review_content: Realistic, no.  Enchanting, yes.  I view this work as a lengthy poem, expressing the life, death, hardship and eventual fulfillment common to all species, from the world of the smallest insects to the complex world of man.  I find it hard to believe that “realism” in Kya’s life was the author’s primary goal in composing this captivating novel.  Her realism is to be found in the masterful descriptions of the sea, the marsh, the actions of the gulls and the fireflies, rather than in the people.  Kya’s life illustrates crushing hardship, soul diminishing prejudice and sheer poverty, yet gaining step-by-step the attainment of a sense of maturity and achievement.  She represents the resilience of all living things, struggling for survival in a dangerous world until the final purpose of the species has been achieved.  This, however, has been marred by the revelation at the end of the book that Aya had succumbed to what is a purely human trait.  Thus, the four stars rather than five.
title: Enchanting

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2019
review_content: Must be the most creative and interesting story I've ever read : sadness, abuse, neglect, survival, naturalism, love, hate, prejudice, ignorance, jealousy, sex, murder, mystery this has it all. A young preteen girl raised in the marsh and slowly abandoned by her family until only she and her alcoholic WW2 veteran with an injured leg and pension stayed on his family land in an old snack w/o running water, electricity or telephone. No car - just a small boat and motor to traverse the waters to nearby very small town.Finally be too leaves - read or alive she never knows, but  as a little girl who only went to school one day and his out from truant officers forever after - against all odds, she survives. She learns from nature and survives. Eventually taught to read and count past 29 by a nice young high school boy she reads generously until she's an expert. Her trials of love, abandonment,and survival are gripping and inspiring. If you are ya real man who can cry openly, don't read this extraordinary tale.
title: Extraordinary Tale

author: Aunt Maggie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2020
review_content: I am a biologist.  I live in North Carolina.  I could not relate to anything in this book.  I suppose it is well written.  There is a lot of description and I found no cringe inducing word choice errors.  The characters seem to me to be about 45 degrees off target.  I got about fifty pages into it, checked the end and  quit.  Reading it seemed suffocating.  It is hard to write valid criticisms.  It just seemed implausible.
title: What was there to like?

author: L. Gompf
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2019
review_content: It was a good story. It could have been a 4-star story if there had been some research and editing. So much of the details of the non-biological bits were so wrong. A novel should be something one can lose oneself in. I kept being jarred back to normal life by the sheer impossibility of some of the things. The bit about Asheville being the nearest big city drove me insane, and then to add insult to injury, Greenville is only 1 1/2 hours from the coast?!  Apparently in humid marshes mold doesn't destroy cardboard or anything else on paper. Storms off the NC coast rarely last more than a few hours and there were no strong winds or flooding or anything else to bother the structure of huts. If I didn't have it on my Kindle I would have thrown the book across the room more than a few times. Whatever happened to editors who, well, make sure the writers aren't making up stuff they aren't supposed to be making up? It could have been a good book, but it wasn't. Ms. Owens, next time pick a publisher that knows how to help get the facts straight.
title: Couldn't escape into the book because of so many hurt-my-brain alternative facts.

author: Granny Sue
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2020
review_content: I seldom read fiction, so when I do I want it to be believable, well-researched, and well-written. "Crawdads" failed me on two counts. First, it is basically a badly-written romance story. The young men accepting Kya's "no" to sex so easily, and waiting so long for it? Unlikely in the 50's or 60's.  The dialogue was stiff and unnatural; the repetitious descriptions of Kya's beauty, loneliness, etc, etc felt like I was being beaten over the head so I'd believe them. There are so many other elements of the story that made me just shake my head and say, nope, nope, nope. The stereotypical abusive father. dysfunctional family, I could go on and on. The book was recommended by people whose judgment I usually trust, but they let me down on this one. And that contrived ending! I could think of several other ways to get to a better conclusion of the murder mystery. The passages about nature were the best part of the book. The story had promise but in the end I just felt frustrated and aggravated.
title: Promising beginning but disappointing overall

author: K. M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2019
review_content: I mostly enjoyed it, but it's just difficult to believe that a six-year-old could manage on her own, even though she was exceptionally intelligent and had helped her mother and watched her make meals.  She didn't read, and couldn't do arithmetic until a teenager, and although it's obvious she was helped out slightly by some well-meaning townspeople, it's just to difficult to believe that such a young child could survive and thrive on her own.  It's also difficult to believe that no one in the town took pity on her and took her in. The ending wasn't entirely a surprise, but again, with her history, it felt out of character, even though I understand the motivation and rationale.  I wouldn't NOT recommend the book, I just wouldn't give it the exceedingly high praise most people are heaping on it.  For a summer read at the beach, it's a good book.
title: Well-written, but hard to believe

author: John Joyce
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2019
review_content: Way overrated. Took half of the book for it to become even SLIGHTLY interesting. Also the ending was disappointing. Overall not a good book at all
title: Boring

author: seadreamart
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2019
review_content: This was my first audible book.  At first I had a hard time getting used to "listening" to a story rather than reading a book.  It felt less intimate show how.  But I stuck with it and I'm so thankful that I did.  I will never forget Kya and her haunting, beautiful story.  The parts about her connection to the birds, plants and animals in her marsh world were my favorite, but the mystery the author builds pulled me in too.  I looked forward to my commute to and from work every day so I could be immersed in this story. I entered my drive just as the last words were being read and it took me a few moments to recover thru the tears enough to get out of my car.  I loved it so much I bought the printed copy for my daughter.  Thank you to the author and the narrator.  Beautiful!!  Bravo!!
title: Lyrical, Haunting and Beautiful

author: Julie Bishop
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2018
review_content: This book is now on my list of all time favorites.  It is sometimes heartbreakingly brutal and other times as soft and soulful as one could imagine.  If only one could find books this good on a regular basis...they only come around once in a great while.  It sang to me - it made me laugh and made me cry.  I loved every minute of the way this writer strings together words.  The main character's relationship with nature is like a true North, steering the reader toward the pain and truths in this book with that easy southern way.  While she paddles the marsh, the reader travels through it with her.  You feel it.  You hear it.  You smell it.  It is amazing how this author's descriptions truly transport you to another place and time.  You get lost - which is exactly what I expect from an amazing book.  This one will stay in my collection.
title: Beautiful hardly describes this book.

author: Georgia
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2018
review_content: Delia,  So proud of a UGA graduate and Georgia native for writing  such a lovely book.  Loved your portrayal of the Marsh girl and felt whispers of Harper Lee and To Kill a Mockingbird in it in a modern way with all of the scientific information and a different kind of justice.  Your description of isolation and how she handled seemed so real.  It rates a high score in that I had no trouble with willing suspension of disbelief.  Your knowledge of the marshes and the life they give to everything else was amazing.  I thought you handled the environmental debate in a smooth and tactful way with no preaching.  Now everytime I go to the Low Country or to Thomasville, I will think of this great book.  Do hope you will write more.
title: Beautifully written

author: MrTechieGuy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2019
review_content: SPOILER ALERT: Don’t read any further if you wish to avoid plot spoilers.I’ll give this book 3.7/5 stars. Since Amazon does not accommodate fractional star ratings, my Amazon rating rounds to 4 stars.First, congratulations to real-world scientist Delia Owens for writing a mega-bestseller as her debut novel. With over 28,000 Amazon reviews, there seems little point in me adding this one additional review, as my rating won’t perceptibly affect the average and there is little chance that anyone will read my review. Nevertheless, I will proceed.The author paints her scenes with detailed observations couched in beautiful, poetic metaphors. This is the hallmark of talented, commercially successful writers. Here is an example from the Prologue: “Swamp water is still and dark, having swallowed the light in its muddy throat.” Very nice.Like all successful novels, the opening draws you in and makes you want to discover what happens next. And I found the chapter-to-chapter time alternation, between post-crime (post-accident?) and pre-crime (years earlier) engaging and effective. But late in the book, when the two narratives converge to one, I began to tire of this world. It seemed at that point that the author was just piling on words and plot elements in a formulaic, contrived way to wrap things up and drag the story across the finish line.The part near the end where Tate, searching their shack after Kya dies, finds Chase’s necklace hidden away in a secret little cubbyhole seems particularly stupid. Why would she save the necklace of a man she hated to the point of murdering him? This would be an especially dumb thing to do because it ties her to the crime. The only apparent explanation is that the author needed a simple, clear, symbolic gimmick to signify in one fell swoop that Kya really was the guilty party after all.The final chapters would have felt more real, and more interesting, if Tate had left Kya again, or if Kya eventually relented and went to live in the city to support Tate’s career, then spends the rest of her life pining for her life in the marsh that she left behind, but then, also finds compensating joys in city life, such as having a few kids with Tate and watching them grow. Hey, life is complicated.And I was disappointed that Ms. Owens, who is a scientist herself, would not try to avail herself of some basics of FORENSIC science vis-à-vis her crime investigation scenes. From the descriptions in the book, the old, abandoned fire tower is composed of weathered, rotted wood and rusty iron grates. In the real world, fingerprints are not recoverable from such surfaces and law enforcement personnel would not be dumb enough to even try. And if they were dumb enough to try, no prints would be recovered (not even from the two boys) and the lab would set the officers straight as to why this negative result was meaningless.And by the way, with all the emphasis on the lack of fingerprints, the author never attempted to explain why Kya left none at the crime scene. If you’re going to build a fantasy world where recoverable fingerprints can be left on weathered, rotted wood and rusty iron grates, and if you’re going to make a big deal out of “no fingerprints left at the scene,” then you should pay at least some lip service to answering the question of why Kya left no prints. At least Tate could speculate, upon realizing that Kya really did commit the murder, that “I guess she was careful enough to wear gloves that night.” Maybe Tate could even find a pair of gloves in the secret cubbyhole. After all, if Kya was dumb enough to keep Chase’s necklace, then she might also be dumb enough to keep the pair of gloves she wore at the murder scene.Another apparent verisimilitude failure—where author/scientist Owens seems not to appreciate the laws of physics—is on page 254, where a sheriff’s boat whips in front of Kya’s boat, she rams her boat into the sheriff’s boat, and she is then “[t]hrown back against the outboard, her neck jerked.” In this situation, Kya’s body would be thrown FORWARD, not back.Finally, my understanding is that the fiction-reading public is predominantly female, and female fiction authors enjoy considerable, deserved success catering to this public. But as a male reading female fiction for female readers, I invariably have to suffer through lots of verbiage dedicated to food and clothing. This novel is no exception: lots of verbiage about food and clothing. At least in this case, some of that verbiage is justified because it is a matter of genuine concern for the reader as to how a ten-year-old child, alone and fending for herself at the edge of civilization, manages to feed and clothe herself. Even so, there was more verbiage about food and clothing than I wanted to read, and I’m puzzled as to why women find these topics so endlessly fascinating.
title: Good start, some good writing, some misses, peters out a little toward the end

author: JW
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2021
review_content: The characters are very well-developed and realistic. I loved getting to know them and see how they dealt with life as they matured and aged.  The situation unfolds and the reader learns over time why earlier events played out as they did and how later ones came to be. It did require suspending reality in some aspects, but that didn't distract from the story. Kya could have been me if my own life had been different. I understood the type of Chase and saw how he mimicked Pa. I also understood how Tate made the decisions he felt compelled to make. It was one of the most satisfying books I've read. I especially deeply felt how Ma, Jumpin' and Mabel navigated a challenging world when people's prejudices were even more pronounced than in modern times. I especially identified with Kya's isolation when one has little interaction with family or community. Poignant reminder of our humanity.
title: Satisfying story of an individual coming to grips with and navigating life

author: Taffodil
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2019
review_content: I enjoyed reading this at a 5 star level because I have taxing job and to be carried away by a story that I only get to read before bed that is written well overall in which I learn something and feel emotionally touched yet don't have to work to hard to access, is such a gift!  However, I give it 4 stars because I agree with other reviewers that there were some unrealistic aspects to this story but perhaps not for the same reasons.  If only we really knew how many latchkey homeless children were out there left to fend for themselves in this wealthy country with so much judgement for the unfortunates, (and I am NOT a bleeding heart liberal) we might not be so judgemental about this aspect of the story.  While some of the details might be odd, such as learning to read so quickly so well and the stark change in her ability to speak so eloquently, her life still speaks to the rising spirit of the human spirit from dire circumstances to create a meaningful life. While many have picked away at the details of the marsh and the south, knowing nothing of these things, I found such a different world very fascinating and enjoyed the word pictures of deep nature the author described.  I didn't love the ending, but I also understood the desperation and survival need that required such action. I recommend this read for the heart, not the perfect detail.
title: Touching lyrical story with a twist

author: Jackie Sweeney
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2019
review_content: It must be me as I did not like this book. From one unbelievable tale to another. A little girl in a town with other people, left to her own devices at 6 and no one takes her in? Then she has an affair with the town quarterback who promises her the moon then reneges but tries to keep the affair going even after he marries another? The swamp kid who gets a college degree but can't forget the "Marsh Girl"? I like a good fantasy as well as the next person but this was like outer space. For all the rave reviews I was really looking forward to this book and was so disappointed.

author: Pmy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 24, 2019
review_content: I need to learn my lesson and stop reading these ridiculously hyped-up books.  The ONLY good part of this was the beautifully descriptive writings about the scenery, but even that went on and on and on for entirely too long.  The story is unbelievable in many ways such as :- Boys born in the 1940s weren't named Chase and Tate- People who grow up in complete isolation, even if they are taught to read, will never speak eloquently.  This woman had almost no human interaction.  No television or radio.  Yet somehow she's speaking like a member of the debate club?  It would never happen.- The marsh is beautiful but also dangerous.  I'm not familiar with the NC coast but do know about the Southeast Louisiana marshes and I assume they have some of the same dangerous creatures and weather conditions that would make them unlivable for a small child alone.
title: Did I read the same book as everyone else?

author: Bob Golf
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2020
review_content: I found the story great in detailing the emotions of the  main character, Kya.  It spends a lot time telling the story in bits and pieces going back and forth from now to the past and back again, enough to distract in trying to follow the story line, but stay with it, because the whole story is worth it.I would like to have been the editor, but still it would have been such a  great story  told in one piece.Parts of homeless Kya growing up without much human help and relying  only from nature and the march might strain some readers, but in human survival anything is possible, remember this is fiction storytelling. Trial is too long, and I found the ending and the poem so very poignant but still a result of nature and its resolve of creatures to get to the end of life made it emotional.I re-read some of the chapters to get my mind on some missing pieces of the  story. I read the ending 2 or 3 times, sorry but I liked the ending.
title: Its worth the read

author: Dtam
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2019
review_content: Where do I begin with this book? I did not want the story to end. This novel was enjoyable from the first sentence until the very last. First, it was very beautifully written; it provided such a clear depiction of the coast that I could smell the salt. The story made my heart hurt for Kya as well as be impressed and inspired by her all-in-one. I barely even cared about the murder storyline, I just wanted to follow Kya as she searched for shells and made her way through life. For those who complained this story isn't 'realistic' enough because how could a small child raise herself in a swamp and not get tetanus from stepping on a nail, you are sorely missing the deeper points of this novel, and perhaps the points of fiction in general. (I mean, I hate to break it to you - but Harry Potter wasn't a real life wizard, either!). I honestly feel a sense of grief knowing I have finished this book, that is how much I enjoyed it. It was an easy, summer read that I would recommend to nature lovers who enjoy a good story everywhere!I will say the one negative thing is the author's attempt at the character's accents. I get it was supposed to be a deep southern accent, but it was very distracting and half the time I wasn't sure what they were actually saying, since the words were completely nonsensical. I think this could have been achieved with less of a drastic attempt at changing the language.
title: Do yourself a favor and read this!

author: John
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2018
review_content: Surprisingly, I feel this is one of the best books I've read in years, and one of the best books I've read, period. You know the book ads that come up when you open your Kindle? I always ignore them. The name of the book caught my eye, I was intrigued about the meaning. That led me to some reviews. I was afraid it was going to be a chick book, but someone compared it to the book, "To Kill A Mockingbird". High praise indeed. I took a chance. Then, I couldn't put it down. Beautifully written, and an incredible story. I'm writing this review in the hopes that it helps convince someone to read the book, like a fellow reviewer helped convince me.
title: Truly Outstanding

author: ramidog
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2020
review_content: “Where the Crawdads Sing” by Delia Owens is a coming of age story set in the coastal marshes of the. North Carolina Coast. A six year old girl is abandoned in the old family shack and must survive by applying all the knowledge her older brother taught her about the marshes and her belief that her mother would return. She studied all the animals and plants of the marsh and grew to be a beautiful but somewhat wild young lady in tune with her environment, who became involved with two different young men. This story is about abandonment and cowardice and finally learning how to accept the friendship of others. (less)
title: Wild child survives

author: mleighc
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2020
review_content: I hesitated buying this book on kindle--it cost more than paperback, and figured I'd get the paperback eventally...but with covid and quarantine, ugh...I just bought the kindle edition instead of waiting.  I wish I hadn't put it off.  I would buy it again, and would pay more.  Easily one of the best books I've ever read.  Not predictable--even though you think it might be. The author's attention to detail in the character's environment and intricate knowledge of the marsh land was refreshing and enjoyable--it wasn't BS-ed, wasn't fake, and wasn't too much.  The character depth of Kya was insightful and-depending on the life you've led-can be relatable.  If not relatable for you, definitely believable and understandable  as her she grows from a child to a woman.  I also appreciate the tie-in of the author's title choice to the story; Seriously, one of the best books I've ever read.
title: Just...Wow

author: Amy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2019
review_content: One of the hyped up books of Instagram! I am always afraid to read books that are full of such hype--they are always hit or miss with me. Where the Crawdads Sing has nearly five stars on Goodreads, which is outstanding. I loved this book, but I had a few issues with it that held back one star.Poor Kya had an extremely hard childhood...abandoned by her family, made fun of at school the one time she went, she is a true daughter of the marsh. Hence the name, "Marsh Girl". Everyone makes fun of her, fears her, thinks she is "different" than them, which scares them.With the help of a few compassionate people, and her eagerness to learn and live, Kya makes a life for herself. However, one of the town favorites, Chase Andrews, is found dead, and Kya is the immediate favorite suspect. She is different from the other town folk--she has never fit in or tried to fit in, which gives her a "mark" none of the other townspeople have. So, with no real evidence, the town (minus a few people) is determined to blame Kya for the untimely death of Chase. What happens will definitely shock you!I definitely recommend this book to anyone who is interested in reading a book about a strong female heroine who has gone against all odds to become successful, and define success for herself. She lives the life she wants to live, instead of conforming to the norms of society, and that is a truly beautiful thing. The only thing I didn't like was the ending--I think you will see what I mean. I could have used more explanation, more discussion about it.
title: A book that almost met the hype!

author: Amy Curtis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2021
review_content: I read a LOT. This book was so casually frustrating. Almost like the author knew she was doing it. The first half of the book moves ridiculously slow and the second half skips chunks of time. Fraught with editing errors, Grammer errors, and time period inconsistencies, it was a struggle to get through. Not sure how it has such high ratings. So disappointing.
title: Boring, inconsistent, and tortuous

author: Michelle M. Wright
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2018
review_content: There is much to like about this story, including interesting main character, details of the wonders of the marshlands and romance. Harsh realities including child abuse, neglect and abandonment as well as prejudice are sad threads of the main character's experience and ultimately her soul.This book offers a look into how the tenacity of human nature can enable one to survive and even thrive with a bit of kindness from strangers who become friends in the temperate, coastal marshlands.
title: Story of life in the marsh

author: S M Boren
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2018
review_content: I purchased this book from Amazon to read with Hello Sunshine Bookclub. All opinions are my own. 🌟🌟🌟🌟🌟 Where The Crawdads Sing by Delia Owens. I would have never chosen this book to read for myself but I am so glad to be part of a Bookclub that did! This was a beautifully written book that will put you right in the marsh from the moment you pick it up. Kya was a girl left alone to defy all the odds of nature as a child and did so with minimal people and help and absolutely no adult supervision. While learning the laws of nature Kya struggles with loneliness but as she grows she learns more and more that much like nature the marsh has laws of it's own. Just as nature lives by its own rules so does the marsh. And sometimes just as in nature, the Marsh deals it's own justice to those who need it most. Kya soon finds herself in front of a jury facing a murder charge. But the marsh has no dealings with the law and tangled inside will hold many secrets the rest of the world refuses to see. Especially way out yonder where the crawdads sing.
title: Where The Crawdads Sing

author: Karina Giada
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2020
review_content: I really enjoyed the first half of this book - it opened with the struggles of growing up in an abusive and negligent household and I was bracing myself for a strong narrative on the trials and trepidation of growing up on the outskirts of society. The book began with just that but it slowly diminished the main characters development to just her relationship with two men while all of her accomplishments took the backseat in the narrative. Descriptions of emotions and events began to feel more like a young adult novel - lacking any depth and taking on a very predictable pattern: the novel was no longer a literary fiction but a predictable romance. The murder trial as well didn’t feel very well developed - there was nothing captivating about the trial and nothing to make this book stand out if it aimed to be a thriller. I expected more out of it and I wish the author took it in a different direction because right now it feels like the author played with many elements but never fleshed out any of them towards the end of the book.
title: It started off strong, but...

author: B. Stephens
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2020
review_content: Hauntingly beautiful, exquisite prose, masterful in every way.For the reviews that are negative, maybe it wasn’t your cup of tea, but that doesn’t make this work of art any less beautiful.I didn’t read a single review before I purchased, I don’t even recall how I heard about the book. The title drew me in, reminding me of my childhood and the excitement to venture outdoors during and after a rainstorm with my brothers to look for crawdads.This book transports you back to a simpler time that is blighted by tragedy and misfortune - her depictions of the landscape and environment alone is praise-worthy, but then the story line also just draws you in.I literally could not put this book down. I am a fiction snob, I will not read something unless it is beautifully written and absolutely captivating, I don’t have time for anything less, and this book did not disappoint.Order the hardback, because you’ll want this one on your bookshelf.
title: Captivating

author: decano
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2019
review_content: A genuine pleasure to read, one of those rare books that truly educate us about the world right in front of us that we know nothing about.  The richness and beauty of the coastal marsh, and the deep intelligence and sensitivity of the protagonist because she has immersed itself in it, hold lessons for us all.  A striking!y original debut.The author has room to grow.  Her characters are vivid and believable, but their interactions are often clumsily described and hence unsatisfying.  The protagonist behaves at times in a curiously weak manner inconsistent with all the author has taught us about her.  Finally, the author seems a bit geographically challenged.  She has the coastal people traveling all the way to Asheville for city services, as if the much larger cities of Raleigh, Charlotte and Norfolk were not much closer.All in all, however you will be glad you read this book and will wish more novels were so beautiful.
title: A wonderful first novel, but not without some difficulties.

author: Book Worm
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2020
review_content: I have no complaints about the geography as others seem to have since I'm not familiar with the area and if the story is good, I don't care about the typographical errors either... but, we have a summer place next to a wildlife marsh (that also has a beach) and one thing I know for sure, if you tried to sleep outside, you would be eaten alive by mosquitoes and that kept coming back to me what with all the time she spent in the swamp. I found the book held my attention and it had some really neat twists and turns, but Kya (maybe she had Asperger's syndrome?) since she turned out to be a genius of sorts, was her own worst enemy - always hiding from everyone. I've read many books I've given 5 stars to, but this just didn't work for me, although the ending was excellent and the descriptions of the flora and fauna were exceptional.
title: A good Fiction read

author: Shelby
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2021
review_content: I like this book. I don’t love it, I didn’t majorly enjoy it, either. In fact, I found the first 100 pages to be an absolute bore. It took me 9 days to muscle through the first 100 pages but I finished the last 270 in less than 24hrs.So while this story is really good, if you’re considering reading it just know the beginning is rough. It’s drawn out, overly descriptive (to the point where I couldn’t focus), and overall tough to get through. Once you get past the 110 mark or so, I felt like it picked up a lot more. The author stopped using extra cartoonish dialog, etc. I grew up in South Carolina/Georgia/North Carolina so I’m familiar with the accent, but I don’t see how spelling “liquor” as “likker” or “laundry” as “laundree” does much for the reading except distract.The story itself, I found to be an emotional one. It brought love, heartache, trauma, empowerment, helplessness…. All of the emotions wrapped up into one. I probably would’ve enjoyed this book more if I didn’t have such high hopes because of all the AMAZING reviews. It’s good, it is. But don’t let the overly-glowing reviews dampen your experience.
title: Good book after the first 100 pages

author: Reader
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2019
review_content: This was a notably uneven read.  The first half of the book is, actually, well written and enjoyable.  The story when told from the point of view of the child-protagonist had charm, was poignant if unrealistic, and flowed.  However, that was about all worth reading.  Once the author was required to "advance the plot" ... the writing became forced.  The language changed from Southern dialect to "proper" English and was stiff and awkward -- particularly in dialogue.  The only thing that saved the book were the courtroom scenes -- nothing special at that, but a tolerable cliche.  The "final twist" was absolutely predictable, having been pointedly signaled from the beginning of the book.  All in all, a real disappointment.
title: NOT A FIVE STAR BOOK

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2018
review_content: It was a page-turner right from the start I think it's one of the best books I've read all year long and I've read a lot such a different story which was so nice to read and so interesting I read this book in a day and a half in fact at 12 midnight I knew I should go to bed and I did but I laid there and said I have to finish that book that is how good this book is with every penny of what it cost the story was so interesting and different and learning a little about insects and birds and everything else you would find in a marsh excellent excellent book
title: This was an excellent read I was just going through books on my Kindle app and tried a sample of this book thought it sounded interesting and bought it

author: C Christensen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2020
review_content: Really disappointing. Some of the writing was lovely, but other parts were jarringly awkward. The dialog didn’t flow and wasn’t believable. This could have, if written tightly, been a great short story, but was cumbersome and repetitive and plodding in parts. The court scene was pedantic, the ‘love’ scenes were trite. The author explained Kya to the reader ad nauseam; great writing allows the reader to discover a character. The characters and the plot weren’t awful - had the writing been tighter and more compelling. I enjoyed the premise (though many details didn’t ring true), and the characters could have been engaging. For a first novel, the editors didn’t serve the author well. I really don’t understand why this book has received the acclaim that it has. Seriously dsappointing.Two years later: I still hate this book to the point that it makes me angry. There are many things that just make no sense. Do North Carolinians actually call their towns ‘villages’???? Are fire towers really built *in marshes* *at the edge of an ocean*???  !!!  These are serious insults to the reader. Amazon reviewers who grew up in NC find the details of the area laughable. It’s as though the editors didn’t have a clue that this book would be a big success, so they simply didn’t bother to do their jobs. I hated this book, because it’s trite, and filled with complete implausibilities and inaccuracies. The biggest mystery about this book is its success — is a U.S. education actually so godawful that this sort of poorly-written drivel is rated as great literature? I don’t get it.
title: Disappointing. Insulting to the Reader.

author: Pamela
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2019
review_content: How could this young child be so forgotten?  A mother walks away without looking back. Her older siblings leave. A loving brother ends up leaving her!  Eventually, so does the drunken father.  She is raised by the marsh she lives in.  There was a lot about this book that was "hard to believe" for sure, but what a story!  As a teacher of reading, I was fascinated about Kya's ability to learn to read so well, but with determination and grit, it can be done!  I never liked Chase as a character, but that's because I knew so much more than Kya did about him.  Her naivety about love and romance and just people in general allowed her to be sucked into the relationship with Chase. Oh, and let's mention Tate--the real love of her life, right?  Another person who left her!  Kya should have hated life, but she never did.  That is what nature taught her.  Love the beauty in all things, but only trust those who prove their loyalty to you.This was a fascinating read.  I loved the ending and wasn't really surprised except by the poet's identity!  Very clever!  I highly recommend this book.  I'm looking forward to reading more from this author.
title: A fascinating book!

author: DeeDee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2019
review_content: Not one to read something because it is on best seller list I had read something about this book in a magazine and thought it might be good and interesting! I had no idea of the ride I was fixing to take! It was an emotional roller coaster in places and then a soaring ride in other places. The beauty displayed in every word was so amazing! The nature story was so visional you could see your self in the places even the smells! The human side of this story was gut wrenching at times you kept asking yourself why and how could this happen to someone and that person come out on the other side.  Taking place in a time where people were in a state of live and let live "I do not want to involved " made this story real. It is full of the social injustices that we hear about now  every single day! But this amazing story of human nature and surviving was so wonderful it made you leap for joy! The ending is totally the absolute best but you can not share with any one who has not read it because you do not want to take that feeling away! Sharing this book with someone who has read it is great because they too understand! No wonder it has been a book club book to so many. I hated for it to end! I sit alone just pondering all that I had read! So many things to think about! I read this on my kindle but I am going to buy the book because there are places I want to read again!  Five stars is not enough!! Read this book if you love amazing stories that can captive your heart!
title: Wonderful!  Best Read in a long time!

author: bscs
