date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2020
review_content: Just finished this book. I thought it would never end! I gave it 3 stars because of the descriptive setting I’ve never encountered, the colorful characters, and the original plot. Those were the pros. I found it unbelievable that a person with so little education could be outstanding in so many fields: botany, zoology, drawing, painting, and authoring something like 10 books on shells and birds, and plants, etc. after just learning to read. That’s all the education she acquired, taught by another child a bit older than she. And when the courtroom scenes came up, it was hard not to skip pages. Every word that came out of both the prosecutor, the defense attorney, and the judge was reported. Every word! After Kya was released, the story flew through the rest of her life, and then she died. The end. And those are the cons. So it’s a worthwhile read, but not great.
title: Picturesque but Long. Just Eh!

author: Carole C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2020
review_content: I've had so many people tell me I should read this book, including my mother-in-law, so one day while visiting I had some gift card money so I decided to download it (to give me something to talk to my mother-in-law about honestly).  It took me a while to read it but it was worth the wait!  I really did enjoy this book, but honestly I'm not sure if it was worth the high Kindle price (I rarely buy a Kindle book for more than $5), and I don't quite understand why it was so much more in Kindle form requiring no printing and production versus the hardcover ($5 more for Kindle!!).  Overall I enjoyed the story, although it was kind of not believable (but it is fiction so I give it room for imagination)!  I'm happy I did buy it, and when talking with my mother-in-law I will give it especially high praises! Overall, I found it very entertaining.
title: Glad I read this book but not sure if worth the high Kindle price.

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2019
review_content: Beautifully written around a North Carolina coastal marsh,  I, too, found it  unrealistic that a 6 year old girl managed to raise herself yet I kept in mind that it was set back in the 1950s-1960s -- a different era, an era in which I grew up.  And I couldn't believe ALL family members abandoned this little girl, yet once I suspended my disbelief, I was drawn in by the beautiful language and the setting of the novel.Kya was born an observer -- she talks about watching her mother fix meals and paint.  Her brother Jodie talked about the secrets of the marsh and she observed how he handled a boat.  Some people just watch and some people observe -- Kya absorbed what she observed and that was her salvation.  And her ability to observe then transfer her observations to paper is what enabled her to earn a living once in her 20s. And there were people who did help Kya -- Jumpin, Jumpin's wife Mabel, the checkout lady at the Piggly Wiggly, and Tate.  They helped as much as she would let them help.A mystery stalks the reader throughout the story, and, wow, I did not see that ending coming.Delia Owens' plot and her beautiful use of language drew me in and kept me turning the pages until the end and this morning, I'm still in the marsh.  That's the best compliment I can give a book -- that in my mind, I'm still in that book's setting and thinking about the characters.
title: Hauntingly beautiful

author: Anne H. Powell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2018
review_content: A wonderful tale about a lonely woman who knows about all of the inhabitant of the marsh.  She knows about the animals, the shrubs, the flowers, everything that lives in the marsh.  And then the tale becomes a mystery that is difficult to figure out.This is one of my all time favorite novels.
title: Wonderful!

author: Shannon Wallace
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2020
review_content: Where the Crawdads Sing is a wonderful book that grabs you from the beginning and carries you along in it's wake.  Although not super realistic in the girl's survival for all those years, it's just possible enough to allow you to fall in love with the characters and yes,  even the marsh.Living in Southeast Texas,  I am all too familiar with the difficulties of living in wet, humid, mosquito ridden, and thick unforgiving foliage. This author carries you right over that to grow to appreciate the marsh through the eyes of the heroine. She creates a character and describes a marsh with multiple layers and complexity that is intriguing and awe inspiring for humanity and nature.Well done Ms. Owens. Thank you for your gift in this book.  It is of great value in its description of human emotions, coming of age, and perseverance. I didn't want to put it down and it's staying power is effective.As a natural resource conservation advocacy it does its job well without coming across as pushy or overbearing.Can't wait for the next book!
title: A True Testament for Naure and Humanity

author: Janice Thompson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2018
review_content: The story was inviting and easy to get involved with but there were unaddressed issues.  For instance;  no plumbing until she made money writing, no means of buying clothing as she grew, how did she get clean water?  I assumed that the couple who owned the store helped her a lot, but that was alluded to, not directly addressed.  Overall I enjoyed the book and will read others by this author.
title: Captivating

author: J. L. DeCastro
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2019
review_content: FICTION, LITERARY, SOUTHERN LIT.KYA was dealt a raw hand. Born and living in a shack on the sea-side marshes of North Carolina. Her mom walks out on the family, followed by the rest of her siblings. Eventually her abusive/drunk father leaves Kya too, to fend for herself. The locals call her MARSH GIRL and rumors abound of her strange existence. Yet no one helps the young throwaway except for Jumpin' and his wife Mabel. Themselves outcasts as local "colored." "White trash" and "coloreds" are equally segregated in these times. Kya mistrusts everyone and learns "about life" by studying nature and the marsh. The only other constant in her life is a local boy, Tate, who grows up appreciating the marsh and is sensitive to Kya's elusiveness. Kya's take away is that eventually everyone abandons her and she will never feel love much less companionship. But there is a thread of hope in what she manages to accomplish. WHERE the CRAWDADS SING is a bitter-sweet story - a MUST READ!!!!!
title: Bitter Sweet Story

author: Amy C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2020
review_content: Delia Owen's over-wrote the crap out of this book. So, so, so many unnecessary details, I found myself skipping several sentences just to get to the meat and potatoes of the story. "The shack stood silent against the early stir of blackbird wings, as an earnest winter fog formed along the ground, bunching up against the walls like a large wisps of cotton"... a whole needless paragraph before she gets to what the main character is actually doing. Is it well written? Sure. But it also gave me a headache sifting through much of that style of writing just to get on with the story!Honestly, if I didn't know any better, I would've thought this was Delia Owens' first book. It was, tolerable, at best- but not recommended.
title: Meh.

author: TAKelley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2019
review_content: When I see this book in Amazons top 100 I was not sure about reading it. But when I seen over 10,000 reviews and most positive I figured it was worth a read. I was not disappointed in short this was and outstanding read.The story is set in the marshlands of North Carolina and is focused on the main character Kya. At the start of the story it is almost shocking with the fact of the mother walking away and in time so does the rest of the family one by one including the father who is a real piece of work. But Kya from an early age finds away to survive and deal with the isolation and the way that the towns people look down on anyone that lives in the marshlands. As Kya grows she ends up with in interesting places but will they stick around. The ultimate test is when the once upon a time star quarterback of the local high school is found dead and Kya becomes a suspect. I really like a lot of the descriptions of how she became at one with nature, really out of necessity . I will tell there is a part towards the end of the book concerning Kya that really made me mad. Definitely give this book a read it is as smooth as a long summer day. I could see were this might be made into a movie at some point.
title: Oh Little Marsh Girl

author: G
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2021
review_content: First, the author has a wonderful descriptive style that draws the reader into her world.But, some of the details of the story knocked me out of that world, for example the young girl growing up isolated in the 1970s; the people of coastal NC driving all the way to Asheville to go to a nice restaurant or to the Sears store (in reality, you would pass about 200 Sears in towns large and small -- Charlotte, Raleigh, Fayetteville, etc. -- to get to Asheville) hint: check geography with a map; stereotyped characters from the town's people to the football hero to the alcoholic father...The plot was a little all over the map (like the geography of the book) and wasn't really a mystery because mystery readers would know where the plot was going very early in the book. The romance part was intriguing.My biggest disconnect was the phonetics in dialogue for the Black characters. This book came from a NYC publisher, not a Southern one. Maybe the editor made the author do it?I wouldn't recommend the book to someone who lives in the region where this is set.
title: Writing style is beautiful, but plot and characterizations left me scratching my head

author: book lover
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2019
review_content: WHERE THE CRAWDADS SING  by Delia OwensWOW! Just WOW! This is a great book.  Murder, abandoned child, growing up alone, nature, young love, sex, ecology, love, poetry, betrayal, education, redemption, forgiveness, treachery -- it is all here. Well written with strong characters and even stronger biology, Owens debut novel is clearly a winner.The North Carolina coastal region and the animals, birds, flowers, grasses, etc. are as much a character as the human in this book. Kya, Chase, Jumpin’, Mabel and Tate are the main humans in this beautiful elegy to nature and the human spirit.Saying too much more will spoil the “mystery” in the book, so just know that is a book that should not be missed.  Book groups will find much to discuss and ponder. Biologists and sportsmen/women will appreciate the accuracy of the science.5 of 5 stars
title: WOW. Don't miss this one!

author: susan k.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2019
review_content: This book is very evocative-- with lots of beautiful description, it really brings the North Carolina marshlands to life. The protagonist in the novel, Kya, only attends school for one day and she is a member of a large, neglectful, and totally dysfunctional family.  Having just read the memoir "Educated", the true story of Tara Westover, I was struck by the similarities. Tara was "homeschooled", but the "education" she received was one-sided and biased and full of stunning holes.  For instance, she had never heard of the Holocaust and was not aware of the civil rights movement. In contrast, Kya's family simply abandoned her, having taught her nothing but how to dig for mussels and oysters and how to fish. She isn't educated until her first love interest teaches her to read."Where the Crawdads Sing" is a mystery--it begins with the death of a man who we later learn was murdered--but the more important part of the book is watching Kya grow and learn. It's a great read, and hard to put down.
title: This book is hard to put down!

author: Crazybookishlove
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2019
review_content: I had been hearing so many good things about this book, that I was sure it was going to disappoint me. For one, the story seemed like something I could never get excited about, being set in the U.S of fifties and sixties, and for another, everyone kept harping on about how emotional it is. Fortunately, Where The Crawdads Sing by Delia Owens lived up to all the hype surrounding it.I cannot call this story of Kya Clark, popularly known as the Marsh Girl, a roller coaster of emotions because there were only high emotions all through the book. Catherine "Kya" Clark is barely 7 when she sees her mother walk away from home, never to return. The youngest of 5 siblings, she is left alone when all her much older siblings also leave their abusive father. What follows is a tale of heartache, hardship, the resilience of human spirit in face of adversity, and the need for love and belonging in a person's life.Kya's family lives in a marsh, on the outskirts of Barkley Cove, a very small town on the coast. They are known as the town trash, just one step up from the "coloreds" in North Carolina of the 1950s. When her family disappears, hardly anyone in the town is bothered. It is with the help of a black couple and an old friend of her brother, that Kya manages to survive on her own, all alone, surrounded by hundred of acres of marsh land.While we learn of Kya's past, there is an alternate story about the suspected murder of Barkley Cove's golden boy, Chase Andrews. His influential parents, and many others in the town, believe that the Marsh Girl is responsible for the murder. Now Kya has to face a murder trial in a town already prejudiced against her, with the possibility of being given the death penalty.As I read the book, I was struck by the fact that real and true love doesn't mean making things easy for the other person. Real love is when you work towards making that person independent and able to stand on their own feet. Reading about a little girl left all alone to fend for herself was not easy. To imagine her going through life without anyone to cuddle her or take care of her, just broke my heart. At the same time, her will to survive, and her determination to win despite all the odds against her, made me cheer her on.The book is also full of lessons on the wildlife found on the North Carolina coastal areas. All types of birds and insects make an appearance and it was hard not to stop reading and look up the creature being talked about. There are zoology lessons along with some stirring poetry that makes this book a unique experience for the reader. Many reviews talk about the murder mystery in the book. However, I was so invested in Kya and what was happening to her that I couldn't care less about the mystery of who killed Chase, or whether it was a murder or an accident after all.A sweet, poignant book about a girl's journey through life, this book is recommended for those who like drama, emotions, romance and love, as well as those who like reading about wild life.
title: 4.25 Stars

author: Bonnie J Weinman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2021
review_content: I had a lot of trouble getting into this book.  The story of a “marsh girl” abandoned at the age of 6, who raises herself, never gets sick (even steps on a rusty nail and doesn’t get tetanus), is hard to believe. Her shack never needs repairs, she is taught by a boy to read and, on her own, learns college level subjects, and is beautiful, sensitive, and artistic.  All that was very hard to swallow.  That being said, the descriptions of the land and the marsh were beautiful, and I could envision how they all looked from the detailed narrative.  The murder mystery added a lot to the story; I had to keep reading to find out whodunnit.  Delia shifted seamlessly from the past to the present melding this murder mystery, love story and coming of age story into one.
title: Lyrical prose, beautiful setting, but hard to believe

author: Tabitha
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2019
review_content: Where do I begin? The book tries way to hard to be overly descriptive to the point where I had to read certain passages multiple times to understand what it was trying to describe. Sometimes, it's good to let the reader imagine the environment by giving them a good description but without overdoing it so that they're left confused about the picture you're trying to paint. The first half of the book was slow and the story happened in small bits between large sections of fluff.After a very drawn out build-up, it comes to an unsatisfying conclusion which was predictable but also frustrating because it writes off murder nonchalantly and leaves the reader wondering why it's okay that the main character was allowed to get away with. The conclusion is plain abrupt and lacks conhesiveness.The plotline is at most mediocre and disguised beneath flowery language. I'm not sure why the book has become so popular but there's much better out there to spend your time on.
title: SPOILERS! Slow and mediocre

author: Lila Faye
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2018
review_content: I read a few of the other reviews before writing this.  I have to say, some people put way too much work into it.  "It doesn't make sense" , "It's not possible".  It's fiction!  Dust off that imagination and lighten up.  I don't read books to be so critical of them.  I read for entertainment and pleasure.  So the author stretches a little.  I thoroughly enjoyed this book.  I cared about the characters and I loved the ending.  The trial was not dry and too detailed like other books I have read.  All in all, a really good book!
title: I really liked it!

author: Lynne
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2019
review_content: So good, So good, So good!!!This story was so well written! What amazing character development! This book was EVERYTHING!!!Kya grows up in North Carolina, her entire family ends up leaving her to raise herself in the marsh. Isolated from the outside world besides a few acquaintances, Kya is labeled the "marsh girl." Townspeople judging her, bullying her, and staying as far away as possible from her.Chase Anderson, the former star high school quarterback, is murdered, pushed from the top of a water tower. No fingerprints, no footprints, no physical evidence. A shell necklace made for him by Kya years before when they were involved is taken from Chase's neck following his death. This seems to be enough evidence for the sheriff to bring in Kya for questioning.Where the Crawdads Sing would make an amazing film. This was such a page turner, keeping me on the edge of my seat the entire time. Is Kya guilty of murder or is she not? Exciting until the last page!!! Loved everything about this story!!!
title: A Phenomenal Story

author: Megan Reynolds
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2020
review_content: This was a really great book, and as a Southerner who mainly grew up on the coast, I could relate to a lot of the descriptions of the setting. It’s definitely not a feel-good/light read, but it has a positive ending and it will make you laugh at some points. There are parts of it that are a little graphic, but not so much that it made me not want to continue reading. The writer does a great job with character development, and I’ll hopefully read another one of theirs at some point soon.
title: Great read that made me want to keep reading more

author: alison
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2019
review_content: Other reviewers give enough information about this book for you to decide whether or not to read it. Here is my experience: pure delight from the first sentence to the last, with many sentences and paragraphs worthy of re-reading. I didn't want it to end. But when I finished the book, I sat there for about ten minutes, then turned to the first page to re-read just a bit--and several hours later, finished the second time through. The first time there is that element of "what happened, whodunit?" and the second time there's the pleasure of seeing how the author develops the characters and of re-reading about that splendid part of the world. I bought it for my sister and my best friend, and they both wrote to thank me for it after they finished it--best book they'd read in a long time too.
title: best book in a long time

author: meme
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2019
review_content: A story about a child who was abandoned by every member of her family, ostracized by her community, failed by the community social services and school system. Raised by herself and the wild creatures of the marsh she was only able to attend school for one day. With the aid of a friend who she met in the marsh she learned to read, paint and be a scientist of the marsh. She was betrayed by her first love when he went away to college. The second relationship was about conquest by the male. He was a male predator who threaten her more than her drunk  father ever had. He was murdered and she was charged with his murder even though she was out of town at a business meeting. She was ruled not guilty by a jury. She returned to her home in the marsh and lived with her first love until she died at work in the marsh. After her funeral her mate found evidence that she had indeed killed the male predator who caused her so much anguish. He destroyed all of her evidence. She was the author of many books and scientific data. She left her slice of the marsh in a trust so it would remain a marsh. A life that was self taught and well lived. A man who loved her.
title: A spellbinding story

author: TribalTech
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2019
review_content: The fact that it had 25000 reviews should have prompted me to do some research on how this book got so popular. Not until I'd read 80% of it did I realize/ find out that Reese W. had recommended this book. Ugh! Anyway so my issue with this book is that it is so so shamelessly unrealistic that it makes my skull hurt. So much nonsense about how this marsh girl survives on her own and becomes literate pretty much on her own, becomes the best painter and wetlands researcher on her own while living in a shack with no formal education whatsoever and goes onto become a prolific scientific author...the list of unrealistic nonsense goes on and on. The only reason i give it 3 stars is that the story line is decent and the ending is riveting. But when I think about how unrealistic everything was to get to that point it leaves a bad taste in my mouth. There are way better books. Waste your time with this at your own peril.
title: Ugh! Reese Please!!

author: SLCgirl
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2019
review_content: The book is beautifully written as Owens has a talent to turn a captivating phrase that can at once provoke a reflective pause, a smile and, yes ... a tear.  Don’t miss Owens’ fascinating bio on her web site:  “Her mother encouraged Delia to explore far into the oak forests where they lived in Georgia, saying “Go way out yonder where the crawdads sing.” Her mother taught her how to hike without stepping on rattle snakes, and most important not to be afraid of critters of any kind. Delia went on to spend most of her life in or near true wilderness, and since childhood has thought of Nature as a true companion. One of her best friends.”  Can’t wait to read future novels by this most interesting writer!
title: Gripping Story Line Against a Lush, Natural Setting

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2018
review_content: This is a sad soul searching  of a family living on the edge of humanity. Rejection because of where you lived..no heart only physical and mental abuse. Never having enough to eat, clothing yourself with whatever someone gave you. No shoes barefoot and no hope of anyone concerned about the welfare of a young seven year old girl child abandoned by her family and society. Prejudice and mean spirited humans who never had a kind word or a simple hug a pat on your back, no acknowledgement other making fun of you turning their backs to you, as if you never existed.So many families are facing abuse every twenty-four seven  no let up never knowing if you have food or whose going to knock on your door to serve eviction notice. The author speaks of croaker sacks, I remember my mother talking about how her sisters boiled those sacks to make them softer, then they bleached them. My Mom said that's what they made their dresses from. What Kya went through, I've witnessed and it's heartbreaking. There were tears reading about how sad and lonely her life had become. Finding solace and comfort with nature and her children. It's almost as if she became one with her surroundings. Everybody abandoned her, no hope but she had herself and Jumpin, Mabel and Tate. Her brother Jodie who found her and told her about their mother who was mentally beaten down by life that her husband who may seemed to blame the war for his alcoholism and his mean demeaning ways toward his family. Her father didn't want or let his children go to school said it was useless and wasteful. Maybe the father didn't want his children to  do better than him so ran them away with his abusive ways.I recommend everyone read about the lives of people who live on the margins of society, totally ignored, the church or government programs totally passing over them. Poverty is way of life nothing more or less...This is a heartbreaking realism of life put forth on paper.
title: ALONE AND FORGOTTEN

author: Loni Gee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2019
review_content: Most of the book was quite unbelievable in the first place, but it is after all, fiction.  So, I guess unbelievable is par for the course.  However, Owens wasn't writing a wild fantasy, so I think it was meant to BE believable.  Kya is not believable.  Her survival skills and reading ability and book selling were too farfetched for me.But, the ending was too disappointing.  It's a book about revenge, and I was sorrowful about that.
title: Spoiler Alert

author: Sandy Lo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2020
review_content: Kya Clark was abandoned by her mother at just six years old, followed by her older siblings, and eventually her father. She had to fend for herself while living in the marsh and managed to evade truancy officers and town bullies.At least she does until Chase Andrews shows romantic interest in her. Kya, now a teenager, yearns for affection and companionship, but believes everyone will leave her like her family did.Cut to several years later when Chase’s body is found dead. Kya becomes the prime suspect.The author does a great job of showing the world through the eyes of Kya — someone who understands nature more than anyone else. It’s no surprise I cried several times during this book and also felt nervous for Kya and who may take advantage of her. But I love that Kya was never truly a victim. She was strong, brave, and smart.If you keep putting this one off for whatever reason, I highly recommend you move it up on your TBR!
title: Beautiful, Heartbreaking, and Touching Read!

author: JB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2019
review_content: Really enjoyed this Unique Compelling novel centered around the character of Kya, known as the “Marsh Girl” who grew up from a young age by herself in a Shack in the marsh in Barkley Cove, a quiet town on the coast of North Carolina.  The story begins in 1952 through 1970, although the ending summarizes Kya’s later years & completes Kya’s story.It’s interesting to read about life in the Marsh with the many detailed descriptions of the marsh’s inhabitants (birds, insects, shells, lagoons, etc) woven throughout the novel.  It’s also interesting to read about the people of Barkley Cove back in the 50’s, 60’s & 70’s, what times were like back then & those that helped Kya, her challenges & struggles & her achievements.The very end of the book in “The Firefly” chapter had a surprise ending, which I didn’t like, although it’s understandable from the perspective of the other elements in the book.I applaud Delia Owens first novel,
title: Unique Compelling Story of Kya & the NC Marsh!

author: Betty C
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2020
review_content: I had been meaning to read this book for a long, long time. I read the description of it and acknowledged its appeal, but was afraid it wouldn't live up to the hype and feared disappointment. My fears were groundless. Owen's tale was mystical and elegiac, gently and , sometimes, vigorously winding through the marsh it memorializes to its denouement. The lyrical descriptions of the natural world and the poetical foreshadowing of events are exceptional. Yet nature's depiction is not sugar coated but set in biological realism.  Kya is a strong and beautiful character, cloaked in melancholy reminiscent of Mick in Carson McCuller's in THE HEART IS A LONELY HUNTER. Loneliness and longing permeate this story. I fell in love with both Kya and Tate and with their love story. I'm sure I will revisit Kya's tale of survival many times.
title: It's even better than I imagined.

author: Joel Morris
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2020
review_content: I realize I'm going against the crowd here - but this is not a good book. Now perhaps as a 69-year old male I'm not the intended audience. But I found the plot implausible, the descriptions of the settings of the story pale, and the ending upsetting. I recommend you not spend your money on this one.
title: Poorly written book

author: C. Hope Clark
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2019
review_content: It has been several years since a book touched me so much. I'm a nature lover, an agriculture graduate, someone who thinks that the worst part of dying is leaving and not being able to smell rain or touch the bark of a tree. . . leaving nature behind. But this book is rich on so many other levels, too. First, the writing is superb, lyrical, touching.  I would have paid good money to see a heart-felt conversation between Delia Owens and Pat Conroy, because they both could take the world and paint it beautifully, similarly. Secondly, Ms. Owens makes us see ourselves on a deeper level. We have felt all of these Kya emotions, who is such a simple, beautiful soul, yet have been too afraid to NOT be a part of a much nastier society for fear of what others would think. We fear reprisal for being unique. In the end the reader almost wishes they had the courage to have lived their life as a Kya, but in reality, at least had the chance to pretend so through the eyes of the Marsh Girl. This is a story that will stay with me a long, long time. Few stories I've read have drawn a tear like this one.
title: A Book to Sink Into - Sensory Beauty

author: SC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2020
review_content: This is the best book I’ve read in a long time. I was completely absorbed in every word. To be honest, I’m shocked that some people seem to have really hated the book. I can’t imagine how. The only guess I have is that they can’t imagine a girl against so many incredible odds in her upbringing being capable of succeeding. As a girl, myself, who has overcome incredible odds to succeed...I see it! I see how it is so possible for this girl to become what she became. She had few friends, but the right ones. She triumphed in the end and I celebrated the final chapter of this story! In fact I exclaimed out loud and scared my husband when I got to the final scene. Fantastic book. If you can imagine a person being capable of beating the odds, read this book. If you think someone’s upbringing defines their future - don’t read it. Simple as that!
title: Beautiful, hopeful, tragic and amazing all at once

author: Erika
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2019
review_content: This book was extremely well written and told a story about people who are very rarely represented in books. Kaia has grown up on a marsh her whole life, but at age six she is abandoned and essentially left to raise herself. She learns to rely on nature and a few good hearted people to survive and make her way.When a popular young man, Chase Andrews, takes interest in Kaia and is later found dead, Kaia becomes a suspect in his untimely and suspicious death. This story follows Kaia before the murder of Chase Andrews and after. It is a stunning portrayal of a young women who is forced to pave her own way; and somehow she manages to do so.Delia Owens is an incredible writer and I loved the poetic writing style of this novel. I could very clearly picture the characters and the story in my mind and felt as if I knew them and envisioned them just how Ms. Owens wanted them to be. The book represents the time period wonderfully, even in the most subtle ways. I would highly recommend this book and I thoroughly enjoyed it. I predict it will become an American classic.
title: Highly entertaining story

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2020
review_content: I was told of this book by many people who highly recommended it.  I  can see why now.  I read the book in 2 days. It started out slowly & I think the only thing that I didn't like about the book was the amount of enlarged descriptive material throughout the story. However, as the tale went on, there was less of the descriptive sentences & I was drawn in completely by the heroine, Kya. I wondered how she could survive as she did, felt what she was feeling & cried with her when she was crying. It is a very emotional story, some intense & some not so much. I would say anyone who enjoys emotional, fiction that is totally different, man or women, would be remembering "Where the Crawdads Sing" for a long time after finishing the book!
title: Wonderful, emotional book.....

author: Steffanie21
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2020
review_content: The book is simple, yet so deep & intuitive.  She brings the character out so that you can relate to her state of mind and circumstance.  The characters are so rich and layered, and the picture she paints with words is just breathtaking.  The story is wonderful on it's own merit (it has loss, love, pain, hope, drama, intrigue) but the way the writer uses words to paint the picture so vividly and express the feelings so clearly is just mesmerizing!  This is one of my favorite books of all time!  Delia Owens, please write more!!! :-)
title: Incredibly deep & simple!

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2020
review_content: Kya is a swamp girl. Her family has lived in a ramshackle shack in the swamps for years. Her father is disabled from the military and he drinks heavily. Her mom leaves after being beaten . Some of her older sisters have left and the remainder left after her mom left. Kya is left with her dad.. The school system send a lady to get her . Kya goes one day and she was harassed so bad she never goes back. She is 6 years old . She has to learn to cook and clean and take care of her dad. Hes good to her sometimes and teaches her how to motor the boat through the swamps. How to fish and how to dig for mussels. A Few times he stays gone for days, weeks, and even a month. He finally leaves for good. Shes alone and has to survive on her wits. She goes to the docks and meets Jumping and Mable a Black Couple and they help her by buying mussels from her. They sell them to the Black people in Black town they know.This is how they make a living. They have no children and they want to help this little white girl.  Years pass and she meets Tate. He teaches her how to read. He brings her books, and shes very intelligent and teaches herself. Going to town is hard but she manages to buy her food and go to the library for more books. Tate and Kya fall in love but Tate knows Kya is too young for him to cross the line of fornication.  He leaves to go to college. He cant say goodbye and Kya is heartbroken. Years go by and then Kya meets Chase. He comes to the Marsh looking for the Marsh girl. Meets Kya and for a few years the become an item. His parents find out and they arnt happy. He never takes Kya to town and he tries to keep her a secret. By that time Kya is a
title: Great Read

author: keb536045
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2020
review_content: SUCH a wonderful book! I will admit the beginning seems a little dry because it’s hard to tell why they focus so much on the dialect and slang in talking but ... keep turning pages! It’s worth it. I realized in reading this book I formed a connection with the main character because I started to care about her strength and relationships. The ending was better than I expected. I was wondering why so many people recommended I read it.. and now I understand. Such a good read. My boyfriend bought it for me to download on my Kindle and it was worth every penny!
title: You need to read it!

author: carolynfromoz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2018
review_content: Where the Crawdads Sing is a very special and unique book and definitely one of my favourites of 2018.When town sporting hero, Chase Andrews is found dead at the bottom of an old fire tower in the North Carolina marsh, rumours spread quickly that the "Marsh Girl" is responsible. Kya Clark is the "Marsh Girl", abandoned first by her mother, then her siblings and finally, when she was 10, by her abusive, drunken father who went to town and never returned, leaving her alone in an old shack in the marsh. Somehow Kya survived, collecting mussels to sell at the marina gas station to the old guy who ran the station, Jumpin', in exchange for gas and food. Jumpin' and his wife Mabel were the only ones who showed any care or concern for Kya, giving her old clothes as she grows as well as extra food. Scorned and ridiculed on the only day she went to school, Kya avoided the town but made friends with Tate, a boy who liked to fish in the marsh and shared her passion for the wildlife around them. Tate eventually teaches Kya to read and write but it is the marsh that becomes her classroom as she studies and learns all about the plant and animal species that live there.The murder mystery is almost in the background here as the marsh dominates the narrative and atmosphere of this story. The writing is so evocative that the peace and beauty of the marsh and it's lagoons and waterways shine through. The author is herself a wildlife biologist and this is very evident in her beautiful descriptions of the insects and birds. This is one of those books that I will keep thinking of and won't easily forget.
title: Unique and beautiful

author: Lee J
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2019
review_content: This is a spectacular book. It is one of the few that I couldn’t put down until I had turned the last digital page. It was beautifully written and totally engrossing. I loved that it was a mystery as well as being chock full of animal and bird lore and description of coastal life. The characters were vivid and memorable. There was only one annoying thing for me. In this lovely, sad story, filled with descriptive language, of a child left to care for herself, the author disappointed me, an English teacher and lexophile, by using the  word gift as a verb, not once but several times. The last time I looked, gift was a noun. The word give as a verb has served us well for a long, long time, and like so many other words that some writers and speakers of the English language have used incorrectly, “gifting” has insidiously crept into vocabularies and replaced “giving.” Just one more thing along with apostrophes incorrectly used in plurals that spoils my love of reading. “Gifting” may have a place on Facebook and may not bother those who have no love of language, but I took away a star for it. Authors are my heroes, and this author’s white hat slipped a little in this beautiful story of courage, determination and everyday scientific beauty.
title: A beautifully told story

author: SueBell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2019
review_content: This book makes you want to take a trip to the marshes of Carolina to breath the air, hear the wind and the insects. The book becomes a live as you read the descriptions are so clear that you can take a vacation in your mind and experience what Kya experienced. Her art and knowledge shown through her books that taught people about the marsh. The town did Kya wrong they should have come to her aide when they knew her circumstances but they failed her. It reminds me of the description in the book about the female prey-mantis calling a mate while they are mating the female eats the male. In the end this rang true for Kya and she did as what nature wanted her to do.I found myself on a roller coaster ride that had me so sad at times that tears rolled down my cheeks and other times I was preying for Kya to survive. Abandonment is a serious issue it does so much harm to children and it broke my heart what happened to her. Kya also is someone who is a survivor she is full of strength. Her ability to overcome her circumstance at ever turn is remarkable her resilience level is through the roof.Mrs. Owens thank you for reminding me that kindness can go a long way. That our humanity can be so disgusting to turn our back on someone who may need to hear a hello or a few dollars to buy some food. Their are many Kya's in the world and we as a people as part of nature need to remember that we all need each other in some form or fashion. Each of us has are own brilliance within us and sometimes we need a little helping hand to shine brightly like a firefly. I want so badly now to go to hear the crawdads sing I am sure it is the most peaceful music I will ever hear.
title: A great book to read!!!

author: Diana
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2020
review_content: I am a voracious reader and was compelled to purchase this book to read and listen to in audiobook simply based on the number of people who felt compelled to review. I read it starting after dinner and into the night, if I didn’t have to work I would have finished it instead of squeezing in three hours of sleep. In the morning I switched to audio for my half hour ride to work and finished shortly after between patients at my desk. To summarize, this book sucks you in and pulls you deep, and like getting tossed by the surf, you struggle to the top for air here and there until the end. It is compelling, arresting, infuriating, scientifically satisfying and one of my favorite reads of all time! Thanks so much to the brilliance and soulful insight of this gifted author!
title: Profoundly affecting

author: Joan Colby
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2019
review_content: This is very much a mixed review. The narrative is fine, in fact in many descriptions of nature, it is excellent as one might expect of an accomplished naturalist as Ms. Owens is. The dialogue however relies almost entirely on dialect. A little of this goes a long way, and Owens could have trusted the reader’s comprehension of regional accent rather than creating an Lil Abner type of verbal exchange. This was so annoying that I almost stopped reading, something I almost never do. I’m glad I gave the book a chance, however, as the story is fairly interesting in an anachronistic Girl of the Limberlost way. The enormous praise of many readers and the book’s position on popular lists mystifies me, to be honest. I don’t find it more than a mediocre read. However, the storyline is strangely compelling as one proceeds and the ending, while predictable, is relatively satisfying.
title: Dialect is Distracting

author: Mimi
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2018
review_content: I can't add a lot to what other reviewers have said.  Bittersweet story:  abandonment, young girl living alone, the marshes, swamps, tides, currents, birds, shells, grasses, love story, coming of age, murder, naturalist collector, scientist, writer, illustrator and more.  The only thing I did not like was the back and forth, back and forth in time.  I just doesn't not make sense to me to jumble up the whole story.  I put the chapters in chronological order and read the book that way.  A beautiful but haunting story.P.S. 3/2020  I just finished re-reading this book.  And, I did re-read it in CHRONOLOGICAL order.It is a love story, a murder mystery, lots of nature, birds, the marsh, the tides, prejudice, relationships.  Beautifully written.  I'm not big on "favorites," as in my favorite book, my favorite color, etc., but this may be my favorite book.  I enjoyed every page.  Since I knew "who done it," I was able to savor all of it, look up the birds she mentions, the feathers, the grasses and more because I read on a Tablet.  Wonderful Book!  Please give us more like this.Chapters in Chronological Order: 0, 1, 2, 4, 6, 7, 9, 11,12, 13, 15, 16, 17, 18, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 26, 27, 29, 30, 31, 33, 35, 39, 41, 43, 46, 48, 3, 5, 8, 10, 14, 19, 25, 28, 32, 34, 36, 37, 38, 40, 42, 44, 45, 47, 49, 50, 51, 52, 53, 54, 55, 56, 57
title: Captivating Story

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2020
review_content: I bought a Kindle book on Amazon.com. I did not want an Audible book. I don't need someone to read the book to me. But Amazon included it in my purchase. No problem, right - I can return it, just like I can with a Kindle book. No, I cannot! There's no return button - the order is split in two - the Kindle book and the Audible book, and there's no way to return the Audible book.I thought, "Ok, I can go to Audible.com where is says it came from." The Audible.com won't let me do anything - it redirects me to the Canadian Audible site. Yes, I'm in Canada, but I know where they say I bought the book. So now I have an Audible book I don't want, and there's no way to get help, there's no way to talk to anyone, and there's no way to get my money back.It's not like I was going to buy any Audible books anyway, but I'd advise anyone else not to buy from them either!
title: Audible books scammed me on Amazon.com

author: Chip Smitley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2019
review_content: This book is like comfort food. Big, it’s not, no War and Peace. But as a comfort story, like a Hallmark movie, it’s great. It’s always enjoyable to read wordsmithing that uses words and phrases in new ways, creating new impressions, provoking thoughtfulness about what language can convey. The writing is excellent, skillful, in a distinct voice. Back to the story, and without spoiler alert needed, somebody feels alone, somebody seeks love, somebody suffers love’s complications, somebody gets help, somebody gets harmed, somebody must interact with authority figures, somebody lives, somebody - you get the idea. Nice that some things don’t go as you foresee, although many do. This is all set in “the marsh,” costal marsh, conjuring images of bayous, moss on trees, cool, filtered sun, marsh birds, beaches, romantic near-lost environmental poignancies. To this man, a woman’s book. Back to harder-edged detailed histories of wars, ages of change, prominent figures, science, politics. But happy to have read new phrasings, and been comforted with the well told smaller stories of a different life, well lived, for the most part.
title: Comfort food, like a toasted cheese sandwich and tomato soup

author: 7Slots
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2020
review_content: A wonderfully captivating story. I simply could not put the book down and for that it gets 5 stars. I must admit I was surprised at the number of POV errors, and one chapter written in present tense that really threw me off. The chapter was beautifully written but seemed thrown in as if it came from another book.  While I was enthralled by her unique ways of describing things and her creative writing, I did skim through a lot of overly detailed sections.
title: Captivating

author: VCCats
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2019
review_content: The writer wrote in such a poetic way; it took me back to the books my parents used to read to me when I was younger.  While I was reading Where the Crawdads Sing, it was so easy to be there with Kya, it's an experience that's hard to explain, but readers get what I mean. Delia Owens painted a clear and artistic story filled with emotion, heartache, and all the things that come along with life. I was walking with Kya while she searched for rare seashells, I was there when she drove over to Jumpin, and I was there when she met Tate.Until this book, I had been going through a reading slump. Hadn't picked up a new book on months, and the last one I had read left me discouraged. I didn't even finish it, that's how disinterested I became. I'm not in the market anymore for a new series, and I haven't read a book with magic in it in ages. I knew that I needed something new, but I didn't know what.Now all I want to do is reread this one!My Mom had already reread it twice by the time I picked it up. She kept telling me to read it, and I kept putting it off. Crazy huh?Anyway, if you are looking for a different coming of age story I recommend Where the Crawdads Sing by Delia Owens, I am so happy that this is a New York Times Best Seller, and that it's sold over a million copies. Delia deserves it for writing such a fantastic story. And it's her first book, too!
title: A different, engaging story.

author: Betsy C. Roberson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2021
review_content: I could not put this book down!  Delia Owens is so descriptive of the marsh lands, that I felt like I was seeing and feeling all the same emotions of Kya!  I learned so much about nature that I did not know!  Kya did not accept second best.....she just needed to be loved!  I live in North Carolina, so this book spoke to my heart!  I, totally, understood and agreed with the author as she described the nature of the small town’s people!  I loved Jumpin and Mabel, and especially Tate!  I do not want to give anything away; however, I was disappointed that Kya never had children!  Great book for anyone who loves the nature of marshlands and the ocean, and small towns in the south after WWII through the 1960’s!
title: The Marsh Girl

author: Dawn D Boyer PhD - Author of 100+ Big Kids Coloring Books for adult coloring hobbyists
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2020
review_content: ... after I sat down to read the book - I COULD NOT PUT IT DOWN!  I spent about five hours reading the book straight through and I have to say the author had a 'breathtakingly beautiful' manner of writing prose, adapting the characters to their tone of voice and thoughts, as well as making my heart ache for the main protagonist.  There is a murder mystery embedded in the plot and the author was a genius in deflecting clues and hints to who 'done it' - with me guessing that perhaps the culprit would never be found - until the very end of the book and the twist was genius!  I started to cry when the main protagonist passed in the last chapter, but had to admit she lived a rich life and was truly loved.
title: Had this book sitting around for weeks before I picked it up - and THEN ....

author: Dragonmac52
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2020
review_content: 'Where the Crawdads Sings' is the story of Kya, the Marsh Girl, who, from an early age, was abused, abandoned, rejected, harassed and bullied by a predominantly prejudiced white community in North Carolina, my home state. The marsh 'mothered' her, a black family 'adopted' her, and a fellow lover of the marsh loved her.  She becomes a scapegoat for the murder of the town quarterback/woman-abuser. The trial covers almost a quarter of the storyline. Fasten your seatbelt til the 'end of the ride.'
title: 'Where the Crawdads Sing' is not for the faint of heart.

author: Kat 5/2020
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2020
review_content: My best friend posted about reading this book and she always has great insight for books. So I downloaded it and started reading it and couldn't put it down. This past week I've had many long days due to late nights reading this wonderful book. Kya captured my heart right from the beginning. It was as if we got to grow up with her. All her trials, Tribulations and loneliness. I also knew from the moment we met Tate that he would be a big part of the story. Reading about how Kya learned new things and how strong she was, even as a young child, is what kept me reading. She knew how to take care of herself even in times of despair, I'm glad it was her that killed Chase, he got exactly what he deserved. Delia Owen's knows how to keep the reader enthralled, up to the last word of the book. Please write more books like this, reading about strong self made women is the best read ever.
title: An Excellent read!

author: bon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2019
review_content: I didn't rush to read this book when it first came out, as often I give a book awhile to be reviewed so that I have a better idea what to expect.I was done reading this book at some point in April and have yet to review it for one simple reason...in my head, I'm still living in it.  I haven't really finished it yet in that I think about it often.  All I can say is wow.  Just wow.  This is, I believe, my favorite book ever, or if not, it's in the top three.  I am nearly seventy years old and have been reading profusely since I could, so that's saying something.There is nothing that should ever be changed about this book.  It is informative while being inspiring, devastating, lovely, horrendous, beautiful, breathtaking, heartbreaking, and wonderful.  It is perfect.  There is no one who would not like this book.  It will touch you in a way most books could not dream of.I fully intend to read it again.  And again.  I envy you if you are reading it for the first time.  What an experience.
title: Perfect

author: flower
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2019
review_content: I was excited to read this book, but it turned out to be just okay.  Some of the storylines were very far fetched.  I think the writing was good but where the story led was pretty uneventful, even though there was a murder.  I was expecting more of a mystery.  I wouldn't waste my time.
title: I have to agree with most of the negative reviews

author: Charlotte L.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2019
review_content: I liked the writing but I would say the author set her story in a place she has never visited or spent very little time. I don’t understand her use of references to Asheville multiple times in the story. She has no idea how far away that is from the coast. The county attorney bought his ties there in a Sears? Well, that would be a six and a half hour trip in the modern age of interstates. Back after WW2 the distance on two lane country highways would probably more like ten hours. Her lack of familiarity with the state makes it a curious choice for her story. Her expertise on marsh and swamp is laudable.
title: Has the author ever been to NC?

author: Katie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2020
review_content: I was reading this book based on the suggestion from my unofficial official book club group because they were having a disagreement on a certain topic and I was to be the tie breaker. I almost didn't want to finish it because the first 20% of the book,while beautifully written, was slow and I wasn't seeing the point in it. By a third of the way through the book I was hooked!I cried a couple of times. Some out of sadness and some of heartache.God bless Jumpin' and Mabel. I still mad at you a little Tate for being a coward, but you redeemed yourself.I don't want to give away too much, so read it. Stick with it for the descriptive writing of the marsh and stay for the way society treats those that are different.
title: Slow start, strong finish

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2021
review_content: Spoilers:  Regarding the red hat. If she was dressed like a man on the bus trip in and dressed like a old woman on the bus trip out where did the red hat come in? She had very limited time to commit the murder. So there are three options here. 1. She kept on the man disguise and added a red hat and killed him then changed to the old lady disguise and caught the bus while not wearing the red hat. 2. She quickly changed into her own clothes (out of the man clothes) and put on the red hat only for the murder then quickly changed yet again to the old lady disguise without the red hat. 3. She went ahead and changed from the man clothes and changed directly to the old lady clothes before the murder...while putting on the red hat only for the murder then hurrying to the bus without wearing the red hat.
title: Contains Spoilers, don't read if you don't want to know

author: Aassshlee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2020
review_content: I love this book for so many reasons,1. I loved the nature element. I felt like I was away on a camping trip with my family by time I was done reading this book. It felt like a little vacation.2. Yes, the love stories are a bit unrealistic in my eyes, but so are most books, duh. The love in this book was different than other love stories I’ve seen/watched. It was a very unique dynamic of love.3. The resilience of Kya is amazing. By the end of the book, you’ll feel like she grew up with you.This book was written so well, I felt like I was there for almost all of it. I did, however, feel the beginning was a little slow, but it was like the first 30 pages, not the entire thing. I really loved this book, and this isn’t even “my type” of book.
title: Nature, love, crime, resilience. This book has it all!

author: Jennifer Poteet
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2021
review_content: My favorite thing about this book is how well written it is and even though poetry is flowing throughout this book the lush language the author uses makes the whole book feel like one giant poem. Kya’s connection to the earth and how the Marsh helps her through her loneliness and isolation is absolutely beautiful. The story itself sucks you in. You root for the gentle Marsh Girl. I was so glad that this book didn’t do that thing authors think is edgy and not give you a happy ending. I will say I was very surprised when I found out the murder, this book isn’t a crime novel but there is a crime and a trial, wasn’t an accident. I was quite pleased. And if you do not love Tate you have no romantic bone in your body.
title: A book that is pure poetry

author: E. L. Bailey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2020
review_content: I loved this book. it is on my favorites shelf. I loved the way it details life in this bayou town. I love the character building. I loved the tension created during the murder investigation and trial, and the way it made me think about biases and prejudices within myself.  I couldn't wait to find out what was on the next page but I didn't want it to end too soon. I've never seen so much beauty woven into a tragic murder mystery. But was it really so tragic? Maybe you will find the answer for yourself because I could see how different people could end up arguing that point. How do you find hope and love in the midst of such fear and pain and hardship? it's in there. So much to love about this one.
title: Did she do it or not? Brilliant building up to the end.

author: Mathspirit
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2019
review_content: I couldn't get beyond Part 1, it was so depressing.
title: Very depressing beginning

author: Roxanne Coats McDonald
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2019
review_content: This book was very interesting and beautifully written. It draws you into our heroine’s life and you become intrigued at her loneliness, love of the marsh and her survival instincts. Many reviewers question the reality of the plot since the heroine is uneducated and naive to the ways of the world.In my opinion, a 5 star book should be able to draw the reader into the storyline and keep his/her interested and wanting more. The reader should think about the book when not actually reading it. The reader should either not be able to put the book down and or longs to start turning those pages again. The plot and characters should be complicated with twists and surprises. It should have a strong message which stays with the reader after the conclusion of the reading material. “Where The Crawdads Sing” offered all this and more to Yours Truly and so I am giving the book 5 stars and an A from me.
title: Where Crawdads Sing Makes the Grade!

author: Tabby Cat
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2021
review_content: I didn't hate this book, but I didn't love it either. The murder is distracting, the trial is theatrical. I knew the ending immediately so there was no "surprise" twist or turn. I would have been happy with the ending of the book being Kya's new found success as a writer. I wanted more detail on her day-to-day survival as an abandoned child growing up alone in rough terrain. I wanted to see her have to kill an animal with 8-year-old hands and figure out how to cook and eat it in order to get to the next day. With the exception of the To Kill a Mockingbird trial (no new insights into the human condition with that one), Kya's character was simply let off too easy. I've never been to North Carolina and only got a vague idea of what it might look like based on the writing. The map at the beginning of the book was certainly helpful. Two stars for the book, three stars because the interlaced poems were well done.
title: It would be a better book without the murder

author: Paulette
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2021
review_content: A relative highly recommended this book saying “It was the best book she ever read.” So I ordered it. I read every spare minute I have and was really looking forward reading this book. Well the book was just so, so for me. I found a lot of it to be interesting and even learned a couple of new things from it, but in my opinion, it’s just okay.
title: A different kind of story.

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2020
review_content: I liked that it is a story of abandonment , love, independence, resourcefulness and loyalty.  It delves into the good and the bad in people and  how they balance each other.  It gives you a window into the 50's and 60's and how much has changed in race relations, yet, it sadly demonstrates how much has remained the same.  The author also takes you to an area of the country where poverty abounds and the differences between the classes are timeless.  Most importantly the author transports you with his vivid descriptions into a different era and a different environment totally foreign to me.I totally enjoyed the element of surprise and suspense throughout the entire book.
title: A great read!

author: Jan D.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2019
review_content: The author created a unique and memorable character with the marsh girl and her lifelong friend Tate, what went wrong is the use of the flavor of the day editing style of contemporary films. Backward, jump forward and backward again and again.Instead of sticking with her original characters, she wanted and failed miserably more tension by creating a very unbalanced back story of a generic sheriff and his sidekick that ultimately end up in a court case not unlike in on  of the most famous American novels.She should have stuck with her characters and she would have written a remarkable original voice story.Right now, trying to please to many masters, it is just an average coming of age story.
title: What does if take to write  bestseller.

author: thwaite
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2019
review_content: The author's descriptions of the marsh and wildlife are lovely. But steer clear if you are prone to sadness. Too many pages are devoted to a young girl's early struggles both as the daughter of a violent, alcoholic father, and later her lonely existence as an abandoned child. The author chose not to describe how the adult protagonist overcame an horrendous and terrifying threat to her existence, nor does the author give satisfying attention tothe story of her eventual success as a fine naturalist, as well as her discovery of safe contentment at last. Instead, the author drags out a court trial, and completely deprives her readers of the triumph of a woman whose pain yielded great power.
title: Ineffective Story Telling

author: Possum Trot
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2020
review_content: I very much liked this book.  Well written, engaging, with beatiful imagery.  My complaint is that the author didn't bother to learn much about the geography of the place she writes about.  The only city mentioned in the book is Asheville, NC.  People are driving from the beach to ASheville to shop, buy a bike, etc.  Asheville is 8 hours away from the coast of NC, probably longer before the interstate system.  Thus, they'd pass Raleigh, Greensboro, Winston Salem, Charlotte, etc. to drive all the way to ASheville, then go back.  Certainly nothing anyone would actually do.  Just shows a laziness by the author to fail to look at a map and just go with the one city in NC she has heard about.
title: well written except author doesn't know local geography

author: Darlene
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2019
review_content: Where The Crawdads Sing deals with isolation and Kya's challenges of surviving on her own for nearly 20 years in the swampland marshes of North Carolina.  The author's brilliant, descriptive writing ability immediately captivated me with her use of figurative language.  Her metaphors, similes and personification combined to create a very poetic quality to her ongoing narrative, further enhanced by her occasional inclusion of poetry.  I loved the author's several references to the title of her book, and I was especially impressed with the well-developed resolution to her novel.  Much can be learned from reading this book, as it has a depth to it that it's critics seem unable to fathom.  Although the storyline seems a bit implausible at times, it provides insights into the varying natures of men and women, their biases and prejudices, relevant to the times in which we now live.  I look forward to reading Delia Owens' next novel.
title: Beautifully written, heartfelt story of survival

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2020
review_content: I've had a difficult time reading lately but this book pulled me in right from the beginning. If you have never been to a marshland you won't know how amazing her descriptions are. She captures the absolute essence without being florid or tiring as she paints her pictures. I loved the characters and found myself justifying and criticizing their behavior in equal measure. I don't need to add my two cents about the merits of the author and story, you can read the thousands of descriptions already written I will just add my personal thoughts. I thoroughly enjoyed reading this. It was a hard subject at times but beautiful and thought provoking. I can highly recommend. Gbash
title: Oh my

author: LCW
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2021
review_content: Its been over a year since I read this book and I can't stop thinking about it.  Easily one of my top ten books of all time.  The authors love of nature is on full display here as she makes the marsh setting come alive.  You can feel the waves lapping on the beach, hear the singing of the insects, and feel the sweaty humidity of a marsh in the deep south.  But not only does the setting come alive the characters do too.  All of them.The plot has been covered by many reviewers before me so I won't get into it. I will just say I loved everything about this book.  You will ache, cheer, cry, and the ending is truely satisfying.  This book is absolute perfection!
title: Beautiful, haunting, this book will stay with you.

author: BaumanBookReviews
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2019
review_content: First things first, I love being in nature. It’s still winter here in the Midwest. Even though we are starting to get hints of spring, it’s not in full bloom. Being able to escape into the forest and the marsh through this book was so awesome. Delia Owens’s descriptions really bring the scene to life. I’ve read a few opinions on the book saying that it was too descriptive, but it was perfect for me.All of the characters had really interesting developments. I felt like every character had their stories wrapped up in a fitting fashion. One of them, we never really find out what happens – but, again, it’s fitting. Kya is the main character, and I don’t think you could even ask for more character development. It seems like we got just enough of her life story for it to be complete and wrapped up. That is SO satisfying to me because you don’t always get that.I just absolutely loved this book. A mixture of a coming of age story as well as a murder mystery and a love note to nature. It’s just beautifully written. The story is told so well. I didn’t want it to end. I would recommend it to anyone who loves nature.This book has one of the greatest last chapters I’ve ever read in a novel. It ties things up without blatantly just laying out answers to your questions. It’s so beautifully written and wraps up years of Kya’s life swiftly but respectfully.5/5 StarsMemorable Quotes: “Sometimes she heard night-sounds she didn’t know or jumped from lightning too close, but whenever she stumbled, it was the land that caught her. Until at last, at some unclaimed moment, the heart-pain seeped away like water into sand. Still there, but deep. Kya laid her head upon the breathing, wet earth, and the marsh became her mother.”“Crows can’t keep secrets any better than mud; once they see something curious in the forest they have to tell everybody.”“Autumn was coming; the evergreens might not have noticed, but the sycamores did. They flashed thousands of golden leaves across slate-gray skies.”“Evil was not in play, just life pulsing on, even at the expense of some of the players. Biology sees right and wrong as the same color in different light.”
title: Incredible Read!

author: BR
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2019
review_content: I loved this book! I set my expectations low based on a few negative reviews; BUT I was pleasantly surprised. Delightful read; I couldn’t wait to read each night.  If you’re on the fence; don’t hesitate any longer.Spoiler alert: contrary to a reader’s opinion that they found the storyline of a young girl surviving in the marsh alone (she was neglected, left alone & abandoned for most of her very young formative years), I did not find it impossible. I’ve seen young children learn to adapt and become young adults & learn to survive when their miserable parents & our systems failed them.  The other parts of the storyline that were a little unbelievable didn’t subtract from how good this book was.
title: Good vs evil.

author: Teresa AnnElizabeth
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2019
review_content: I finally decided to read Where The Crawdads Sing. I’ve watched it climb to the top of different bestseller lists, and then, literally stay at the top for the last 3 months. The #1 New York Times Bestseller and over 8200 5 star reviews on Amazon Kindle alone, I gave it a chance even though it wasn’t anywhere close to my normal genre of favorite books.For me, the book is somewhere between “Before We Were Yours”, by Lisa Wingate and “To Kill A Mockingbird” by Harper Lee, yet entirely its own unique “species” among all the others.I highly recommend the book. The only thing I would have done differently was with the Audible narration. I went back and forth listening and reading with Kindle’s “whyspersync”.If the narrator was the exact same as “Before We Were Your’s” it would be 5 stars ++. The narration was okay, but the southern accent, though bearable, didn’t have the same impact on me as the Lisa Wingate novel.It’s a beautiful book I feel destined to be a classic so if you haven’t read it already, choose it for your next read!
title: Bestseller and a Classic

author: Big D Reads
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 29, 2020
review_content: I went into this book not wanting to like it, to be honest, as the author's interview on CBS Sunday Morning turned me off completely. As I read, I saw the literary merit in the book, and many times I had to tip my hat to Ms. Owens. In the nature scenes, her prose are flawless. In the courtroom scenes, less so. Grisham you are not, ma'am.Then the ending... no spoilers, but the ending was a shock that was not fully earned. It is never explained how the ending is/was achieved, only that it was. Also, this is marketed as a mystery. It is not a mystery.If you want to read a truly good mystery, try A Knife In The Fog by Bradley Harper. For a truly good book, read the novel What Death Taught Terrence. I'm hoping Ms. Owens writes another book, and hopefully next time she focuses on a story whose ending actually makes sense!
title: A well-written book with a plot whole the size of Texas at the end

author: Lynn K. Harland
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2020
review_content: I loved it.  To all the reviewers who said it is unbelievable that a mother, father, siblings would leave a little girl alone to fend for herself I say to them this is a NOVEL.  Fiction!  It does happen of course all the time in this country and hundreds of other countries so really what's not to believe.  Survival of the fittest is a true statement regarding this book.  I found it to be full of love, empathy, heroic, graphic, and yes believable on so many levels.  I cried a bit several times throughout the book abut the ending took my breath away and the tears flowed.  A bait and switch finale that kept me guessing until the ending.  A great story and would NOT put this novel in the category of a "beach read".
title: A fabulous book!

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2020
review_content: This is one of their stories that will haunt you long after you lay down the book- After being abandoned by an abused mother and then again by an abusive alcoholic father the little girl is left on her own to survive in the marsh.  She finds a friend in the young who sees her passion in collecting unusual samples of the marsh and befriends her by leaving her special feathers and shells,  When he finds she cannot read he teaches her to read and write deepening the friendship.  Then one day he too abandons her.Then one day a charming young man works his way into her life and she is conflicted by her need to survive and her need for love.  Young and gullible she is led down the garden path to yet another tragedy.
title: Surviving a broken heart

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2019
review_content: This is one of those books that both surprises you and delights you.  The story is interesting and gives fresh eyes to an old issue.  Not just like others you have read.  The setting is immensly interesting and all the more so because the author is an actual naturalist.  This is her first novel, but she has written three other  non-fiction books.  She is writing about a swamp with the eyes of a naturalist and it was very interesting to take that in and know that the science is right.  I would recommend this book.  I'll probably read it again this winter.  THAT is high praise form me.
title: The best novel I have read all year long.

author: Dee Hill
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2021
review_content: I don't know why this is on the NYT bestseller list except now that so many people have read it it seems like a "must-read" book, it's acquiring readers like a dungball rolling downhill gathering mud. It's a cliched romance novel with a wildly implausible murder trial tacked on to it. Yes, the author does a lovely job of describing the sights and sounds of the natural world in the marsh. There are better, more realistic books out there about coming of age in impoverished circumstances with unengaged/absent/abusive parents ("The Glass Castle" comes to mind). Just skip this if you're a fan of great literature.
title: Pure schlock

author: Phost
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2019
review_content: My 94 year old grandfather suggested I read this, so of course I purchased it immediately. He told me, "lock yourself in a room for the last 30 pages, so no one can disturb you." My mom got the same suggestion from him and blazed through it, and said the same thing about the last 30 pages and was entirely enthralled when we were on a family vacation. I'm more than halfway through and I have to stop myself from starting a new chapter or I would actually never stop and never sleep.The author has a way of describing people and places to make you feel as though you are breathing the same air Kya is breathing. The connection to nature one feels when reading this incredible piece of literature is like no reading experience ever before. This is the best book I have read in years, probably ever. Owens touches on racial tension in the south, societal norms and cruelty to the 'other' and explicates scenarios of love and coming of age is beautiful prose. The reader is kept on their toes, at all times, and just when you think you understand something, another detail arises causing you to question.A true must read!!
title: Holy mackerel...

author: Sherry Sasser
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2019
review_content: I loved this book.  Close your eyes and this book will transport you into the Marsh instantly!  There is not one dull moment in this book, it is both exciting and alarming at the same time.  You grow to love the Marsh Girl and her determination to live in spite of the conditions that she must live in, because she wants her independence and her home.  She is alone but, she is surrounded by what she loves and refuses to give up NATURE!
