The book surrounds her difficult life living alone in the marsh all the while she becomes an expert in the field of all animals, fish, birds, plants and anything to do with the marsh land she grew up in and lives in, eventually gaining acclaim for her knowledge and going on to write several books on her knowledge and collections over the years.  The real twist only comes at the very end when the reader realizes something, she had to do, surprise ending , but she had to do it.  She is a great person even if she was a Marsh Girl.
title: Excellent Read !!

author: Dadannac
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2020
review_content: Based on the reviews, I was prepared to either love or hate this book. It was the former for me.  Yes, the idea of a young girl raising herself in the marsh without resources, adults, medical care, etc. is far-fetched, but this is fiction after all, and the author did a great job of convincing the reader this could happen and this determined and talented girl could accomplish it.  And such a tutorial on nature without being pedantic!  The first 150 or so pages were almost perfection for me—great prose, setting, character development, emotion, plotting, suspense etc.  Although I enjoyed the last half of the book, when the story evolved into a decent murder mystery-courtroom drama read with some good twists, it didn’t quite rise to the level of the first half.  You won’t regret reading this wonderful novel.
title: Read this book

author: AG
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2019
review_content: Before reading this book, I did some research about the author and listened to a few of her interviews. As a young girl,  I was always fascinated by Lions and Elephants, so I was immediately immersed by the author’s life in Africa and the isolation she experienced living in a wilderness with these animals. This book as she described it, is about human nature in its core with isolation. The writing is beautiful and poetic. The character, Kya Clark is the epitome of strength and how one survives abandonment and continuous disappointments. Yet, finds love and learns to trust again. She will touch different emotions in every readers,  and will take them into an adventurous journey filled with sadness,  but  ultimately contentment at its core. Highly, highly recommend this book.
title: Amazing Book. Beautifully written. Great story.

author: Karen C. Smith
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2018
review_content: The is a charming novel, with beautifully rendered descriptions of nature in the swamps and wetlands.  The story of Kya requires you to suspend disbelief because it never quite fleshes out her story of survival when abandoned at age six.  I kept wondering how she survived life on the far margins of society.  This is really the only “catch” in an orherwise delightful novel.  The story of Kya is one of resilience in spite of insurmountable odds.
title: A Naturalist’s Delight

author: Carolyn K S
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2020
review_content: A good friend was besotted with this book. It was her book club choice, heck Reese loved it. All I can think is why??  All the siblings and the mom and finally even the dad leave this 5-6 year old?? Who would do that- did none of them have one  shred of decency? The parents were originally from good families, yet they speak and act like trash. The murder chapters were distracting. A normal time line probably would have worked better than back and forth through years.Honestly I did not like this book at all. And I did not realize while reading it was not even showing NC correctly. I saw that in the many reviews I read trying to figure out what I missed.
title: Sadly not my cup of tea

author: JannyVH
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2019
review_content: It was recommended to me by a couple strangers at random in a local coffee shop (which happened to be in Chapel Hill, NC).  They agreed "it's the best book I've ever read and found myself reading it slowly so it wouldn't end".  I blew it off thinking one may actually be the author and trying to promote it.  Within a few days, my boss asked me if I'd read it.  He said he read it in 2 days because he couldn't put it down.  Of course, I had to give it a try.I have to admit, it's one of the best books I've read.  I read many reviews regarding different aspects of the book.  I agree with most all the positive comments but have to say the descriptive writing was by far my favorite part.  The story was great, but the author's knowledge of the extreme details of nature was mesmerizing.  I would highly recommend you treat yourself to this amazing story.
title: LOVED this book!

author: S. F. Wilson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2020
review_content: Typically the begining of a book is at least interesting enough to keep me reading further.  I find the heavy accented language style of WTCS challenging to read in a fluid manner.  I've read many sentences more than once to get even the basic idea of the intened message, and I'm only on page 9.  It's my thought that the overly detailed discription of the desolate marshlands dragging on and on and on wasn't neccessary. Providing readers a one page discription of the setting would have accomplished the authors intent.  Right now I'm turned off from the book and feel like I need a bath.  I don't know if I'll pick the book up again and give it another chance.  Maybe.  I've heard alot of great things about it.
title: Doesn't Draw Me In

author: Marilyn Ragland
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2021
review_content: American indigenous writers craft descriptions of the natural world so detailed, they read like poetry. Delia Owens first novel has that quality. An isolated lonely child grows into a woman whose reality is shaped more by the natural features of low country Georgia than by the people in her community. Her development into a woman of substance - independent, loving, operating by the rules learned in her world - is a pleasure to experience. To understand the indomitable will of the human spirit for survival, our need for connection to others, our drive for justice within community, and the incredible beauty of the southeastern marsh land, read Where the Crawdads Sing.
title: A Hauntingly Beautiful Narrative

author: UMB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2019
review_content: Kya’s story is in parts powerful, earthbound and majestic. The story of someone who is closer to nature than people. Who has deeply touched people who see with than their eyes and who, in the end, lives her own truth.Sometimes a book comes along that is so strong that others fade beside it. This is one of those books. It pulls you into a story that spans decades but remains rooted in the evolution the central character from abandoned child to distant aloof adult.Kya knowing only that people go away, is self protective to the point where her isolation makes her a curiosity and marks her an outsider. But it is also the story of someone who finds purpose in deepening her knowledge of the Carolina marsh she calls home. A self-taught expert, artist and scientist, her knowledge leads to a life unimaginable for the abandoned 7 year old.
title: Wonderful story, beautifully written, profoundly moving

author: Teresa Cobb
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2020
review_content: Reading this book felt like an eight-hour slog through the swamp marshes Delia Owens describes in her book.  Some parts are impossibly slow to navigate, such as the descriptions of plant and animal life in the marshes and the main character's early life with her abusive father. I kept waiting for progress and waiting and waiting. Also, I realize novelists have to take some creative license, but this book requires suspension of rational belief from start to finish. I bought a new hardback, I plan to donate it to Goodwill so the next reader who's suckered in by all the good reviews can buy mine for a third of the price.
title: Messy Writing, Unbelievable Plot, Annoying Stereotypes

author: Tracy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2020
review_content: Sometimes you read a book and know that it will change what you consider to be a good book going forward and this is that book for me.  I started reading the book and then stopped because I was so upset that this little girl was left behind and no one seemed to care.  But, the book kept calling to me to finish, so I gave in, prepared for what may come.  When the end came, I was not ready and have read the ending about 10 times now and reverted to the map for a visual of Kya's footprint.  This book will stay with me, as time goes on, I may forget the characters names, but I will never forget the book and a renewed love of reading it provided.
title: A beautiful life story of quiet strength

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2019
review_content: I read this book in one day.. The manner in which the author wrote was deep. I fell in love with the character kya, the stark vividness of her life touched my heartstrings. As Kya grew up and became a young woman she learned at such an early age that those you love can quickly leave you, but in a way there are those that will love and care for you no matter what. The father behavior was cruel, but there was a moment in this book where he demonstrated care and interest in his baby girl. But he had his own demons to bear, I wished we could've known more about her older siblings how they fared after there mother left.. I thought was refreshing to see her brother cone back and be supportative. Although Tate was her first love, she had me cracking up when she threw pebbles at him, but I guess you can say first loves are never forgotten. I didn't like the prejudices of the town people especially the mother with the young child.. I couldn't put this book down. Kya was resilient and strong and after nearly being raped by her ex, I can understand why she did what needed to be done.. Surprising ending...
title: Poignant and enriching

author: Loretta H. Diehl
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2020
review_content: I just finished reading this book today and have been thinking about the story all day long.  The descriptions of the landscapes and the wildlife of marshes, swamps, and estuaries are truly stunning, as is the original poetry.  But, the most compelling aspect of this story is how the author weaves the aspects of wildlife into the narrative comparing humans, animals, birds, and insects and their ways of being in the world.  The author has a very keen knowledge of what she writes about , but also an engaging writing style and story-telling ability.  I can highly recommend this book as one you will find it hard to put down.  I actually read it in about 5 hours.
title: What a rare find!

author: Roseygirl
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2020
review_content: What a story.  How can a baby girl of 6 learn to live on her own?  Nature has a way of guiding us along the way.  To live without nurturing, love, touch, family or friends are unimaginable to us.  While Kya's story is both sad and compelling, it was Tate's story that touched me most.  He had to bare the burden of loving her from a distance for so long and then at the end realizing what she had done.  Considering how long this has been a bestseller, I wasn't as intrigued as I expected to be.  Yet I was compelled to keep reading to find out what would happen to this brilliant, self-taught, nature lover who appreciated her world much more than most of us could ever imagine.
title: Crawdads Singing

author: Well Read Nana 1/24
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2019
review_content: I'll be really honest, I purchased the book well over a  month ago when it first came out .I read the first two chapters and put it down. It wasn't until my book club chose it as our first read into the new year that I picked it back up again and I'm so glad I did.I think what made me put it down in the first place was the author's overly extreme detail to nature and the marsh land where this story takes place.I must have been in a impatient mood that day and even though I'm still saying that there is extreme detail about the surroundings of the book,it turns out to be very warranted even if I bit long winded at times.I finished the book in a day and a half and it really enjoyed it. It's definitely a murder mystery but with so much more relationship fascists. The ending was a great surprise, the writing was good ,editing great , it's definitely worth your time and money. I finished the book hours ago and I think it's going to be on my mind for a few days. That is when you know that a book left it's mark .
title: It was a really good read,it's definitely a must read.

author: David A.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2020
review_content: Great story.  Great characters.  Great development of plot.  Great depiction of trial -- I have been a trial lawyer for 50 years and this story captured the drama, essence (and accuracy) as well as any book I've read.It's a book that's hard to put down.  Author does a terrific job telling the story in two different time periods, going back and forth between them, rather than in a chronological sequence which wouldn't have been effective.I read the authors bio and was surprised to learn she is a scientist and her prior works were non fiction.  I'm looking forward to her next novel.All in all, an excellent read.  Highly recommended.
title: Great story with good character development

author: Krista
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2020
review_content: I bought this book at the recommendation of a few people and I'm glad I did.  I loved the book!  I had no idea what it was about and was shocked at the reviews here that were polar opposites...people either loved it or hated it, almost no in-between.  I guess it just depends on your personality and life's experiences if you liked it or not.  I'm an introverted loner and spent a lot of time alone as a child.  I've been very hurt by a few people in my life and that's left a big impact on me with trust issues, so I guess I could, in a small way, relate to Kya's personality, plus I love nature and also collect feathers, shells, rocks, bees nests and tree fungus, and of course, love the southern coastal states of the United States.  I could truly 'feel' Kya's hurt and how it molded her personality to retreat further and further from civilization and people who weren't genuine.  I was rooting for Kya the whole time.  As far as the ending, I was sad that she died so young, and I was shocked, but in a way, not shocked, at what Tate found under the trap door of the shack after Kya's death.  I found the book to be a real page-turner and would love to see it made into a movie!
title: Beautiful book, a page-turner!

author: Denny cranford
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2020
review_content: Excellent book. The main character will steal you’re heart.In a small community where people are afraid of anyone who is different a woman whose simple existence causes discomfort and protectiveness.When she is in trouble the community’s ability to extend grace and “love thy neighbor “ comes into question.Does being different by definition make you a criminal or someone to be feared? Are small minded people capable of setting aside preconceived prejudices?Are you capable of putting aside your opinions and put yourself in someone else’s position?This book raises these questions causing you to examine your own ability to re-examine preconceived notions.The ending will surprise you.
title: Is being different wrong?

author: E. Lees
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2020
review_content: The popularity of this book speaks to either a paucity of competition or a really, really good agent.  As a 5th generation North Carolinian, I found the use of so many stereotypes offensive -- the drunk, no-good father; the downtrodden wife (who in this instance abandons her family); the poor little white trash waif who is really so much more; and the kindly African American couple who take pity on her.  Give me a break!  Even the title is offensive. Crawdads is not a word generally used in the part of the country where the story is set, and honestly, I never heard a CRAYFISH sing.  I did like some of the descriptions, and I wished the author had written about what she really knows.  Not sure why I didn't give it a 1.
title: What's the big deal

author: lpreddy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2019
review_content: Drawn in by the back and forth storyline between the hardships of growing up in the Carolina marsh and the mysterious murder of a local hometown favorite son, this story weaves together flawlessly and is a "can't put down" read. Kya emerges as one of the most fascinating characters written in years. Her unique circumstances and outstanding ability to embrace and study the marsh land that so fully defines her has created a humanity that defies the reader to take a slow look around their own community and see people in a different light. Her story shed light on the plight of so many children who were let down by every single adult in their lives and found a way to endure. These stories are too frequently lived in the very cities of our large urban areas still today. As much as I loved the character of Kya, the more ashamed I was at any time I turned when I saw a street child who was completely abandoned and hungry. Thank you to the author for reminding me the importance of SEEING these children.Another great concept from this novel was the difference between "school" smart and intelligent. Kya's intelligence, and later in life her validation of that intelligence, was an inspiration. The sweet and sometimes sour love story woven through that search of learning was both heartwarming and heart breaking. Just very well written.This is one of those books that will be with me forever. After finishing the first read, I immediately reopened and reread the first 4 chapters of the book. It is that good. If you only read one book in 2019, this should be that book.
title: Best fiction novel of 2019!

author: D. F. Dehart
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2019
review_content: A delightful story, the writing is lyrical with imaginative with beautiful original metaphors.  It’s worth the read if only to enjoy the writer’s skill as she describes, the sights, the smells and the creatures of the swamp.  The storyline may be too unbelievable for some, but it is an imaginative creation in novel form so I could overlook that.My real disappointment was in the physical quality of the product.  This is a shoddy product, poorly bound with thin paperback quality pages from an old and reputable publisher.  Midway through the book chapters 31, 32 and 33 were repeated so it took a bit of searching to find the plot again.  Putnam & Sons should be embarrassed by the quality of their product!
title: A Good Read But a Physically Shoddy Product

author: Book reader
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2018
review_content: The story start out with a death. No clues ,nothing to show what happened. Then the book goes back to the start of a young child of 6  who's family slowly over time  just up and leaves because of her abusive father. They leave her alone  in the marsh in North Carolina. She meets a young man named Tate , whom she loves, who teaches her to read. But he leaves to go to college. Her education is her environment and what few ppl she trusted. They understand her pride and trade with her to give her the things she needs.  But she never truly trust anyone due to the way the town folks had treated her.I loved this book which I rarely can say. The author made me feel so much apart of Kya and the marsh. I turned each page waiting to see what next was going to happen. This book never disappointed not even the ending. Which oddly just made me smile and shake my head yes.This is a book if fiction so to expect it to be anything else is foolish. I loved the slim chance of such a life happening.
title: Unbelievably touching

author: Maryann Troche
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2019
review_content: This AUTHOR has grabs every emotion that exist. Wow! Her first  novel and she blows it out into the universe! A heartfelt story of a little girl left to fend for herself. Abandoned by her mother due to the abuse given by her father, abandoned by her siblings for the same reason. her own father comes and goes until he never returns.  This is a moving story of a young girl learning about life completely on her own living in a run down shack and living with only nature as her guide.  She becomes smarter than you and I who is reading this.  She makes three friends who are her Angel's.  I am touched deeply by how she went about surviving by nature. She was neglected yet probably learned more in this state than any person with money, school and parents. I won't spoil this by telling you everything Kya goes through; I guarantee you will be in love with Kya when you're done.
title: If you love "To Kill A Mockingbird" hurry up and start reading!

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2019
review_content: I did not want to read this book. Nature, coming-of-age,  gentle, southern... all the descriptors that make me roll my eyes. My book club had to promise me there wasn't a child rape (you see it coming, and a lesser author would have succumbed to its siren song, but they were right).I'm still unpacking what I think. It's beautiful, yes, but am I seduced into belief? Hmm. Kya's transformation (in terms of sophistication, vocabulary, articulation) is just too abrupt, too complete. I get that she knows everything there is to know about her marsh and its biology; I don't buy that learning to read suddenly transforms the way she speaks utterly and completely, especially when she has no real desire to join or fit in with the outside world.What is the measure of a good book? Keeping me up at night reading? Thinking about it after I finish? This checks those boxes for sure. Do I want to live in this world? Not even a little bit. It makes me itch just thinking about it.I assign stars by gut feel. Most people will *gush* over this book, which usually subtracts a star for me. So yeah, chances are you'll like it.
title: I (grudgingly) liked this book

author: Julie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2019
review_content: I don't think I can even put into words how incredible I found this novel to be. My heart was in no way prepared for the emotions Delia Owens made me feel. Every page is absolutely engrossing and beautifully written. The heart-wrenching loneliness and vulnerability put on display only makes the connections forged feel so much deeper. I genuinely can't a remember a time when I have felt this strongly about any book. If you don't read this book in your lifetime, you are doing yourself a disservice.
title: A beautiful celebration of life, love, and nature

author: The Spoiler
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2020
review_content: I cannot believe that this is Delia Owens first novel, It is absolutely the best book I have read in a long time and I have read many books and most of them excellent, but through this book I could appreciate Kya's natural world and even picture some things in my minds eye.  I felt that little girl's pain at rejection and admired her resilience in pushing forward when people would leave her all alone in a place and time of overt racial and sexual discrimination.  I am not going to spoil this book for you, but if Oprah can recommend books, so can I even though I'm not famous or a professional book reviewer, I'm screaming..........GET THIS BOOK!!!!!!
title: Not a Crawdad and Can't Sing, But I Am Singing!!!!

author: Bonnie Dooley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2019
review_content: I loved this book!  It was such a great story on so many different levels!  It had a mystery that kept me guessing until the very end.  It showed what life was like for children who had tough upbringings in the 1950s and 1960s.  It accurately depicted the life of people on the coast in the Carolinas as well as the geography, attitudes, accents, etc.  It described the elitism, sexism and racism in great detail of small town southern life in the mid 1900s.  It showed the human ability to survive under the most adverse conditions and how to find joy in life in the simple but really most complex beings.  A must read for everyone!
title: I loved this book

author: Happy Hill
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2019
review_content: Laughable anachronisms galore, cross betwee n Green Mansions and The Blue Lagoon, tedious and incredible plot, deadly writing and so on. Teenage sex anyone?  Some historical points I think are just wrong  but too bored to follow up.  For instance, was her dad drafted or did he volunteer?  Men with multiple kids were exempt for most of the war I believe.  Okay, I cant finish this mishmash.  Best sellers arent necessarily good books.
title: Save yourself time and money.

author: customer of the week
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2019
review_content: So as not to give details of the ending which would ruin reading the book for those who are just buying it...I'll just say that there are holes in the logic which bothered me.  Otherwise, the story also bothered me, because my granddaughter is the same age of Kya when she was left.  Charles Dickens also used children fending for themselves in his plots, so the author is in good company.  Also, and this is on me, I never knew how to pronounce her name, long e sound or long i sound?  I went back and forth and was distracted by my self.  Enjoyed all of the nature facts woven in.  Read it in one day.  Can't wait for the movie, although Hollywood will have to add some nasty language, and that is why I don't go to movies anymore.  I'm sure a movie will come out of this book.
title: holes in ending but enjoyed the read

author: Psymansez
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2019
review_content: I read a LOT - 2-3 books a week, and this is one of the very best in years. A first novel by a talented scientist, the author weaves both her marine biology work and an obviously rich emotional life together in an incredibly moving novel. The book combines a fascinating who-dunit plot line with wonderful descriptions of the coastal area of North Carolina. For me, it was somewhat like reading the best of Pat Conroy - rich Southern writing, and with a plot that grips you, and what an ending.
title: Moving and intellectually satisfying, both to the nth degree

author: Debbie Finn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2020
review_content: I enjoyed the descriptions of the location and reading about the wildlife. I did not feel like the characters were well developed and found the circumstances implausible. A mother who had the courage and wherewithal to leave would not have left without her young children. No way. Starting with that idiotic premise already took me out of the story. A 6 or 7 year old left to her own devices? Also highly implausible. In all that time she never needed any work done to the shack? Nature would have completely overtaken that place, especially in that climate. I found most of the characters to be more like caricatures of personalty types. When a story can’t be believed and characters are flimsy. it is hard to get into it fully. Just my opinion.
title: Unrealistic story, undeveloped characters

author: Kindle CustomerKayte
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2020
review_content: One of  the best novels I've read  .  This author scribeOne of the best novels I've read.  The author described the swamp life of people, birds, wildlife with such skill, this reader could visualize it all while reading about all of it.  Kya, the "marsh girl" survived living there on her own after being abandoned, first by her mother, then by all her siblings.  She lived with her often absent drunkard father until he, too , leaves never to return. At the age of 10, she was alone. She finds means to support herself and adapts. This is a spellbinding read, the story ends much too soon as I didn't want it to end. I highly recommend this book!! I'd award "Where The Crawdads Sing" more than 5 stars!!
title: Absolutely Wonderful

author: M.I. Silk
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2019
review_content: A 6 year old manages to raise herself in a shack until she's an adult. Let's first address Hurricanes.... Having lived in an area just like this for most of my 60 years... it couldn't happen. Nevermind that that flat bottom boat, or motor, lasted for  15, or so years... that wouldn't , COULDN'T happen either. The whole story is ridiculously impossible.
title: Ridiculous story line

author: Xin Chen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2020
review_content: The rating of the book is very high. So I read it. The story is interesting, although as a biologist myself, I personally feel that the self-educated naturalist and biologist story is hard to believe, but at least it is beautiful, as a beautiful fairytale. What I was really shocked is that She did kill Chase! It was a accurately planned murder, hiding in the bus, taking advantage of the tide, etc. She got away with murder and had absolutely no remorse. Yes, Chase was a cheater, a jerk, but did he deserve to be murdered? No way in my opinion! I feel sorry that she was abandoned as a kid, and she was prejudiced by the villagers and cheated by Chase. But that does not give her the right to kill another human being!I am sorry that I cannot accept the moral base of this book.
title: A fairytale that went horribly wrong

author: Don C. Johnson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2019
review_content: This is the best book I have read since I read "To Kill a Mockingbird," more than 50 years ago.  Simply stunning!  This book has everything.  A great story line with well defined three-dimensional characters.  It is a love story.  It is a mystery.  It is a legal thriller.  It is a prison drama.  It deals with major social issues like race and class and family dynamics in an absorbing and uplifting manner.  It is a character study of the first order.  It is wonderfully written from the beginning to the end -- the story line is simply enthralling.  It also deals with nature and wildlife in an enlightening manner.  All the while portraying small town life in a sleepy southern town very realistically and with flair.  It is an amazing historical novel.  It creates wonder.  It creates awe. Simply stated -- it is a must read.  A MUST READ!  If it is the only book you read this year, or this decade, read this one!  READ THIS BOOK!If you read one novel this year -- or this decade -- this should be the one!
title: Best Book Since "To Kill a Mockingbird"

author: S. Carroll
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2019
review_content: I finished it because I felt invested but it really is not well written. Quite elementary really and vapid dialogue. The ending is un-believable (that is to say not believable) and left me feeling very sad for her boyfriend. This book was highly recommended to me by so many people and I have to say, I wish I had those hours back that I spent reading it. One positive note, the author is very skilled at describing the NC coastal islands and estuaries.
title: Meh.

author: CatBleux
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2019
review_content: I got this on a very strong recommendation from a friend and I was very disappointed. I really wanted to like this book. This reads like a first attempt at a young adult novel.  The characters were secondary to the endless descriptions of the marsh, the shells, the feathers....A 7 year old surviving alone in a dangerous place is implausible, the characters really a bit thin and just written in a juvenile manner. I had no connection with the characters and hated the whole murder/mystery plot - which was transparent right from the start.
title: Wanted to like it but was very disappointed

author: AliceP06
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2020
review_content: I admit I bought this book given the number of reviews and mostly positive reviews on Amazon. I did not quite understand what this was novel going to be about and I had some trouble getting into the first few chapters, but I kept reading until I finished that same-day I started. Once, I got into the story about this poor marsh child, it had me emotional & I’m not really an emotional person. It also reminded me a bit of Jane Eyre by Brontë in a way well with the difficult upbringing of the Marsh girl. Then, once she was a teeenager and had her first love, I was captivated by the love story! I kept reading & reading hoping this story would never end! It’s a really good novel and I hope they dont make a film, but a series!!!! I don’t think a film will be enough time to show this remarkable story and the characters! I am in “aww” by this book!
title: This book had me emotionally unstable through each chapter

author: J. Gallo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2018
review_content: This one had me guessing till the last chapter.  A really interesting story that pointed out the foolishness of some of the prejudices of the 1960's in the USA, and not just toward people of color.  The book is well written and you can "see" all of the beauty that the main character sees in her natural environment. The mystery part of the book is also a page turner as you try to evaluate "who did it?"  Reminds me of a lot of books like the Prince of Tides where the characters are well developed and very believable.
title: An unusable book, but a great read

author: Elizabeth Davis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2019
review_content: This book was incredibly boring. Endless descriptions of a marsh. One would have sufficed! Endless descriptions of flora and fauna. Let's face it a marsh is a marsh. A child surviving on her own with no idea how to cook or clean, really???? Time travel?? Going from the East Coast to Atlanta or Charlotte in an hour?!? Unbelievable!! The child learned to read and write with only 1(one) hour in a school, c'mon. I won't go into details on the courtroom trual. What would be the point! Totally boring and redundant! Don't waste your dollars (get a library card) .
title: Doesn't love up to the hype. Totally agree!!  BORING, BORING, BORING!!!

author: Jan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2019
review_content: This is an amazingly beautiful story of a girl who grows up in the 1950's in the marshes of the North Carolina Coastline. Abandoned by her mother by the age of six and then by all of her brothers and sisters, she is left to fend for herself and take care of her abusive father. Then he leaves her as well by the time she turns ten. Illiterate, penniless, starving, outcast and ignored as "white trash" by the town people, she learns to live on her own in her little shack, aided by the help of one black couple and a boy a few years older than herself.Where the Crawdads Sing is masterfully written and some of the best prose I have ever read.
title: What an amazing book

author: SWS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2019
review_content: Years ago, I saw a documentary about Delia and Mark Owens.  I immediately purchased their book.  By far the most memorable book of non-fiction I'd ever read.  When a friend suggested we read this over spring break, I knew who the author was and started reading it anticipating the beautiful descriptive language. I was not disappointed.  The story is good with many twists and turns, but the beauty is in the language.  The words read like poetry. Having lived on a salt marsh, her descriptions are authentic. The marsh becomes alive.  You will feel the quiet solitude much as the main character feels it. Owens treats the wild, secretive beauty with reverence making one want to explore such a place.  She also tries to instill that deep understanding that much of the land that is considered without value, and that we must protect and cherish its wild beauty.
title: More than a novel

author: KayTee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2019
review_content: This was not a complicated read, but it was - for lack of a better description-very satisfying. I came to care for the characters, dislike some as well. Was moved to tears several times, which was evidence to me of the power of the author’s ability to invest the reader in her tale. I feel as if I know the marsh despite never having been there. Possibly the only weak link was that I was not surprised by the ending - indeed expected it. But maybe this was also intended by the author.I was sorry when it ended.
title: Sorry when book ended

author: Michael
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2021
review_content: I have finally finished this WONDERFUL NOVEL!!! If you enjoy reading, if you have a sensitive nature and are a hopeless romantic who enjoys nature then this novel is for you!!I enjoyed this heartwarming, sometimes painfully sad saga about this wonderful little girl who lives a very difficult poverty stricken struggle in her life and triumphs over it despite overwhelming adversity!Beautiful prose that reminds me of another author named James Lee Burke !  They should definitely make this story into a movie!!  They are going to make it into a movie with Reese Witherspoon as a Producer!
title: Definitely worth your time and money!!!

author: Bradley D. Reigel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2020
review_content: Another Husband/Wife book club book!Overall a good read. Maybe too long on the set-ups and background, and too quick on the ending. For me, there were nagging holes in the story, beyond the absurdity of the conclusion that left me unsatisfied!Without giving away too much, some examples include that Ft. Benning, (Columbus) Ga, is the home of the U.S. Army Rangers (Special Ops). Not so much Engineers, although the Corps of engineers does have a base in Atlanta.They (Special Ops) can be referred to as “Sneaky Pete’s” or sometimes “Sneaky F*’ers”. (Book tie-in)That is where I thought she was going, and wonder if the author had any idea?My belief is that arc would have provided a more satisfying (and realistic) plot!Also why keep the shell?Chase? With a new wife? Like she would ever allow that...Kya? For someone so intelligent and so risk adverse, that makes NO sense...
title: The improbabilities that saved her ultimately render the conclusion absurd!

author: Karissa Downs
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2020
review_content: Where do I start! When this book first came out I checked it out from the local library, read the first few chapters and tossed it to the side uninterested.. in the months following I had seen it climbing the charts (now #2 on Amazon’s charts) and many friends were reaching out insisting that I read it. I bought that book yesterday afternoon and finished it about an hour ago. The book is slow building but once you get on the track you can’t put it down! It was really good for it being Delia Owens’ first book. The book pulls at your heart strings! It also requires you to pull out your inner southerner as we travel deep into Carolina’s marsh land!** Spoilers ahead**This book had me on an emotional roller coaster! I ached for the small girl left behind by family and society to fend for herself in the marsh! I found myself wanting to console her! I wanted to be her friend, her mom.. her family! I wanted the towns people to pull their head out of their butts and give her a chance!! It made me so mad at how close minded everyone was! I also soooo wanted her to have a child to carry on her legacy! But I love Tate and was so glad they found each other again! When the sheriff came to get him I was so scared they found evidence that he killed chase for him attacking her. After what he found in the floorboard I was sooooo stumped.. shocked.. in disbelief! I wish Delia would have written one more chapter and went back to the day of Chase’s death to show us how it played out! It would have made sense because she flip flopped so much in the book.. It makes me sad that she died and now Tate was all alone in the marsh but at least she died doing what she loved! Kya was a strong woman! She defied the odds! I love her for it! For all that she accomplished! She didn’t let her shortcomings decide her fate! She decided it herself!I am so glad I decided to give this book a second chance!
title: The Marsh Girl who will steal your heart, Kya

author: Cynthia McDermott
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2020
review_content: Good description of the swamp and ecosystem in north carolina... that is about where the realistic aspect of this book ends. Some how a six year old that is abandoned makes it on her own with no money or education. This book has the most cringey poems I had to start skipping them because they progress and get weirder. Its a fast read and its entertaining enough to finish but the ending is sort of predictable and its very unrealistic.
title: Starts out good... gets crazier

author: Brian Finney
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2020
review_content: What an unusual novel. A novel in which a stretch of marshland on the North Carolina coast figures as a major player in the narrative. The marsh and Kya (nicknamed “The Marsh Girl” by the locals) are equally the protagonists of this novel. Kya grows up in the marsh and while still a child is abandoned by her family. This leaves her with the marsh as her one abiding companion. “For Kya, it was enough to be part of this natural sequence as sure as the tides.” The marsh is not swampland. It is where plants and water depend on one another, creating a unique ecosystem that attracts its own species of birds and insects. As she matures Kya learns to paint and describe all the life forms of the marsh, eventually publishing books that reveal for the first time the secrets uncovered by her intimate and continuous observations of them.Delia Owens has woven into this already fascinating story a charge of murder against Kya and the trial that ensues. Yet it ends as it starts by telling the story of Kya as someone who sees human life as governed by the same laws that prevail in the natural world. In the court Kya compares the judge to the alpha male (with the biggest antlers), her defense attorney to a powerful buck, and the prosecuting attorney to a lesser male who needs to shout to be noticed, just as lesser male animals make up for their inferior presence with gimmicks. Kya can discern the same dominance hierarchies that create stability in the bird and animal kingdoms in the world of humans.I don’t mean to suggest that this is a novel in which little happens in this primitive natural world. Delia Owens opens the book in 1952 when Kya is only six. Within a few pages the narrative jumps to 1969 when the murdered man’s body is discovered. From then on the book alternates between Kya’s life moving relentlessly to her arrest for the murder in 1970 and the course of the investigation from 1969 to 1970, both strands coming together in 1970 when Kya is arrested and put on trial. The plot is gripping and skillfully handled.Just as Kya moves from the freedom of the marsh to the deathly confines of her cement block cell, so the fecund marsh gives way to the swamp inland where “life decays and reeks and returns to the rotted duff . . . death begetting life.” The parallels are subtly presented and work satisfyingly together. This is without doubt the best and most satisfying novel I’ve read this year. I would recommend it without reservation.
title: An unforgettable and unusual novel

author: Fritz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2020
review_content: An emotional ride, this book is at times beautiful, tragic, inspiring, and sometimes provokes anger at the way some people treat others.  It is a work of fiction, and I can not vouch for its regional or historical accuracy, but I doubt you will be able to read it and remain untouched.  I also believe it is possible for a girl or boy that age to have the basic survival skills.  You have only to look at the pioneers and some of the rural areas where everyone in the household had chores and had to contribute to the running of the household.  Draw your own conclusions, but  I highly recommend it.
title: Poignant and haunting

author: 30 Weight
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2020
review_content: Hope I don’t sound like a total snob here. —But If you like deep knowledge of a subject, irony, authenticity, believability, humor and/or thought-provoking content… Don’t get this book.It tricked me at first because the writer is obviously talented, but there’s really not much here in the end other than a bunch of unrealistic and magical thinking. Could a six-year-old girl really survive and learn to become a scientist aline in the Everglades? Are you a fan shallow scientific terms and bodice ripping sex? If you think that’s all good, this may be the book for you. It’s gonna be tough for this writer to dig down to find something deeper with 78,000 5 star reviews, but I hope she does.
title: Couldn’t finish it.

author: cookieASE
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2021
review_content: It started off strong and I was able to ignore some of the unrealistic parts and just read, but it began to be too much. I was able to finish the book, but many things were just told instead of shown. The characters weren’t rounded.  The black characters were stereotypical and even though they supposedly helped the main character out a lot, we don’t learn much about them. The dialect and poems were distracting and annoying. And the nature descriptions were beautiful, but did get distracting at times. It wasn’t what I expected. Someone stated in a review that it was like a lifetime movie and I agree. It is entertaining and kills time, but at the same time I wouldn’t recommend this book.
title: Meh... it was ok

author: J. Ban
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2020
review_content: I know I am late to the party of readers on this book. I am glad I chose it now. The beautiful rhythm of this book is soothing and intriguing as this book describes the little girl, Kya, a d her life in the marsh as she grows up.Sometimes you read a book that just grabs you and pulls you into the world the author created, and this one did exactly that for me.The marsh is soothing and the sea can be smooth on the surface, but both are moving underneath all the time. The author takes you into this beautiful and yet brutal world of nature and solitude and keeps you wanting more.Read this.
title: Beautiful. Just beautiful.

author: Catsjb
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2019
review_content: This is a book of feelings, feelings for the poor, lost, waif of a girl, rejected by most and loved by only a few.  Feelings for the young girl, alone in a cruel world and learning to live without the support of a family, scorned for being different, deserted over and over again.  Finally reconnecting with one of her family members and a lost love, she learns what love is truly about.  The end will leave you surprised and wishing for more and it will leave you astonished at the end.I enjoyed reading about the life living within the swamp and Kya's attention to chronicling everything so beautifully.  If you want a book that will stir feelings within you, compassion, joy, sadness, love, rejection, and a dramatic ending, this is the book for you!
title: Wonderfully touching.

author: Bookaholic
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2019
review_content: I had heard all the praise for this book but couldn't imagine that it would meet up to the acclaim . It surpassed it.The author is like a wizard using words to create magnificent artwork in the reader's mind. You want to actually see the world as Kya saw it.I couldn't stop reading until my eyes closed at 3:33 the first night and had to finish it the next day, while at the same time, I dreaded finishing it.Where the Crawdads Sing is as filling as the most delicious dinner you've ever had, and while you are sad that you've finished it, it is so complete in itself that you feel satisfied.This is one of the best books I've read in years, and I plan to re-read it one day, not because I will have forgotten the story, but because it is so beautiful.
title: An amazingly beautiful book

author: Tye H.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2019
review_content: The story was not believable, there were repeated and tiresome cheap attempts for sympathy for the main character, author used worn out 'Southern' stereotypes, put forth as a central idea that Kaia magically gained 'scientific' knowledge from 'observing' at wildlife, magically had an ability to read scientific texts without any education ( not easily understood with an education). Really think this book could not have stooped any lower to pull at the heartstrings. If you like a good/bad moral romantic setup, are comforted by nostalgia, and are able to suspend what you know of human behaviour & commonsense you may love it as much as most book groups of 50+ old women.
title: WORST BOOK

author: LaKuesti
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2019
review_content: Celia Owens never disappoints.  I had read and loved two of her previous books about Africa.  This one is a completely different setting.  Instead of exploring the lives, surroundings and emotions of animals in the wild, this one deals with a human being - in the wild one might say.  It brought tears of sadness and tears of joy  as the main character slowly and arduously learns the skills to survive, dealing with other humans and the temporary joys and then disappointments that come with it.  In the end  she learns to trust and to love.  A wonderful story beautifully told.
title: A beautiful book

author: J. F. Weigl
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2020
review_content: As a born-again introvert and having lived and traveled in the South; met a few inhabitants, and suffered the miserable heat and humidity, yes, I was living there. I marveled at the ambition and tenacity of Kya, which might reflect the ambition and tenacity of the author. I learned a bit more of the diversity of the environment. As a truth seeker and law abiding citizen, I still saw the self-defense mechanism in place for Kya to rid herself of living in fear from the monster Chase turned out to be. I thoroughly enjoyed this book, and most novels based on an author’s occupation, and look forward to more from Delia Owens.
title: Full of Life

author: jmurr
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2018
review_content: Definitely a different but entertaining story of a young girl, Kya, growing up in a North Carolina marshland, surviving using ingenuity, her understanding and love of nature.  The characters especially Kya are well developed and believable given the crazy circumstances. I found it a bit slow at first, but that might just be me.  The author eventually got me hooked after 10%. The read is also a love story and a testament to commitment. In a matter of fact way, the author highlights the worst and best in people and injustices that occur because of life’s situations. As any good story, there are some good twists that caught me by surprise! All and all I thoroughly enjoyed this book, would give it a 4.5!
title: Story of survival, heartfelt

author: Sky Gazer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2019
review_content: As other astute commenters have mentioned, the geographical, zoological, botanical, maritime and rational inaccuracies sink what could have been a terrific book. The author’s late, desperate hail-mary efforts in tying it up quickly with vapid bows of cliches and haste made, as they say, waste. A rewrite could save it, but that skiff has left the marsh.
title: No. Just.... No.

author: KAC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2020
review_content: Considering how long the book has been on the NY Times bestseller list, it's obvious that a great many people have loved it.  I thought that its first part, which covered the "Marsh Girl" growing up alone on the wild coast of North Carolina, was exquisite--a brilliant combination of insight into the girl and loving, knowledgeable description of the marshes and forests.  The second part, which covers a murder and trial, is cleverly plotted, but I didn't feel that the author's heart was really engaged with it as much as with the natural history.  Still, it's a far above average novel, and well worth reading.
title: A naturalist's view of the NC coast, plus a murder mystery

author: Laurie S Printz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2019
review_content: I don’t understand all the hype over this book. The only good thing I truly enjoyed about this book was the authors very detailed description of the beauty in the  marsh and it’s inhabitants. Since the author writes books on wildlife I think I would have enjoyed one of those more.Too many inconsistencies, unrealistic, the brutality of her home life was just barely addressed which was very disappointing, it seems that would have a more profound effect on Kya but I didn’t get the sense that it did.It is written in very plain prose which does make for a fast read, but did not help in consistency or holding my interest. I sometimes got confused with the characters because they spoke in different dialects in different parts of the story. I found myself going back to be sure I was reading about the right character.This could have been a beautiful story if it had been more realistic and consistent.
title: Disappointed and confused

author: Ericalc
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2021
review_content: Wow, this novel is capturing! I’m newer to reading novels as I balance my life between work and home. I’ve explored here and there, but I find myself struggling to remain interested after starting. Thus, I’m still on a journey to finding what I like. This hit the nail on the head for me and seemed to have been everything I ever would have been interested in to read! Mystery, love, a female coming of age, poverty, social issues/prejudices, nature indulging...this novel was emotional and so detailed I felt as if I were there at every scene hiding in nature watching.I read this in 3 days time and it was very difficult to put down. Needless to say, any chance I even had 5 minutes here and there I would pick up and read again.Look no further and buy this novel!
title: Intriguing and Beautifully Capturing

author: lisa m.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2020
review_content: I'm truly torn on this....The reason for 3 stars is honestly, I don't know if I liked or hated this book.  The imagery, passion and description the author puts into writing about the scenery of the swamp and all the items the character collects is so dymanic it makes you want to finish reading the book because you can feel the love the author has for the area.... but at the same time it's missing some serious body and meat to the story and plot to keep me entertained. I'd say, sure read this book if you have the time, but put it at the bottom of your book pile.  Not a must read in my opinion.
title: I honestly don't know if I liked or hated this book

author: Leslie, children's author and teacher😊
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2019
review_content: I'm a southern girl, whose traveled the world.I've  read too many books to count by excellent authors.And, I rarely bother to write reviews, feeling that one is drawn to books that touch their soul somehow.When i read the books title, it caught my attention. When I  read the sample, it touched my heart and love and respect for nature.Even the small things were a treaure to Kya, a tiny girl , all alone.I want this author to know she has given the world a treasure and hope she will gift us with more books like this one. In closing, i will say this is the first book i have EVER read, that at it's end, I realized there were tears in my eyes.Leslie Boriss Allgood
title: A Must Read for ALL and what is Sure to Becomea Classic in Literature.

author: Andy S.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2020
review_content: This novel offered the right amount of commitment and involvement for me, allowing me to pick it up, read a bit, then revisit it later in the week or month without missing a beat. The storyline isn't especially nuanced or complex; you could take a stab at the ending pretty early on. It would be a shame to project forward, as the descriptive writing offers an in-the-moment immersion that's truly delicious.  She paints scenes with words so well you can smell, see, feel and touch the environment she creates.  And she mostly steers away from cliches and conveniences, not that it matters. If you love nature, the outdoors, the human condition and grit, you'll enjoy this look into the life and loves of the Swamp Girl.
title: Enjoyable Tale of Human and Mother Nature with Wonderfully Descriptive Prose

author: Pauline V
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2019
review_content: I enjoyed reading Where The Crawdads sing by Delia Owens.  The story entails physical abuse, abandonment, betrayal, love, loneliness and a murder mystery . Ms Owens did a beautiful job describing the Marsh and its inhabitants (birds, insects, etc). The story centers around Kya Clark, also  called the marsh girl.  Kya is abandoned by her parents and siblings. She is left to care for herself at age 6, in a shack (not believable to me). The story goes between 1950’s, 1960’s and 1970, about kya and about the murder case. I did not like theWay Kya died, with no one by her side. There were parts of the story that are unbelievable to me, however, I enjoyed the book.
title: An Enjoyable Read

author: Lydia Fazio Theys
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2019
review_content: When I began this book, knowing nothing about it, I thought I was reading a new, young voice. Shortly into it, I realized I knew Delia Owens, had read some of her non-fiction work, and that this fresh and beautiful book was her first novel. The descriptions of the locations in WTCS were exquisite and perfect. I was there with Kya, the main character, and felt I understood her. The Marsh Girl was more than the last remaining victim of poverty and abuse, though. She represented to me what being a girl and young woman with an interest in science felt like. The world was simply not on board with that, and so she was suspect on many levels every day of her life. I don't want to get into spoilers, so I will stop at saying I hope there is a next book coming from Delia Owens very soon.
title: Isolation, Damage and Survival

author: ML Surprise
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2019
review_content: This book drew me in at the start. I've lived near the Atlantic Ocean for much of my life, and Delia Owens writes evocatively about the North Carolina coast and its ever-changing beauty and mystery. The local characters and their surroundings are brought to stark, vivid life. This debut novel teems with life - human, avian, aquatic - and works best as a coming of age story for Kya, the Marsh Girl, abandoned by her family and living on her own by age ten. Like the tides, the story moves back and forth, ebbing and flowing between Kya's quest for survival and the death of local golden boy Chase Andrews. Was his death a tragic accident or something more sinister? Read closely; all the answers are laid out well in advance of the final pages. In the end, what happens is less relevant than how it all unfolds, in lush prose, bird feathers, and sea shells.
title: Teems with life - human, avian, and aquatic. A beautifully written coming of age story.

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2020
review_content: Where the Crawdads Sing moved me more than anything I've read since Pearl Buck's The Good Earth! The intricate connections between man and earth seem tangible in this story. The predictable behaviors of those ignorant buffoons who seem to be  present in nearly every society are described in this book in heartbreaking detail. It's  sad to know the truths the author revealed in this novel. It also shows how love can persevere even  the most dire of circumstances as well. This book will become one of a few rare books in my library to be read and read again, simply to experience the wonderful talent of Delia Owens! Well done!
title: This novel has the makings of greatness!

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2019
review_content: Where The Crawdads Ding by Delia Owens is about the loss and loneliness of a young girl forced to live alone on the outskirts of society. Her grit and determination to survive are palpable on every page. While working every day to feed herself, she keenly observed the lives and cycles of the creatures that inhabit the marsh around her ultimately becoming an expert. The only constant in her life is Tate, the son of a fisherman, who befriends Kya in their youth, teaches her how to read, and becomes her first love.I genuinely loved this book. It is extremely well written. The characters are well defined and broad enough to be people I would wish to know. I recommend Where  the Crawdads Sing to anyone looking for a good and memorable read.
title: OUTSTANDING!

author: Deidre J. Edwards
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2019
review_content: My neighbor raved about this book saying it was a must read. I dutifully ordered it, not even knowing what it was about.It's been a long time since I have read anything of such quality as this book. The author paints such clear, rich, scenes and develops characters and thought processes in the skilled ways of accomplished writers. I was totally blown away. The plot and characters just pull you in to one great read. Being torn between turning to the next chapter and just pausing to digest and appreciate what I just had read, I usually chose to reflect on this great literature.  Still...the end came - with great surprise - and I am still savoring the quality of what I have experienced.Yes, this is a MUST read! Satisfying, poignant, and eye opening all at the same time.
title: A quality book for the ages

author: JR
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2019
review_content: At least it was readable. But it just didn’t make any logical sense. The author took too many liberties within the boundary of fiction. Skipping 40 years to get to the big reveal was lazy and left me wondering why  I just spent several hours getting there.
title: Ridiculous storyline

author: Buyer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2020
review_content: This was a great book at the start and well into the story. I liked it a lot, but it starts to go downhill at the trial and the way the author chose to end the book is a phoned-in, weak, unthoughtful betrayal. It’s like a gotcha in a bad episode of Law and Order. If the end was how it was going to be the lead up needed to be better planned in the book. Some of the events needed to be timed differently. The same outcome could have been written a number of different much better ways. Don’t change the end result, just rewrite farther back into the book how you get to the end.
title: Great, Great, Great, Then Ok, Then What? That Doesn’t Fit

author: PattiL
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2019
review_content: I loved this book from the very start.  Her character descriptions put you right there.  Those little feelings in the heart were right there.  The prejudices and hurting was right there.  I immediately did a search for other books by her, but I believe this is her only novel, so far.  She and her husband have written 3 other books, which I will be looking into, I believe they're documentary.  But if she's writing those, they're going to be great as well, I'm sure.  You can't go wrong reading this book.  It would be ok for young people too, it explains a lot about the natural Marsh life that lives in them.  Also a good lesson about not being prejudiced about people you don't know.  Highly recommend it.
title: BEST book I've read in a very long time!!!

author: Wanda Paryla
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2020
review_content: To me, this story is character driven and I really liked the main character as well as a couple minor ones.It is well written, and seemingly well researched. Some reviewers said they deciphered the ending early on.  Honestly, I didn't. I thought I had then found out I was totally wrong.I really like the era and setting, and think it's perfect for this type of story.I will admit the genre may not appeal to everyone. I found some reviewers felt they were about to read one type of story, then found out it wasn't what they thought it would be and for that reason, some people may feel misled and unsatisfied.I would label this women's fiction.
title: Well Written

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2020
review_content: Honestly this is one of the most heartfelt books I've read. Kya is abandoned by everyone and raises herself in the marsh. Everyone in town knows her as the Marsh Girl. Instead of taking care of Kya they shun her and leave her to her marsh.Kya sees the world around her more vividly, instead of living in the marsh she lives with the marsh and all it entails.You will not soon forget this beautifully written story. I laughed out loud,teared up and actually shed a few reading this story. Kya's story will stay with you long after your finished reading it.
title: Beautiful

author: Joshua M. Lisman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2020
review_content: Stupid. Why did this book get so many good reviews? It’s so long and drawn out. And the premise is totally unbelievable. The whole time I just kept thinking, “who cares?”  There’s nothing compelling me to want to finish the book except to just finish it which I did. So much of the story doesn’t matter and is disjointed. I wasted my time and money with this book.
title: Waste of time.

author: Diane Scott Lewis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2020
review_content: The first part of this novel draws you right into the flora and fauna of the North Carolina marsh. Owens' prose is lyrical in description and detail. The problem is that the likelihood of a six year old fending for herself after her family deserts her defies logic. She's never sick, the boat never falls apart, the shack doesn't leak. She never has to fight off poisonous snakes. It's too ideal for a struggle. And as many pointed out, no one would drive all the way  to Ashville for supplies, etc. I did want to finish it to find out the ending, thus the four stars.
title: Beautiful Prose but an Unlikely Plot

author: J. B. Perkins
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2019
review_content: I read this book for my book club and, after reading reviews, was looking forward to it.  The basic story was an interesting one and it was well written.  I did, however, have some problems with it.  I felt that the first part was very long and detailed and didn't get really interesting until Kya started interacting with other people.  The trial section was also interesting.  Unfortunately, Kya was the only character that was developed.  We really didn't get to know any other character to any extent.  The part from the trial to the end was like one quick blur.  I would have enjoyed it more if the beginning was shorter, characters were developed and the last part had more substance.  I won't spoil the ending.  I'll only say I found it strategically unlikely and was a bit of a stretch.
title: Somewhat Disappointed.

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2020
review_content: Where the Crawdads Sing was an absolute surprise as I purchased only for the name. A book set in eastern NC during the time that I grew up. Owens has completed a book which rivets through me and my childhood. Her characters lifted from the pages as it reading over your shoulder. The writing rich with language you know well when you're from NC.  I absolutely recommend this book.  Put it on your to read list.
title: An excellent read

author: Leslie Macchiarella
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2019
review_content: The marshland descriptions are nice, the topics of living alone and mistreatment of children are touching but the overall story is shallow and under developed and the characters are trite.  I could barely  get through the sex scenes. The author has great experience living alone in an outdoor environment and that part of the book shines. I would not have finished the book but it was my book club’s selection (they enjoyed it) so I listened to it on Audible during travel to get me through it.
title: Trite characters & story

author: R1Z2
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2018
review_content: I really enjoyed this book despite some criticism about the perceived weakness of character depictions  of the secondary male leads.  It has been noted they are both a bit stereotypically drawn as  good boy/bad boy characters,however, I found that easy to overlook when assessing the overall qualities of the novel.  I found the main character, Kya, aka swamp girl, captivating and particularly liked the descriptions of her isolated life and interactions with the natural world.  The coastal marshlands of North Carolina are as much a central character as any of the people and I really appreciated the wildlife scientist author’s  wonder filled and often poetic descriptions of the varying moods of the marshes and it’s wildlife.The novel includes a murder and a romantic entanglement to keep it moving along quickly and I believe readers will remain engaged throughout.
title: A very good read

author: sun_flower
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2019
review_content: It's a fun read if a little predictable. I guess it felt a little like a paint-by-numbers book--no shading, not enough subtlety. There were times when the author just didn't trust the reader to pick up on the implications of dialogue, so added too much explanation for my taste. Also, I didn't really buy that even an expert could identify a cheek feather of a flicker when separated from the bird itself. The trial seemed pretty anticlimactic to me. I liked many of the poetic descriptions, but again, sometimes they felt a little overwrought. Finally, I can't abide a love story where people want to spend virtually every waking hour together. It gives me the heebie-jeebies to even pretend that would be ok. The most poignant parts for me was Kya's loneliness and her love of the marsh. Those were worth the read.
title: Could be subtler

author: Mary Beth Boucher
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2019
review_content: I could not put this book down, and I can't believe that I almost allowed a negative reviewer keep me from reading this book...probably one of the best books I have ever read. Delia Owens has a complete command of a writing style that drips off the page--rife with personification and similes so unique and eloquent that you repeatedly wonder, "How did she come up with that?" The writing so entertaining yet descriptive that I could vividly picture every nuance. Here are a few of my favorites: "They sipped until the sun, as golden and syrupy as the bourbon, slipped into the sea." "Barkley Cove served its religion hard-boiled and deep-fried." "But loneliness had a compass of its own." I could go on and on. I felt as if I was in Kia's head living in the marsh.As far as the ending, I won't tell you how it ends, but I thought I was so smart and knew exactly what the last chapter would hold; however, I sat reading literally with my jaw dropped. Stunned and with a sly grin on my face, I reluctantly had to bid farewell to Kia and Tate. My, but what a fun ride that was.
title: One of the best books I've ever read!

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2019
review_content: I finally picked up this book after seeing it on so many best-seller lists.  I would agree with all the hype and say that it was a beautiful and engaging story.  The author really captures the many truths of human behavior, and the flipping between past and present made for an intricate and well-written story-line.  It was both heartbreaking and rewarding to follow Kya as she moves through her life surrounded by so many of the good and bad people that life has to offer.  The love story is very understated and artfully woven into a much bigger plot.  My only reason for four-stars is that I just didn't like the ending.  I am sure plenty of people would fight me on this, and I guess looking back, a small part of me had to have known this was where the story would lead.  I think if I reread the book, I would be even more sure of that based on Kya's connection with the laws of nature.  I might even say that I liked the rest of the book more because it did not serve me up the ending I wanted on a silver platter.  If we could give half-star on here, this would be a 4.5 for me.
title: Beautiful story, didn't love the ending.

author: Denise Adams
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2021
review_content: A remarkable story, you feel as if you are in the Carolina Marsh... feeling Kyas loneliness and pain. I found myself turning the pages quickly to see if somehow she would be rescued!  As a fiction survival biography I easily have related this young girls journey to my own real life account of survival depicted in .. “ I’ll Raise You Ten “. As well as many other chilling non fiction stories, like “ Spilled milk “  Coming of age survival stories are painful to read, but catch the readers emotions and love for their heroines quickly. Great writing, great story!  A must read at least once in your lifetime!
title: An amazing masterpiece!

author: KDubs322
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2019
review_content: This book was beautifully written by Delia Owens and I finished it within two days! Her descriptive writing had the perfect amount of detail and it didn't become too "flowery" to overwhelm the story. I enjoyed watching Kya evolve throughout her journey and there were many times I laughed, cried, became angry, or was incredibly happy! Although the chapters jumped between time periods, it wasn't difficult to follow along. I was pleasantly surprised by the ending and felt  satisfied once I finished it. In fact, I feel like I miss all of the characters now that it's done! As a lover of nature, I found it very easy to relate to Kya on many levels. I almost felt like this story mimicked the life of Mary Oliver in certain ways. I highly recommend this book!
title: Makes me want to live in a marsh

author: H2Odog477
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2020
review_content: What a story. The descriptions of the marsh and birds were like poetry they touched my soul. This book spoke to me like few others. The aloneness, the derision of being an outcast all the emotions that Kya felt I have as well. What a strong character in Kya and Tate the first last and only love she had beside her mother's. Jumpin' and Mabel at that time in North Carolina helping a lost innocent waif who had every reason to fail. This book was reminiscent of "Freckles" by Gene Stratton Porter a childhood friend. This book is worth reading again. Thanks sharing this wonderful story.
title: Wow incredible book!!!

author: Lisa
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2020
review_content: Although the story was entertaining, there is much that is very unconvincing. A six year old surviving living alone in a marsh, in poverty and isolation. Then as a young woman learning a college-like education from books and a dictionary given to her  as a young girl.However, the story of a woman and her experiences with the two loves of her life in her world of isolation and rejection  was entertaining enough to read it through.It dragged at times, and I was bored in her isolated marsh existence, however, it was the other characters that brought life to the story.
title: Entertaining but not gripping

author: Lady  "T"
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2019
review_content: This  story is set in a small town in the South near a marshy , swampy area. One can hear the critters scurry around and feel the sadness and unworthiness of Kya , the main character,  as she sorts out her life alone because her family all bailed out of her dysfunctional family. You feel you are living her life as she is ostracized by the people in town ! She finds an enduring relationship with a family living on the shores of the river.Love comes into her life as she blossoms into a beautiful girl and there the mystery begins to develop.Her boy friend is murdered and there the mystery begins. She is accused of the murder.The writing is great and brings the reader into close relationships with the characters and the prejudices of the folks who live in the small town!
title: Life of Kya in a small southern town where crawdad’s sing...

author: R. Simon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2019
review_content: To echo fellow one-star reviewers, I found reading this “acclaimed” book painful going..like trudging through swamp or sludge.  Sloppy plot, not believable and yet not magical enough to resemble a fairytale.  Unbelievable characters speaking in the most  annoying dialect.  Mark Twain could get away with it but here it just doesn’t,t work.  I have often wondered what editors do these days.  Maybe too busy keeping  their eyes on the $$$$ to pay attention to what passes for literature?
title: SLUDGE

author: Michael Brown
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2019
review_content: A book review said that this was about a girl's coming-of-age, the natural world, and a murder mystery. I needed gifts for my four great-nieces, so I bought them each a copy. They are becoming young women, and I thought this might be a good read for them. One of them will get a used copy, since I had to read it myself.
