I'm glad that I did both, reading it and giving these gifts.The book pulls you in immediately with the desperate situation of six-year-old Kya, mixed with the investigation of a murder that will involve her years later. She adopts her environment as her comforter, the sea, the swamp, the birds, the feathers, the shells. As she ages, she confronts rejection, love and loss, and domestic violence. As the reader is pulled into Kya's world, her experiences become more and more poignant since the reader has an understanding that most of the characters don't. As with most good books, once hooked, the urge to know what happens becomes compulsion.
title: A book for men, women, and the citizens of our planet. That's you.

author: Peter T. Tomaras, Author of Resistors and Innkeeper
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2019
review_content: This novel needs no more reviews, so I will simply second the emotion of the 12,000+ positive reviews.  I tend to avoid #1 bestsellers because I was burned by the awful writing of a few.  I kept seeing this book at or near the top in the WSJ Saturday listings, and when finally it was #1 for hardcover, e-book, and combined fiction, I yielded.  So glad I did.  I cry at some movies, and always when I see young people in performing art, or hear great sopranos (Callas, above all) bringing arias to life...rarely over books.  But at one point near the end of "Crawdads," tears simply rushed to my eyes.  So poignant, so evocative [a favored word among reviewers]--got to me.  I wish all novels I read could be so beautiful.  I was prepared with a criticism: the author so painstakingly follows the thoughts and actions of Kya until she is charged with a crime...then she skips what would seem to be obligatory scenes with her defense attorney.  Only later do we learn why, and it's all right.  In fact, no other way would it have worked so effectively.  So:  wonderful reading experience.  I will not soon forget.
title: Absolutely Beautiful

author: Library lady
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2019
review_content: The author has scored a home run with her first novel.  It is obvious that she labored lovingly over the text. The writing is superb. The story and the subplots  work well together, and every loose end is addressed at the conclusion.  What I liked best is that the main character, who we first meet as a young child, may have had a hard life, but she is never represented as a victim, nor does she think of herself in that way.  She is a survivor, in the very best sense of the word.  A compelling read about her growth into a fully developed person in her own right, despite circumstances that would have made a lesser person out of many of us. This is the best book I read  in 2019.  Highly recommended.
title: An incredible first novel

author: Cj Couch
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2020
review_content: Everyone told me to read this book. They said it was the best book they have read. Well, maybe my taste is just different, but I was bored and almost couldn’t finish it. The first 30 chapters could have been summed up into one. The last part picked up, but was predictable.The author writes well, but the storyline was unbelievable and too slow for me, and I lost interest very quickly. Was never so glad to finally finish a book.
title: Not Impressed

author: SLR
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2019
review_content: The audible book was very well done. As we live on an estuary in coastal Carolina, it was nice to listen to it every night while we looked out over the marsh. The book is very well done. There are some research failures that surprised me. One is that at no point she ever acknowledged alligators in the setting. The other is her complete failure to read a North Carolina map. The "big towns" everyone went to for supplies...Asheville about as far from the coast as you can get and still be in the same state. Wilmington and New Bern are pre-America cities with major ports and would have been the logical choice for heading to the city. I know the town in the book was fictional, but still. we had this book as our selection for book club, and everyone enjoyed it. I'd definitely read this author again.
title: Great narrator and storytelling.

author: Nancy R P
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2020
review_content: The voice of the main character in this novel,  "The Marsh Girl”, is poignant, believable, resilient, innovative and strong. As members of her family walk away from her drunken, violent father—and eventually, he disappears as well, she turns to nature for solace and comfort.  Befriended by a Local gas store manager and his wife, she is given clothing and emotional support.  A young boy, 4 years her senior, teaches her to read and count, so that she is able to self educate, and during this process, she falls in love with him.  But not everyone is kind to her; nor does every encounter end positively.  While I found the ending weak, much of the book was a very engaging and an enjoyable read.
title: Where the Crawdads Sing

author: Diane M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2020
review_content: A lot of my friends read this book on their summer vacation, so I came a bit late but decided to read it.  And I am so glad I did.  The beginning seems a bit sad and unreal, but you get caught up in the story of Kya and how she uses her survival skills.  I tried to envision myself in her shoes.  She is very smart, just uneducated until Tate comes along and teaches her how to read.  She takes off from there.  She is naive about the ways of the world but turns out to be capable of handling what life throws at her.  I live in North Carolina so the marshes were so interesting to me.  I highly recommend this book!
title: Beautifully written, hard to put down

author: Obsessed with romance
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2019
review_content: This book was AMAZING! It was a book club read for me and we all enjoyed this one... I can see it becoming a movie. The setting is perfectly described I could literally see things as they are described. I enjoyed the book from beginning to end. Kya as a character is so innocent, sweet, resilient and wonderfully made.. crafty and smart and knows her way around a Marsh! Tate is my guy and Chase.. well.. you’ll find out. This is a great story.. a story of loss.. a lot of loss that it makes you angry.. but the way she- Kya returns from her loss and triumphs makes you become a huge cheerleader in the end! You won’t be disappointed..
title: Definitely a must read! Love this!

author: Kathy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2018
review_content: Owens found a way to combine her two, seemingly unrelated, gifts: her ability to describe her natural surroundings, and her ability to truly understand human motivations. The result is "Where the Crawdads Sing," a story about a little girl who grows up with the creatures of the marsh as her only friends and family.  Owens' writing is so good, I felt like I was walking alongside Kya as she explored the marshes and lagoons of the backwater.  I almost felt the salt spray on my skin and the feathers in my hand, and the squishy mud between my toes. I also deeply related to Kya's need for love and acceptance, and her gratitude towards any nugget of kindness her father threw her way.  While I think some parts of the book are improbable (at best), they don't take away from the book at all.  The magic in this book is the author's ability to make me feel like I'm there in the salt marsh.  Absolutely brilliant.
title: I could almost smell the briny air

author: Margaret
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2019
review_content: It's been forever since I've been compelled to put my life on hold to read a book from start to finish! Ms. Owens is a rare talent.  Not once did I see a single word in this book. I saw a beautiful world in which a tormented soulful woman lived, surviving and excelling through heart rending hardship. I laughed and cried page after page.  Each character jumped to vivid life and became fully developed individuals with thoughts, feelings and hearts though some were rotten and hateful. Others were fine and wonderful people. This book would make an incredible movie.  I am so happy and grateful to have come across a book that should be a classic piece of literature. I await with alacrity for her future novels. Thank you Delia Owens.
title: Absolute Best Book I've Read This Year

author: Lisa
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2019
review_content: The book was a beautiful read. Some of the main character’s ability to survive were hard to believe but I appreciated the story line and the incredible description of the marsh. The ending was a huge disappointment. The facts at the end didn’t stand up to the carefully crafted  portrayal of Kya’s inability to deal with people and go outside of her marsh.  How she could have obtained the needed items to pull it off without someone stepping forward with knowledge of purchases was implausible, so was the timing. It would have been far better for one of several possible people to leave the necklace for Kya and leave who did it  it a mystery. Wrapping up the mystery in this case ruined the book.
title: Ouch! That ending! Contains possible spoiler.

author: Noel R
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2019
review_content: I guess I am too much of a realist.  I could not get into this fairy tale of a story.  The fact that a young girl raises herself in the swamp, learns how to read and is equivalent to a college graduate,  and then becomes a famous author with little contact with the outside world was just silly and unrealistic to me.  I was disappointed since everyone said it was so amazing.
title: Unrealistic-Spoiler alert

author: L Felts
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2019
review_content: I’m a picky reader. It doesn’t make me a critic as I dont have a knowledge base, other than my own, to critique someone’s hard earned work. However, this book is like a clever spider distracting you by it’s beautiful web before it snatches you. And, that is what this author does. She calls to you like a siren. I found myself smiling frequently at her clever descriptions of the marsh. I could easily see the shack and feel the heat and hear the cicadas singing. The story was fascinating as well. I had to physically put my hand over the page so my eyes wouldn’t jump ahead to learn the outcome. And, when it was over, I didn’t want it to be over. I can’t believe this is her first novel and I cant waIt to read more. Until then, I think I will enjoy this one again.
title: I want to go where the crawdads sing...

author: L. Paquet
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2020
review_content: My wife and I both enjoyed reading Where the Crawdads sing. This novel combines a tragic childhood that is overcome by a very strong and resourceful girl. Her mother is forced to leave their marsh shack to escape the alcoholic husband. The children are faced with the grim prospects of staying home to endure more abuse or run away and try to make their own way. The novel is a nice length- not too short and not one of those 600 page marathons that I grew tired of. There's a murder mystery included and the main character learns to succeed while living a very unconventional life.
title: This is a novel for people who don't like to read novels.

author: P. Blevins
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2019
review_content: Where the Crawdads Sing was written by Delia Owens. This is her first novel but she has written other nonfiction books before.  Her first try at a novel is fantastic. She brings to life the marsh of North Carolina where Kya lived.  As Kya, Tate, and Chase move throughout the marsh, the reader can see the cypress knees, the various plants and grasses and hear the sounds of the birds, the frogs, and the other animals that inhabit the sprawling wilderness.  She does a fantastic job in creating Kya and helping her grow from a little girl surrounded by family to a little girl surviving on her own in the marsh as she waits for her Mother to return.  We feel her shyness and fright when Tate and Chase invade her space. We sigh with awe as we watch her fall in love only to be left alone.This book is definitely one which should be on everyone’s summer reading list.
title: Wonderful reading- remember it is a novel

author: Gloria Squitiro
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2019
review_content: So many children grow up without a voice. Owens describes—in beautiful language that is all her own—the extreme of what can come of not being heard, from not feeling loved or worthy. Yet she also shows the sheer strength that often evolves from having to go it alone. An incredible story that I didn’t want to end. Thank you for tucking me into bed each night, at least, for a little while.Gloria Squitiro: A first lady of Kanas City and author of May Cause Drowsiness and Blurred Vision: The Side Effects of Bravery—YOU, Too! can OVERCOME ANXIETY and live a bigger more carefree life—Become a New and Better You!#YayWomenWriters
title: #WomenPower

author: Heather T.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2021
review_content: I absolutely loved this book. I recommend it to all of my reader friends that haven’t read it yet. This book had been on my list of books to read for well over a year. So glad I finally ordered it and read it. Definitely a favorite of mine by far! Loved the story, the characters, and maybe it’s just me, but I didn’t see that ending coming!
title: Such a great story

author: MAS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2020
review_content: Most of me understands why a lot of people liked this book but it wasn't for me. Sometimes the character development was great but most of the time it dragged on my brain. Walking on the beach, dancing on the beach, looking for shells, and the unbelievability that a very small child could survive alone and no one was concerned enough to find out why her mother was never seen again. Apparently taking a young girls word 'that her mother was too busy' to do the usual chores she did in town before she left. I figured out the end way before the end. All in all, it's a good vacation read or a long airplane trip book.
title: Not my favorite kind of book ...

author: Carol P. Zimring
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2019
review_content: The book gets off with a somewhat slow story line; it seems like it's going to be the usual white trash family that dwells in the south, but it doesn't take long til you see there's a big different!  You have an opportunity to learn a lot about the life forms in the marsh areas and the relationship our heroine has with all that she comes across.  There are some very kind characters that help her out without her even knowing it, and they play a big role in the story as it progresses.  Things turn very dark for our "Marsh Girl" and you have to hold your breath as you keep reading [faster], because you're terrified about the outcome.  It turns into a complete who-dunit i- and I won't say any more!
title: A Terrific Read that Sneaks Up on You as You Go Along

author: Deb B
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2020
review_content: This author’s use of poetic magical and lyrical wording is quite well done.  Actually a step above most authors, but when she strings the words into sentences and then paragraphs, finally ito chapters it reads like books I read in the 4th grade....quite simplistic and disappointing.  But if you are looking for a good book, I would still recommend this one as her knowledge of North Carolina marshes and wildlife is spot on and refreshing.  That alone makes for a good read as she does it without boring you in her process.Overall well done.
title: Poetic magical wording but prose lacking

author: C. J. Edwards
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2019
review_content: First, I loved the dedication.I can't remember when a child has been a more sympathetic character than Kya in this book.When I read "But Ma's carryin' that blue case like she's goin' somewheres big" I was totally hooked. It was so hard to imagine a mother and eventually other family members taking off and leaving a six year old alone. She walked four miles by herself - barefooted to get some food at the Piggly Wiggly. Can you imagine?Such a richly written story with a mystery within, completed with beautiful descriptions of the world in which the "Marsh Girl" lives. I understood her connection to the birds...sometimes I believe the birds are what makes Florida livable.
title: Beautifully Written

author: Danielle Ciesielski
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2018
review_content: This story will captivate you, from the first sentence to the very last word as Delia Owens weaves you through a tale as thick as the marsh brambles. It's easy to see this best seller on the big screen, as Owens paints a masterfully crafted tale of love, loss, and mystery swirling around the most elusive of all the marsh creatures -Kya. After a long life of twist and turns, Kya has learned a few helpful things about marsh life and how to survive therein. Follow along as she hides among the palmettos, staying always just out of sight -just out of reach. From her scenic descriptions to her gripping storyline, every twist and turn will keep you enthralled. It's a book I couldn't put down, but I didn't want to end; I truly loved every word.
title: Couldn't put it down but didnt want it to end

author: PHM
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2019
review_content: The storyline of an abandoned young girl who learns how to survive alone in the wilderness was unique and original, and the author’s writing style was beautifully descriptive and almost mesmerizing in its style. However, after a key plot element occurs towards the end of the story, the author goes on to summarize the next 30+ years of the story in a cliff-notes-like synopsis. The ending lacked all of the elements of prose that I had found so captivating up to that point. It was as if she had a publishing deadline to meet, so she summarized all of her ideas for the ending into one “35-year chapter”. She would have done better to leave more to the reader’s imagination, in my opinion. Despite this, I still enjoyed the book and found it to be a solid first novel for the author.
title: Beautifully written until the end

author: kjs
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2021
review_content: Let me start by saying, I almost never read fiction and every time I try to "get into fiction" I find myself bored and putting the book down and not picking it back up. This book was recommended to me by a friend, and I was skeptical, but from the start I found myself drawn in. The story line is intriguing, the characters are relatable, and I thoroughly enjoyed it! I also appreciated that most of the chapters were short, so it's easy to read and take breaks if you are the type who can't sit still long. You won't regret getting this book!
title: Renewed my love of reading for pleasure

author: ReviewingRita
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2019
review_content: Let me start with this: If you're looking for a book about dysenteria, STDs, negativity, and all the other bull crap reviews that the one starers have put out there, then yes, do not read this book. If you're looking for a book that makes you feel good, with a few unexpected twists, and restores your faith in humanity and love, I feel confident in saying you'll love this book.The bad reviews are absolutely asinine and people with a stick up their ass. Seriously.♥️♥️♥️♥️Taaaaaaaaaate♥️♥️♥️♥️♥️If you love the notebook, the help, secret life of bees, the glass castle, water for elephants, and on and on (or any book ever that has made you feel so good after reading it), this is your book!  I finished reading it 2 months ago and I still can't stop thinking about the characters!!! Again, don't be fooled by the bad reviews, I promise you'll feel good after reading this!!!
title: So. Freaking. Good!!!!!!!!

author: Cheryl J.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2020
review_content: Even the sentences seemed to flow like the tide coming in and going out. Sometimes there were rip currents and fog and it became dangerous. But nature-and life isn’t predictable and neither was this story. Sometimes I think nature tried to calm her, especially when she was young and had to grow up too fast. I’ve lived in places just like this, and even though I was going through some difficult things, this book made me remember why I begged my parents to get that house on the river. It brought back some good memories. I will say that I avoid books that make me cry. I read so I can escape life for a while. I cried but I also enjoyed this book so much that I feel like it was worth it. I don’t say that very often.
title: Beautiful

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2018
review_content: So much to love about this book, particularly Kya, the lonely lover of her natural world, abandoned as a small child by her biological family. But the ending felt rushed and contrived - like the author wasn't quite confident in her format and needed to complete with a bang of courtroom drama.
title: Great story, weak ending!

author: M. Collins
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2020
review_content: Loved this book. Great story, engaging, and I particularly enjoyed the ending. Only thing keeping it from being a 5-star novel, in my opinion is, at times, it seemed to languish, then suddenly, speed up. This isn’t a spoiler alert, but stop reading if you’re afraid to learn something you might not want to know, but I particularly enjoyed that the reader discovered the WHOLE STORY without having to read every single detail of the WHOLE STORY. Ruminating on the author’s style, I really enjoyed the chronological discord, even though it frustrated me at times. Now, though, I get it.
title: Bummed That It’s Over

author: S. Cox
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2019
review_content: I was hesitant to read this beautiful book for some reason. First a friend recommended it, then I read a bad review.  I take issue with that review, but we all have different tastes. The reviewer said it was a ridiculous premise, a 6 year old left to fend for herself in marshy, coastal Carolina. I get that, but if you will just suspend your disbelief for a moment and let the beautiful writing hypnotize you, you will be transported, as I was, to a different time and place. Kya, the main character, manages with help from very few people and only one day’s formal education, to raise herself, survive despite the abandonment of her entire family, and become a renowned naturalist.  She finds love and betrayal and is ultimately accused and tried for murder. More than that I won’t say. I actually hope my book club selects it so I can read it again, this time not at warp speed, so I can savor every lyrical word.
title: Hard to put down.

author: Alexis Powell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2020
review_content: Beautifully written.  This story draws you in immediately,  Kaya is someone very intriguing that you want to protect throughout the story.  The backdrop immediately wants to send me to North Carolina in hopes that this little town/marsh truly exists!There’s a few disgruntled reviewers bitter about the accuracy of the setting, but it’s fiction...is it supposed to be 100% accurate?  Ms. Owens wildlife knowledge paints a beautiful depiction of the marsh, I found myself retelling my grandsons about the traits of a firefly. I finished it in just a couple days.  I loved it.
title: Delia Owens paints a beautiful backdrop for Kaya

author: Rachel Brown
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2020
review_content: I can't believe this book got so many  5 stars with so many people. I thought it was one of the most boring book I ever read....OVERATED BIG TIME!!
title: OVERRATED

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2019
review_content: I looked forward to reading this book based on the rave reviews but was let down again and again.  The story is about a young girl who is basically left to raise herself in a marsh.  She has no education, no money, no family, yet manages to survive.  Miraculously, she learns to read with the help of a boy who befriends her, and in no time is reading college level books.The book doesn't know if it's a love story, a coming of age story, or a murder mystery, so the author chose to make it all of these.  I saw the ending as soon as the murder mystery began and the courtroom scenes and our heroine's actions are  implausible.  The story has an unsatisfying ending which is tied up with a bow in just a few pages.I would not recommend this book as a "must" read.
title: Very disappointing

author: Cynthia Carbone
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2019
review_content: I will never understand the rave reviews for this one. The writing seemed stilted and heavy-handed, characters exaggerated, the plot implausible. Perhaps not meant to be taken literally, a metaphor for something about wildness and the natural world? I try to be gentle, as a former writing teacher and writer myself, but this was disappointing, given the hype. In fact, it reminded me of a self-conscious student effort. I finally just skimmed through.
title: Sorry, but the rave reviews are inexplicable.

author: ppsc
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2019
review_content: The book was generally well-written (as in, without grammatical mistakes), and it was a quick read which held my attention from beginning to end.  The characters were interesting and fairly well-developed.  In these respects I liked it, but the ending was quite predictable and contrived.  Also,the entire history of the main character was so unbelievable as to read more like fantasy or science- fiction than a mystery.  None of the events which occurred seemed believable to me, and in restrospect, I can only give the book 3 stars.  My initial feeling was that the book was very fascinating, but as it continued, the plot got more and more hard to believe.  Just sayin'
title: Fascinating but so unbelievable, it gives me mixed feelings

author: Tina Keller
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2020
review_content: One of the best books I have ever read. I have never reviewed a book.  This book takes you through an abandoned child's eyes who had zero education and no one to love her but then it proves unconditional love. As Kya ages and improves upon herself the writer takes you through that journey as well. Kya's voice and purpose changes and the writer guides one through that effortlessly. I was left in awe at the end.  The reader is left questioning everything and putting puzzels together. I felt I built a relationship with Kya and I felt everything she felt.  It is just perfect!
title: Such an amazing read!

author: Laurielv
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2019
review_content: This book is going to be in my mind for a very long time. The beautiful language is exceptional. The author paints such a vivid picture throughout that I truly felt as if I was in the marsh with Kya. The twists and turns kept me reading (even when I needed to be doing something else) and I finished the book in two days. The beauty, the mysteries, the wonderful characters - both good and bad - will all be a part of me for a long time. I highly recommend this book. It’s a wonderful journey. I just wish the books she wrote in this story were real. It would be a way to continue the beauty of this story. I’m not a big fan of poetry, but this story really spoke to me on such a poetic level.
title: Just so beautiful!

author: kasey barton
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2020
review_content: Find it hard to fathom that, apparently, so many people enjoyed this read.  The book lacked editorial correction,  droning on and on in descriptive circles.  Plot was so very predictable,  By the end, which was ridiculous, I really did not care, at all, what happened to mud girl.  Was touted as a mystery, yet plot twists were so obvious.  Characters were cliches, borrowed from other writers.  Historical research was clearly missing in background of towns, name used, navigation and boats.  So many holes in this tale, so forgettable, sigh, another kindle wasted read.
title: rambling metaphoric predictable Mess

author: F. Shepherd
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2019
review_content: This was a stunning first novel from anyone... and the best I have read in many years. I could not put it down once it had me hooked. While it is being panned by a few because they found it hard to believe a 7-year-old girl could "raise herself" in the swamps of Louisiana... I found that part absolutely fascinating... and, unlike others, I remembered this was a "novel" and not a "first-person account." In fact, I found the fact of her being alone the best part of the novel... loved each page... so did my wife and several neighbors. Never once did I hear that poppycock of "can't believe she did that".... You will not spend your money any better than this novel.. what's to lose? Absolutely everything if you don't read this .....
title: An A+ First Novel

author: Lata Pimplaskar
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2019
review_content: The book for its rich prose qualifies as literary novel. Initially a reader can easily get involved in character of Kya who draws sympathy as an abandoned child. However, many parts of story are unrealistic. Kya’s behavior and take on life is learned mainly from Nature. The birds and insects, fish and many others sources that she daily observes.The best parts of the book is the amazing detailed description of Marsh and its habitat. She learns observing them as to how to survive, Love or kill. Also how to bait to kill.However, love and understanding of poetry and publishing books etc. is a long stretch in real life. The end is where the book concludes Kya of Marsh.  Wonderful read! Will read again to absorb in the nature!
title: Kya learns from Marsh species to survive, to love and to revenge

author: Julie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2019
review_content: I really liked this book - but not enough to give it 5-stars. There were a few things that didn't make sense to me. This woman who lives on her own and eschews human contact for the most part, somehow ends up getting handymen to fix up her house. She doesn't have a telephone and so some of the contacts she makes to get things done just don't add up. But, if you can suspend your disbelief, it's a charming story that will bring back the same feelings you may have had when you read books 20 or 30 years ago about kids who grow up in the wild. Oddly, this very much reminded me of the 1994 movie Nell, starring Jodie Foster. I say, read it!
title: I enjoyed this!

author: Jodi
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2020
review_content: I enjoyed this book because I liked the storyline, however I personally thought that alot of the writing was kind of sloppy. The time lines didn't always match up and I thought that alot of her descriptions of things were either way over board and wordy or not enough.  The biggest issue I had with it wasn't even alot of the "unrealistic" parts, it was that the ending seemed very jammed together in order to be complete, yet the biggest moment that you wait for when the two main characters finally come together was so short ans not nearly as sweet as  it should have been.All in all it was a good book, but could have been sooo much better.
title: Could have been better. SPOILER ALERT

author: Michelle
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2019
review_content: It's hard to write book reviews since so much of whether or not you enjoy a book is subjective, but I'm not sure why people are so very in love with this book. I found it to be a real let down after the hype. It had so many elements that I hoped were building to something interesting, and I didn't dislike the main character, but there was a lot for her that fell strangely into place despite her circumstances. I generally dislike when people complain a plot is predictable since I think that's subjective and part of a book is how you get there, not just what happens. But I just didn't find the writing in this story interesting enough to overcome the predictability of it.
title: Didn't grab me

author: Walking Man
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2019
review_content: Where the Crawdads Sing is a skillfully written murder mystery. The nagging question for me was how an abandoned child could possibly grow up basically on her own in such an impoverished environment in the 1960s and 70s. My familiarity with the Outer Banks of that time period is limited to annual beach vacations, but something about the setting and lifestyle of the characters in the book just doesn't ring true. Nevertheless, the story is engaging, even given that the obligatory PC elements are quite "in your face." For me, there is an eerie suggestion of the O. J. Simpson murder case lurking in the background. For cat lovers, there is an endearing black and white who makes an appearance toward the end of the story. As a bildungsroman the book is a little shallow, but still a good mystery read.
title: A bit of a stretch, but very engaging nonetheless.

author: Cranky Egg beater
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2021
review_content: I read the reviews for this book and the ones I read were so awful I had to pay the 30 chits to see what all the fuss was about.  I read folks saying there was no way some of these things could have happened in the ways its told and such. I'll tell ya . It was worth every dollar spent. This is an amazing story and I have absolutely no doubt this story was written by someone that lived it. And I say this from a place of someone that lived a similar version in the 70s and 80s. The independence life hands you when you stare this life style in the face is not a choice. It is survival.  And any person wanting to debate that point was likely born with a silver spoon in their bits. Beautifully and graphically written. The language is outstanding.  I recommend the read. It is definitely worth it ♡ And many thanks to whoever told this story♡
title: The most amazing but horribly reviewed story ever written.

author: Mae Clair
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2019
review_content: I expected this book to be great, given all the buzz it's had. The story is engaging and holds the reader's interest. I was especially taken with the vivid descriptions of the marsh and small-town life in the 1960s. I was halfway through the story thinking how good it was, but waiting for that extra something to make it "great."And then it happened...The last third of this book is what elevates it beyond good story-telling to exceptional story-telling. Where the Crawdads Sing deserves all of the accolades it's received and more. The characters are ones that will linger in my mind for a long time to come, especially the conclusion of their story. As for the marsh--it became a character in itself. This is a book I can easily see myself going back and reading again.
title: Lose Yourself in an Exceptional Story...

author: Jten
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2020
review_content: This is now one of my top five favorite books, and I am very picky. It evoked so much feeling - such haunting longing for human connection that was instead provided by the marshlands and all its splendor. The joy from a bird’s feather, the smoothness of shells. Delia Owens is a master naturalist and an amazing storyteller with her poignant, beautiful descriptions of Kya’s home, her abandonment, her strength.
title: Moved to my core

author: J. Barker
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2019
review_content: Where the Crawdads Sing by Delia Owens immediately engages you, and doesn’t let go until you’ve turned the last page!  Kya is an amazing character — abandoned as a small child, she learns how to survive against all odds. You’ll feel her heartache at being so alone, and you’ll celebrate each of her accomplishments!  I couldn’t put this book down, and was so sad to see it end.  Don’t miss out on this monumental read!I hope Delia Owens is hard at work on her second novel — she is a phenomenal writer!  Her descriptions of the natural world are unparalleled and they pull you in, making you feel like you’re right there with Kya, seeing what she sees — you become part of the experience.This book will be with me for a long time to come.
title: One of the best books I’ve read in a long time!

author: Garden4Fun
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2019
review_content: I liked this book, a lot.  Sure, parts of it are unrealistic, a child on her own, no one coming to her aid.  That's the way her life was, and she was up against the stares, glares and gossip.  She was an easy target.  Sure, the author could have made it more realistic but why?  That aside, the story is wonderful.  So different.  Not to mention the descriptions of the marsh and its inhabitants that the author throws in.  I could feel just what she was talking about.  Being an outdoors and wild animal enthusiast myself, I enjoyed those bits of nature.  Reading is for entertainment, it does not always have to be correct and proper.  Those who are reading the negative reviews, give the book a chance.  I think you'll be glad you did.
title: A good read

author: Karen Beth Martin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2020
review_content: I usually read classic literature, lots of British and Russian stuff. I picked this one up for my Mom who likes more contemporary stuff and fleetingly thought that I might read it too since I do like nature writing. She read it first and LOVED it so I dove into it. I'm not sure what I was expecting but... I LOVE THIS BOOK. The story is great in itself but the writing is just otherworldly. I've sent it to friends as gifts and plan to read it again at some point. I cannot recommend it highly enough. Truly a beautiful reading experience.
title: This one surprised me.

author: TC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2018
review_content: My wife saw this as a recommendation on reading the Wall Street Journal.  She ordered it immediately and read it within a day and a half over Thanksgiving while fixing dinner for fourteen people.  The author describes a plausible story, probably personal or close to home and weaves a knowledge of science and local southern culture into it.  I read it today in just over three hours.  Wow.  This should be a movie.  Netflix, pay attention.
title: Should Be A Movie

author: Linda : )
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2020
review_content: There is a rhythm and flow to this novel that draws you in and becomes a part of you. Delia Owens has the ability to engage all your senses so you can feel the moisture of the marsh, smell the earth, taste the air, see the feathered brow of a bird and hear the slightest breeze. But she takes you to deeper senses, of feelings of wonder, shame, survival, abandonment, confusion, simplicity and so many others. The story is gut=wrenching and sweet, not in an artificial sweetness but one of politeness, It is a well=woven tale that continues to draw you in, deeper and deeper. I eagerly wait for another novel by Delia Owens.
title: A Melodic Novel

author: Candy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2019
review_content: "Where the Crawdads Sing" is truly a marvelous book.  The author, Delia Owens, must have an innate talent for writing.  While she is known for her nonfiction, it is quite extraordinary that she could write her first piece of fiction with such accomplishment and artistry.  The book is truly a work of art.  Owens' ability to weave factual information from nature into the story's plot with such ease is remarkable.  Further, unlike many authors today, she delivered information in an interesting manner without overdoing description and losing the reader's attention.  It was so easy to become attached to the characters, Kya and Tate.  The book sustained my attention throughout, and I was quite sad to finish it.  I hope to see another novel by Delia Owens in the near future.
title: Exquisite Novel

author: Kathleen W
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2019
review_content: This beautifully written story takes a reader through the painful experience of a young girl who suffers abject rejection — and abandonment — who has a will to survive and just enough caring, tender-hearted people to enable her to prevail. Her astonishing survival skills are nothing short of miraculous. She matures, is nurtured by a special gentle friend who teaches her to read and provides her with books that expand her knowledge and understanding of the marsh where she lives, as well aspects as the world beyond. There is soul-crushing sadness, yet tender moments of joy. The mystery of an apparent murder woven through the life of this girl when she becomes a woman resolves in a way that leaves the reader with a sigh ... and, in my case, a smile.
title: A beautifully well-woven tale that ends with poetic justice

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2019
review_content: WHERE THE CRAWDADS SING is as much a nature study as it is a novel. It is lyrical in its descriptions of swamps and marshes and the creatures that inhabit them. Author Delia Owens has spent much of her life in wild places, and it shows.  The story is well-told, though I found the character descriptions a bit wooden and mundane. Still it was an interesting read, and it had enough tension to keep me turning the pages.
title: An Ode to Swamp Ecology

author: Marianna J
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2020
review_content: This is truly one of the best books I’ve ever read, and I’m an avid reader. My top favorite will always be To Kill a Mockingbird, but this came really close. Where the Crawdads Sings was the first novel written by a scientist who usually wrote technical work. She’s so observant of the natural world ( and her description of it is magical, and is a character in the book) that it plays a big part in the novel. It was a joy to read and the “twist” came literally two pages before the end. A true reading joy, I have read it multiple times with a surprise everytime’
title: Shot to my top ten!!

author: Anne Marie Holen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2020
review_content: Mostly I was disappointed in this book. If it were marketed as Young Adult Fiction I would be more generous in my review. Not bad for a "first novel" and I hope the author writes more. But this story needed more exposition, not just a few sentences to explain so many of the improbable occurrences in the book. I could accept that the main character basically raised herself starting at age 6 or 7, it's all the other improbabilities that I struggled with. Anyway, it was a quick easy read so I won't call it a waste of time, but it's not a great book.
title: OK, but not great

author: Algelis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2020
review_content: I as a male would probably be turned off if I was told the story from beginning to end. But I would be so foolish to do so, this novel has a way of drawing you in page by page for figure out what becomes of our main character Kya. I don't want to discuss the details but what I would say and what grasped me the most is how grounded this story is. I couldn't helping think about how many people out there live this life in real life. This a great read and my first novel in many years (I usually read non fiction) If you haven't read a fictional book in many years pick this one up and explore the story knowing as little as possible.
title: A heartwarming AND heartwrenching perspective of solitude

author: Joe M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2020
review_content: This book was recommended by my dentist, who is female.  It's a fairly good read but is more attuned to the more romantically inclined souls.  The story of a young girl coming of age in the backwaters of North Carolina (a better setting would have been the bayous of Louisiana.)  Here, she is abandoned first by her mother and then by her brother, leaving her alone with her drunkard and abusive father.  In this setting she meets the boy of her dreams, who also abandons her leaving her to fall into the clutches of a misogynistic Romeo.  She is eventually accused of murdering him and the story evolves from that point . . .
title: Would Make a Good Chic Flic
